Subject: Re: cops & racism

Status: OR

Chris,

I agree with everyhting you said.  I think that the cops/race/sex/etc.
issues are all in some way related to the rave scene.  I mean for the MOST
part raves are for everyone and for all races and sexual bents.  The cops
figure in as a MINOR irritant, which at times acts as the glue to keep us
all cohesive in our attempt to enjoy ourselves and our community.  I know
this sounds drippy, but I DO believe it.

Many people have pointed out how the discussions on the net of late have
been, "pointless", or "have degenerated".  I see it as just the opposite.
Underneath all the love and smarm some people like to push there are
questions.  And if you look at the subject matter that has been discussed of
late, flames not withstanding, there has been a fruitful dialog.  We have
talked about sex, age, race, public policy, sexuality,and humanity over the
course of these discussions.  How BORING it would be to JUST have party
announcments, and record reviews (both of which are important to many),
instead of a total expression of feelings that has occurred over the past
month.

There has been much chaos on the scene.  And this is reflected everyhwere,
from arguments here, to murders at parties, it has at times seemd like
everything was becoming unraveled.  In truth though things have become
better defined.  People are starting to take action (the benefit for Mal is
JUST one instance) in many forms.  Some have stopped going to parties that
are not open to more age groups, some have taken their cause up with lawyers
and the legislative process.  Overall a beautiful and pro-active thing, if
carried out fully.  So bag all of this apologetic shit, because in one way
or another it realtes to us.  If not as fellow party-goers (I have the term
"raver") then surely as human beings.

Peace.

(Oh yeah, it should read I HATE the term "ravers"---oops fingers slower
than the mind :).

again, in response to john,
i agree that we as women relinquish our power when we look to jenny craig
(who is she, anyway?) however, i think we all have to remember that for many
of us, loving our bodies is a STRUGGLE, is RESISTANCE, against the
dominant/dominator culture that keeps us buying their diet products and their
other consumer goods to overcome what are perceived as, constructed as,
inadequacies.  sure it's great when a woman feels powerful enuf to take her
clothes off in public - i've done it in countless gay pride marches til the
sun started burning my titties.  but i'm getting off-track.. .. just remember
that while the confidence may come from within, it is a result of active
resistance to media messages, and it is a PROCESS. the fact that women may
want to look more like jenny craig than themselves is not a result of
individual neurosis, but is a SOCIAL issue.  

monicat

Subject: Cops, Montreal, H2O...
To: ne-raves@gnu.ai.mit.edu, sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Date: Sun, 2 May 1993 13:13:31 -0400 (EDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL21]
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 1958      
Status: OR

This week we were talking about cops on sfraves and neraves. I said that we
didn't have any problems with them here. Until now.
Last night (saturday may 1st) was H2O LIFEJUICE in Montreal. A big event,
totally commercial, tickets sold in advance 15$. Got in with some help at 11pm
but if i had done the lineup i would have got in at 2am... At 3 am, the system
is shut down, lights turned on. On the mike: "the cops are here. please leave
the building, thank you.". Everybody sat on the floor (what happens in most
case when there are large crowds faced to the cops here) and waited. At first
i couldn't see any cops, then suddenly i see about 75 cops all geared up with
helmets, sticks etc... People were not leaving. Then the cops start running
in the crowd, then stop. Panic. people running everywhere, afraid of beeing
clubbed. When trying to find my way out, i saw a girl with blood on her head
but i couldn't get to her to see what was happening (turns out she is ok, but
it is not sure if its because of the cops or people running). Again they
start running in the crowd, then stop. Somebody picks up the mike: "yo, give
them a chance to get out, there is only 1 door left open!".

It turns out that the event didn't have a "special event license". Talk about
organisation! Still the cops showed up because clubs are putting a lot of
pressure on the city council to shut down the raves since Solstice. It seems
that the owner of Metropolis and Royal and some other places are really
pissed off. Well, people maybe would go more to these clubs if the crowd and
the music was interesting...

Ciao,
-- 
Francois Dion

>i just recently attended a panel on raves in san francisco... the likes
>of markie mark, 

An SFRaver!  Yay :) (oh, he's NOT the guy in the underwear - wholly 
different person)

>neesa (the earth girl), 

She generated some interesting discussion about feminism and the like - 
and as to why she was the only woman up there.  Hmm...  basically the
issue was sorta resolved when an audience member said we needed to
transcend the concepts of patriarchy and matriarchy and look at the
panel not at 8 men and 1 women but as 9 people.

>mark healey, 

Former ToonTown promoter, basically one of the guys who helped bring 
House music to SF (and also later on one of the cheif over-commercializers,
but he sounded like he'd stopped throwing parties because he didn't want
the monster he'd created) - quite eloquent and thoughtful in all his
responses.

>bruce eisner, 

Author of "Ecstasy: the MDMA story" - why he was on a "future of raves"
panel is a little beyond me.... h

>dante (? from new york... something like tribal evolution ?), 

He was REALLY GREAT - very positive in all his comments, definitely 
someone who "has got it".  Talked to him afterwards - he's still waiting
for his terminal, Chuck :)

>and well, i'll probably fuck
>up the rest of the names, so i won't try... 

There was Ernie Munson, SF DJ (and very high on the spiritual aspect
of raves), Alan (a promoter, does Wicked and the Full Moons), Tef 
(from LA - one of the main large-rave promoters down there - didn't
say much), and Nick Philips (the moderator for the panel)

>anyway, the panel was pretty cool
>and they talked about the future of raves, the rave mindset/consciousness, and
>such stuff... 

Yeah, it was great to finally see people throwing the parties start talking
about stuff like this - particularly the realization that we need to start
taking some responsibility for what we're doing, we need to start better
representing ourselves to the outside world.  Read like 2 hours worth of
good SFRaves or ne-raves mail :)

>what i wanted to know is, what is it like out on the east coast?

The same, I hope.  I got my tickets Friday - May 28th-June 8th!  Hello,
Boston & NY!

>some of the points made were:
>
>--rave is not just hedonism, but rather rave and house music serve as
>  a vehicle to self-realization, self-empowerment, self-consciousness

Definitely, but we shouldn't limit the parties to only those who see
raves as such a holistic viewpoint.  People should arrive at this 
conclusion naturally.

>--rave is a subcultural arena in which music and dancing unite the 
>  people (music and dancing created by the people for the people)...
>  the unifying factor is that the individual is free-form dancing but
>  together with the group in a sort of group trance effect
>--no one is a leader at a rave... the beauty is that everyone is equal

Definitely - it's easy to lose this focus (is this why I'm never 
impressed by live acts at raves?)

>--rave is at a crucial point in its existence; the commercial market
>  is taking hold of it fast BUT ravers have the power to transcend 
>  this commercialization if they will it; never underestimate the power
>  of dance and you can not put a price tag on the rave experience

Here here!

>there was a lot more raised in during this session, but all the while that 
>this was going on, i couldn't halp think that "wow, this sounds straight
>out of nietzsche or some other philosphical text" (you know, the one where 
>nietzschesays that art should be our religion... 

Ack... never thought of this as Nietzsche - maybe I should go do some
reading... 

>we should sombine the dionysiac and the apollonian, or 
>the hedonistic and the more structured, rational forms of art, in
>order to experience oneness, unity, etc... "the birth of tragedy)... that's
>really deep and all and as cool as shit... at the same time, however, i think
>there are certain realities to raves that impede this realization process...

Yes... another thing I noted was that people had lots of lofty ambitions but
came up short in trying to think of specific ways to implement them.

>basically, what i'm looking for is a response to this... some of the things 
>i've said are meant to simply provoke a reaction... 

aaa!  provocation!  aaa!

>what do you easterners think?

BTW, I'm cc:ing this to SFRaves for obvious reasons :)  

>is this techno shamanism unique to san fran/california? and again... coming
>back to the central question (which hopefully is not cliche) what is the future
>of raves?

	I certainly don't think it's unique to us, it might have a larger
pre-existing subculture out here to tap into, but I hope it's a message
with universal appeal....

>						*joie et paix*

	Brian

From: Fred Heutte <phred@well.sf.ca.us>
Message-Id: <199305022331.AA29072@well.sf.ca.us>
To: rth@netcom.com, saeedi@shell.portal.com, sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Subject: Re:  Groove Kitchen a rip off ...
Status: OR

This was my only night off during my current SF trip, so I decided to
be adventurous.  Caught the bus to Berkeley and went to Flower Garden
at the Berkeley Aquatic Park.  At the 'Thunder Bay' pavilion at the
north end of the park, which is that water you see on the right when
driving north on 880 toward the University Ave exit.  

What a cool place!  It has a medium-sized sort of old-style funhouse
main room in a sort of oblongish octagonal shape, and a big side room,
i.e. perfect for chillspace which is what they were using it for.
The DJing when I got  there was good (could have been Harry Who? but
I couldn't see for sure because he was mixing upstairs in the projection
room), interesting light show and various flashers.  The sound system
was undersized and overdriven, which meant that the bass had a really
muddy sound, and it needed to be better balanced, but what the hey.

The main thing was there was almost *nobody* there, maybe two dozen
people tops in a space that could easily fit 300.  In fact, when I
got  to the front  nobody was even taking money so they just waved me in.

I left after about an hour and made my way back to SF.  Showed up at
King St around 4:30 but by 5 it was clear nobody else was going in, 
and then it  got shut down.  Way disappointing -- I'm not completely
tired of King St yet and I miss the energy that generally develops
there.

So I walked up to Big Heart City and did the Groove thang between
about 5:30 and 6:45.  Not very crowded inside, but not bad, the
spinning  was decent and the visuals pretty good.  But it is obviously
a slice of clubland, and when the floor started getting populated with
beer drinkers after the bar reopened I figured it was time to split.

My schedule just isn't  working out these days -- have to go back to
Portland Tuezday night so y'all will just have to howl at the moon
without me . . .

From: Monica Tauriello <monicat@gandalf.rutgers.edu>

Status: OR

Arthur Chandler wrote that in the cyberforum one of the themes that "seeped
out" was : "we have to transcend patriarchalism and embrace the feminine side
of aour natures."  he asked for opinions, so....

i am VERY uncomfortable with this statement, as it reeks of essentialism. 
IMHO there is NO such thing as a "feminine side" and a "masculine side" to
our "natures" - femininity and masculinity are culturally and socially
constructed categories, not natural at all.  i assume what the speaker meant
was that we need to get beyond a dominator/hierarchical mentality, and
embrace a mor(oops) ESSENTALLY FEMININE about cooperawhat one can say,
however, is that in our culture cooperation is THOUGHT OF as feminine/
competition - masculine --- but there is nothing natural about this.  

i am uncomfortable, also, with something stated on another post (brian's, i
think) about the cyberforum, which said that the issue of 1 woman, 7(?) men
on the panel wasn't a problem, because we need ot get beyond patriarchal and
matriarchal thinking - they're all people.  sure, we're all people - however,
we do live in a sexist culture, which organizes things along gendered lines,
whether we like it or not.  the lack of women on the panel could mean that
women are not as active in the rave scene, or it could mean that women are
active but in different (non-visible-leadership) roles, and thus are being
overlooked.  and if women aren't as active in the rave scene, why not? any
thoughts?  

monicat

Uh, I hate to say this, but I RARELY remeber any policy of parties that say
"If you don't like the party there is a 100% refund".  Unfortunately parties
are NOT department stores and you should not expect them to act as such.
I would suggest buyer beware.

Groove Kitchen is NOT a ripoff.  It is one of the best parties put on by one
of the nicest promoters I have met.  It all depends on WHY you go to
parties.  If you determine that a good party is one that has a lot of
people, then you cut yourself out of alot of quality gugs in SF.  I would
suggest waiting for one of the massives if that is your taste. But calling
GK a ripoff is a bit extreme and unfair.

From: John S. Lee <jslee@well.sf.ca.us>

Status: OR

There has been one, as far as I see it, bad trend in the scene.  There is a
suburbanization as comapred to two years ago.  This scene was quite
different.  I am not making judgements here, but the crowds were a bit more
mixed, ethnically and sexual-orientation wise.  Now it is mostly a white
hetero thang.  If you went to ANY of the early toon towns then you know what
I'm talking about.

It makes me wonder whether people on this scene want to be segregated.  The
hets from the gays, white from black/asian/ etc.  To me this is NOT the way
to amke this scene thrive.  Things have got to be more inclusive, but it
escapes me as to how this is to be done.

I do know I select the parties I attend very carefully.  I usually know the
promoter and know the party that they throw, and will attend based upon past
performance as well as stated goals.

I mean the celbration of Beltane is truly wonderful, for those that
understand it and know what it means or want to try to gain understanding.
But how do you translate this event to African AMericans/Asian Americans,
etc. who are not of Celtic origin?  I guess it depends upon your
perspective, but it may ahve inadvertantly kept some people away who may
have seen such celebrations as exclusive to whites...I dunno...

I mean the ladies generally play to gay crowds, and that limits their
exposure.  Also the music a gay clubs tends to be more "soulful" (tons of
those screaming divaesque lyrics), and that is the last thing I want to hear
before the sun rises.

Smokin' Joe though is one woman who can spin with a vengeance!

> 
> I mean the celbration of Beltane is truly wonderful, for those that
> understand it and know what it means or want to try to gain understanding.
> But how do you translate this event to African AMericans/Asian Americans,
> etc. who are not of Celtic origin?  I guess it depends upon your
> perspective, but it may ahve inadvertantly kept some people away who may
> have seen such celebrations as exclusive to whites...I dunno...
> 

Don't always judge a book by it's cover, I know more about this holiday
then your average "God Fearin'" celt (Irish,scottish, britton) does:)
When you start to study ancient and pre-history you begin to realize that
20 - 30, 00 years ago, all of these holidays that we "civilized folks"
have forgotton about were observed in one varient or another by every culture
on the planet (give or take a week or two).  Holidays like beltane are
linked to the seasons and astronomical year, the Celts called it Beltane
the egyptians called it something else, native americans have their "own
rites of spring" and I'm sure the aboriginals have an inverse or anti-holiday
equivilent, (There in the southern hemispher, and it autumn there). I've
studied Celtic "mysteries" and am currently studying african "mysteries" and
you know what? they have a LOT of the same stuff in them right down to the
drumming and other aspects of Trance,  I thought I had
really stumbled on something "the missing link between africans and celts
(so that's what they ment by `black irish')" but then I picked up a book
on feng shui (chinese geomancy) and started to see some of the same connections
and then you know what I realized? There was a time when all of us,
asian, africans, europeans knew this stuff, knew how to trance and heal, and
knew about rhythm. But we forgot! Or at least a bunch of us did.  And we sarted
to force other's to forget and to see the ways in which we were different
and make that more important then the ways we are the same. And while it may
be true that the "indiginous" culture of europe was the first to succumbe to
this Dominator mentality, It wasn't fully put down in europe until
"the burning times" when at lease 10 million people (mostly women) were
killed for being "witches" over a period of about 300 years.  These days,
we don't have to convert people to the Dominator culture by the blade
(that's form is still reserved for the smaller countries of the world)
we can just get a few people in that local to "sell out", set them up
with a lot of material wealth and put them in charge of the "area" it's
done in macro-cosm  (countries like S. Africa) and in micro-cosm
(selling drugs in S. Central) they will keep their neighbors down so long
as they get paid.  It's easy to use racial devisions to convinvce the
masses that blacks/whites are a violent race of people that must be contained
but in real life the people at the top of the econonomic pyramid only
care about one thing and that is MONEY.

Now when we go to a Rave, our spirit REMENMBERS how It USE TO BE! before
all this bullshit about my race is more-better-different-then your race.
We remember that were different but all connected to the earth so LET'S
PARTY!  That's what raving is about for me, learning to reconnect with each
other along co-operative bonds as oppose to competative bonds.  That doesn't
mean you have to want to associate with every body all the time but it
does mean that you are committed to tearing down barriers, cuz deep down
in side, we all come from the same source!

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

From sfraves-request@medisg.Stanford.EDU  Sun May  2 23:09:13 1993
Received: from medisg.Stanford.EDU by soda.berkeley.edu (5.65/KAOS-1)
	id AA06525; Sun, 2 May 93 23:09:13 -0700

	id AA09227; Sun, 2 May 93 23:03:11 PDT
Received: from netcom3.netcom.com by medisg.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA09223; Sun, 2 May 93 23:03:09 PDT
Received: by netcom3.netcom.com (5.65/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id AA03764; Sun, 2 May 93 23:03:36 -0700
Date: Sun, 2 May 93 23:03:36 -0700
From: tgrant@netcom.com (Tony Grant)
Message-Id: <9305030603.AA03764@netcom3.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@medisg.Stanford.EDU

Hello, everybody.  I'm taking an intermission in my post weekend hibernation and
thought I'd try and share something that moved me.  I had a very exhausting
weekend, and as usual I was rejuvenated at 1015 on Sunday Morning at Boogie
Buffet.  For those of you who haven't been there since they opened the sun room,
I urge you you to check it out.  Unfortunately it's 21+  :(   :(   :(, but for
those who can, it's pretty amazing.  I've started to call it my church  =)
	The reason I felt so motivated to share is that around 1:00 in the afternoon,
Thomas took over for Gavan and spun *the most amzing set i've heard in months*,
maybe ever.  Totally slow, funky, soulful... all over the place from P-Funk to
Earth Wind & Fire to Eazy-E old school.  With every song he sucked more and more
people in, and I don't think I've ever felt that much energy... a room full of
people with the sunlight streaming in, everybody's bellies filled with blueberry
pancakes and fruit salad... absolutely slammin'... brilliant ... wicked ... cup
o' tea ...  =)

Usually I can't totally release on the dance floor unless I slip into the trance
mode and the DJ is able to erase the whole context of the club, but this morning
was different ... it was the most intense sense of sharing I've felt on the
floor with a group of people, and it wasn't 120-130 BPM which is very
invigorating, very refreshing ... sorry to keep rambling, but it triggered a few
things:

	"I'm not against playing fast.  It's just that now I understand
	fast as only an aspect."
		Wynton Marasalis

	"High energy does not necessarily mean fast.  High energy has
	to do with heart."
		Lou Reed

I think about this when I hear a DJ and it feels like the whole set is about
8-10 BPM too fast-- I understand that in the course of mixing, certain records
will need to have their tempo increased-- I'm talking about cats who knock
*everything* up a notch, and it just doesn't seem necessary.  It reminds up this
excercise club that I occasionly walk by and they'll be playing Top 40ish stuff
and they'll crank some 120 BPM song up to like 150, and it makes me shake my
head in sorrow.  You may gain some energy in sheer tempo, but you lose all the
original feeling, the soul of the song.

OK, OK, that's enough.

Thanks for listening.

Make my funk the P-Funk,

Tony

>From: Tamara Palmer                        <IZZYPK3@mvs.oac.ucla.edu>

>The other thing I forgot to mention is -- I asked
>a DJ here in LA (who shall remain nameless lest he
>look like a chauvinist pig on both ends of this
>coast!) why he thought there weren't more female
>djs and he said that females are not into the music
>as much and are not willing to make the necessary
>sacrifices that being a dj entails...how can we
>win with that sort of attitude?

"So, who's girlfriend are you?"
"Are you a hoochie girl?"
"Oh, yeah, I've heard of you... you go out with X, right?"
"So, which promoter are you helping?"
"You're not a lesbian, then?"

I swear to god, all these things have been said to me at gigs that
I HAVE BEEN PROMOTING!  The level of ignorance is astounding!  I could
write a ten-page message here on my views, but I think it's more effective
to say simply how you (men and women) perpetuate the entrenchment of the
problem by how you treat others and how you expect others to treat you.
Women MUST work with other women, not against each other, to overcome
this problem... and I know men who recognize and sympathise with this
view as well (and are doing something to help).

Andrea

Subject: Pay To Play Loud in SJ
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Date: Mon, 3 May 93 6:44:41 PDT
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]


 Well, as I was reading my email this morning , the morning San Jose TV
show had a short story on a new fine that the SJPD will be levelling on 
people who , by being noisy , cause their neighbors to call the cops to
shut down the noise. The fine will be around $50+ dollars per call.

 The rational was that the fine would discourage habitual offenders of
the peace ( Many of the noise complaints in SJ are generated by the 
same repeat offenders ) . SJPD says they had 9000 (!) noise complaints
in 1992. The fine covers the cost to the police to answer the complaint.

 The chilling thing was , the newscaster said something like " if it 
works in San Jose , expect other municipalities to follow suit. ".

				Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com


-- 

From sfraves-request@medisg.Stanford.EDU  Mon May  3 07:31:26 1993

	id AA27762; Mon, 3 May 93 07:20:41 -0700
Message-Id: <9305031420.AA27762@soda.berkeley.edu>
Date: Mon, 3 May 93 10:06 EDT
From: laura@usl.com
To: ne-raves@gnu.ai.mit.edu
Cc: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Subject: Women in the scene (was Re: the whole life expo...)
Received: from usl by usl.com; Mon,  3 May 1993 10:06 EDT
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 3219

Someone wrote:

>> >neesa (the earth girl), 
>> 
>> She generated some interesting discussion about feminism and the like - 
>> and as to why she was the only woman up there.  Hmm...  basically the
>> issue was sorta resolved when an audience member said we needed to
>> transcend the concepts of patriarchy and matriarchy and look at the
>> panel not at 8 men and 1 women but as 9 people.

Someone else replied:
>This issue was not solved! Yes we need to look at it as 9 people but
>we also need to look at the fact that rave scene, at the level of organization,
>and performance (the DJ's) are dominated by Men.  Might I also add that 
>the person who said that we should look at it as 9 people was
>a man and I did not feel that all of the women who spoke up felt
>that the issue was solved, we just moved on thats all.
>Let`s not sweep this one unde the rug guys, (and gals) we'll be making a
>mistake if we do.

Back in January I was sitting around with my friend Ed and we were talking
about the scene.  We got on the subject of "how many women are really involved"
and started couting.  We only knew of one female organizer -- Patty in Chicago.
We knew of six DJ's (Miss DJAX [Holland], Heart [aka Heather Heather of 
Brooklyn], Psycho Bitch [Chicago], Moneypenny [New York/Belgium], Sondra 
Collins [LA??]  and Jacqueline Christie [New York]).  This didn't sound so
great.  Ed looked at me and said "well, you know we can do something about
this."  "What" I asked.  "You've got records, I've got the equipment sitting
in my basement, come over any time you want and start learning."  So I did.

Since then, I see exactly WHY there are so few women DJs.

It ain't easy, kids.

I *PURPOSELY* picked a DJ name that did not indicate my sex just so people
wouldn't look at a flyer and go "Oh.  A girl DJ.  I wonder if she sucks,"
which is EXACTLY what people did to Heather Heather when she was starting out.
(Heather was not so great to begin with, but no one is.  In the months since
her debut at Quest 2, she's gotten a lot of practice in and she's a FINE 
hard trance DJ now.)  

When I go to buy records or show up at gigs, guys look at me and go "oh, so
you're the girl hardcore DJ.  I never expected a girl to spin hardcore."  Or,
when I ask to hear a record, a guy might say "you really want to hear that?
That's hardcore you know."  (Fortunately I have found a great place to shop
and a decent person to deal with in the store who accepted me from the start.)

Even my *friends* say to me "you don't look like what we'd usually expect
to see behind the tables."  Just because I'm a female?  Or because I'm not
17?  Or because I don't wear anything resembling rave gear?  Or what? 

When I spin guys crowd around the table.  I don't know whether they are there
just WAITING for me to fuck up or if they're trying to look down my dress, or
both.

I'm somehow preceived as a THREAT by some of the more egotistical/insecure
(funny how those two traits go hand-in-hand) male DJs out there.  They
crowd me while I'm spinning, or yell at me, trying to break my concentration.

So, this is a first-hand account of what it is like to be a female DJ in the
man's world of techno -- especially hardcore techno.

Laura

Subject: Beltane, Malls & Wicked

Well most of the mall dwellers must have gone to Wicked cos they certainly
weren't at Beltane. Beltane turned out to be a rockin good time with
absolutely great visuals, nice staging incl: trees fountains and lots of
space to stretch out in. Great chill room although not far enough from the
main room to have  a distinctly different sound. And *NO SMOKING* YES!! What
a concept wonderful! Plus the aroma therapy was really nice. Music was
great; simon just shredded everything. Micjael from Island/univers started
off ans was great too. Mark Farina came on after Simon and was real good but
not great. Follwing him was Evil Eddie's replacement Julian who was also
great. Great people, Vibe in full effect!

All in all a nice job by Marc, Richard son and Co!

peace
nrg

 I received this on the Leri list and thought a little amusement might be
appreciated here given the current conversations.


---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Sat, 01 May 1993 20:57:34
From: David L Racette <dlr@medical.win.net>
To: Leri <Leri@pyramid.com>
Subject: Interesting mail


 Opening Statement to the House Subcommittee on
 Telecommunications and Finance, Washington DC, April 29,
 1993

        Hello everyone and thanks for inviting me here.  My
 name is Bruce Sterling and I'm a science fiction writer and
 sometime science journalist.   Since writing my nonfiction book
 HACKER CRACKDOWN: LAW AND DISORDER ON THE ELECTRONIC
 FRONTIER, I have returned to writing science fiction.  And I've
 returned to that with some relief, frankly, since the world of
 science fiction is in most ways rather less strange and less
 bizarre than the contemporary world of telecommunications
 policy.

        I hope therefore that you will forgive me if I testify
 today as a science fiction writer.  It's one of the perks of my
 profesion to write about the future, or attempt to, and I
 thought you might like to meet someone from the
 telecommunications future that you are so busy creating.

        With your kind indulgence for my novelist's whimsy
 then, the rest of my brief presentation today will be given by a
 Mr. Bob Smith, with is an NREN network administrator from the
 year 2015.

        I present Mr. Smith.

        "Thank you, Mr. Sterling.  It's a remarkable privilege to
 talk to the legislators who historically created my working
 environment.  As a laborer in the fields of 21st Century
 cyberspace I of course would have no job without NREN and
 my wife and small son and I are all properly grateful for your
 foresight in establishing the Information Superhighway.

        "Your actions in this regard have affected American
 society every bit as strongly as did the telegraph, the railroads,
 the telephone, the highway system, and television.  In fact, it's
 impossible for me to imagine contemporary life in 2015
 without the Global Net; living without the Net would be like
 trying to live without electricity.

        "However, it's a truism in technological development that
 no silver lining comes without its cloud.  Today I'd like to
 mention two or three trifling problems that have come up that
 were not entirely obvious from the perspective of the early
 1990s.

        "First of all, this 'Research and Education' aspect.  Since
 communications *is* power in an Information Society, giving
 fantastically advanced communications to the Research and
 Education communities did in fact empower those communities
 quite drastically by comparison with interest-groups lacking
 that advantage.  Today, one of the most feared political
 organizations in the world is the multi-national anarchist
 libertarian group called the Students for an Utterly Free
 Society.

        "Of course, there have always been campus radicals, but
 thanks to their relative lack of financial clout, and lack of even
 a steady home address, these young fanatics once found it very
 difficult to organize politically.  Therefore, they were easy for
 the powers-that-be to ignore, except during occasional spasms
 of violent campus unrest.

        "Thanks to NREN, however, spasms of student unrest can
 now spread like lightning across entire continents.  Advanced
 AI translation programs installed on the Net only made matters
 worse, since in 2015 the global leaders of the student
 movements are not only extremely radical, but French.

        "Attempts by campus authorities to control this unrest
 have failed miserably.  In 2015, NREN sites are always the first
 buildings occupied during a campus strike.  Campus chancellors
 and faculty are themselves so utterly dependent on NREN that
 they become quite helpless off-line.

        "A second major problem has been the growth of
 unlicenced encryption, which has proved quite unstoppable.
 Today some seventy-five percent of NREN archives are
 material that no one in authority can read.  Countries that
 attempted to control and monitor network traffic have lost
 market share and service revenue as data processing simply
 moves offshore.

        "The United States has profited by this phenomenon to a
 great extent as people worldwide have flocked to the relative
 liberty of our networks.  Unfortunately many of these
 electronic virtual immigrants are not simply dissidents looking
 for free expression but in fact are organized criminals.

        "Take for instance a recent FBI raid on an enormous
 archive of encrypted Iranian files, illicitly stored in an obscure
 NREN node in North Dakota.  Luckily the FBI was able to
 decrypt these files thanks to an inside informant.  Deciphering
 these archives revealed the following contraband:

        "Eighty percent graphic image files of attractive young
 women without veils on, or, in fact, much clothing of any kind.

        "Fifteen percent digitally stored pirated copies of Western
 pop music and Western videos, still illegal to possess in
 Teheran.

        "And, five percent text files in the Farsi language
 describing how to guild, deliver and park truck-bombs in major
 urban areas.

        "I can't conclude my brief remarks today without a
 mention of a particularly odd development having to do with
 *wireless* computer telecommunications.  Since it is now
 possible to transact business entirely in cyberspace, including
 financial transactions, many information entrepreneurs in 2015
 have simply given up any physical home.  Basically, they have
 become stateless people, 21st Century gypsies.

        "A recent tragic example of this occurred in the small
 town of North Zulch, Texas.  There some rural law enforcement
 officers apprehended a scruffy vagabond on a motorcycle in a
 high-speed chase.  Unfortunately he was killed.  A search of his
 backpack revealed a device the size of a cigarette pack.  In
 searching the dead man's effects, the police officers, who were
 not computer literate, accidentally broke the device.  This tiny
 device was actually a privately owned computer bulletin board
 system with some 15,000 registered users.

        "Many of the users were wealthy celebrities, and the
 apparent outlaw biker was actually an extremely popular and
 nationally known system operator.  These 15,000 users were
 enraged by what they considered the wanton destruction of
 their electronic community.  They pooled their resources and
 took a terrible vengeance on the small town of North Zulch,
 which, by contrast, had only 2,000 residents, none of them
 wealthy or technologically sophisticated.  Through a
 combination of harassing lawsuits and sharp real-estate deals,
 the vengeful board users bankrupted the town.  Eventually the
 entire township was bulldozed flat and purchased for parkland
 by the Nature Conservancy.

        "Thanks in part to the advances that you yourselves set
 in motion, violent conflicts between virtual and actual
 communities have become a permanent feature of the cultural
 landscape in 2015."

        Thank you for your patience in entertaining my
 speculations.  I'll be happy to take any questions -- though
 only in my real-life persona.  Thank you very much.





----- End Included Message -----

Subject: Re:  Cyberforum: rants and raves



jslee writes :
 
> I agree with everything you stated.  But that still does not answer the
> question of why the scene has become more homogenous.  I understand the
> common bond issue and the commonality between all of us.  But the scene,
> whatever it's good intentions, does not reflect this ideal.  If what you
> said was truly happening, more and more people would be brought in by the
> sheer positive nature of the experince.  This has not happened.
> 
> Gays,Hets, and all others used to party together.  There was a
> multi-cultural feel to these events.  I can say, that after watching this
> scene over the past couple of years that the intergrative aspect has been
> lost.  Maybe because the message has been diluted perhaps?  I don't know.
> 
> Unless the scene is able to draw many different people in, in the spirit of
> commonality (striving to overcome the bullshit of artificial barriers like
> race and sexual orientation), then can it truly be called and instument of
> change, or much less a thriving and growing community?  Or does it become a
> thing exlcusively for use by one group of people or another?

Yes, I'm concerned about the trend toward LESS diversity that I'm
seeing in the Scene.  Many folks are afraid to flyer in minority
communities like Oakland and East Palo Alto because of the Gangs, but
NOT EVERYONE WHO LIVES IN THESE COMMUNITIES BELONG TO OR PARTICIPATE IN
GANG ACTIVITY.  If we fall into our fear on this then we will become
hypocrits.  You know and I know that the best parties and events get
there draw due to personal communication, one person telling other cool
people.  Look at parties like Wicked who didn't do a tremendous amount
of flyering, they can't keep the people away (even when it is in a
cheesey place like King street, which Wicked has definitely outgrown).
The problem that the 60's movement fell into was that eventually it was
"taken over" from a grassroots movement which included all races and
became (at least in the media's eye, a white thang) let's not fall into
the same trap.  As I've said before, I've seen "tuff" Black Homeboy
types totally trance out after a few hours at a rave.  For them they
have to let go of a lot of stuff before they can "take in" the scene.
I know cuz' I grew up in one of these areas.  They are use to white
people being a certain way and a rave doesn't fit their picture of
reality (they are literally having a reality crisis). First they have
to get over the stereotype that white folks don't know how to "let
loose" this is one of the most amazing things to some Brothers that
I've talked to at raves, that they see white people exhibit a lot of
rhythm and seem to be comfortable "shaking that booty".  The next thing
that they have to get use to is what we (AA people) sometimes refer to
as getting "vibed" this IS NOT the way that ravers use the term!  To a
black person comming to a rave, they are surprised that they are not
getting "vibed" by the white folks there, getting "vibed" is what
happens to many people of color and to most black men when they step
into a situation that is predominately caucasian, it is a subtle
feeling that you pick up comming from the people around you , mostly
fear, sometimes mixed with guilt, after years of this, you get sick of
it, some kids react by living up to the gangsta image and giving white
folks something to really be afraid of, some say fuck it and refuse to
socially associate with whites at all, some ignore  it and become
neurotic, some work for change on all fronts.  So anyway, at the best
raves, these brothers and sisters come and they have a reality check
because, for the first time in their lives, for some, they are being
treated as simply a human being by a white person and not a "race
object".  Next thing they have to get use to  are white DJs throwing
down some serious Phat beats, I saw homeboys at the New Years Gathering
running up to the turntables and finding Jeno ripping shit up, they
stared in disbelief/amazement/fear/joy.  One of them demanded of me
"Hey man!  who IS this guy!" I watched one guy grab his head like his
mind was on fire :) (yup they got it!) In African American culture,
dancing has always been an outlet, when things got real bad (as they
often did) you could always get some 45s a little record player and
dance.  Now some of the "upwardly mobile" blacks who feel like they
have to emulate "white" culture have a lot of hang-ups about dancing,
their reality check goes like this, "Wait, I thought white folks
thought dancing was an activity common blacks did, but these white
folks are out there shakin it, I spent my whole adult life surpressing
this part of my culture to "fit in" now I see the people I'm trying to
fit in with embracing it?  This does not compute!"

And it doesn't compute!  That's right! All of this bullshit, the fear,
the stereotypes, the assumtions, evaluations, etc, can be, needs to be
and at the best events ARE dropped by everyone involved, that's the tru
beauty of what's happening here.  So I encourage all of you out there
especially those who go to college and come in contact with people of
color on a daily basis to take flyers with you and invite them to the
parties that you would go to.  If you do it with sincerity, love and
awareness they will detect this about you and respond.

monicat-

i must argue the point of men and women NOT having separate natures,
ie, 
"feminine" or "masculine".  these traits are affected by chemical
(im)balances in your body.  which is why you act different on drugs.
however, acting feminine or masculine can be a learned behavior, but
i don't think one would conciously "learn" either type of behavior
unless that one had the tendency to, as a result of having more of
that type of hormone.

this is not to be confused with domination/subservency.  i don't think
that anyone should have more power, or more luxuries, or more of anything
because of their sex, but men and women ARE NOT EQUAL.  THEY ARE DIFFERENT,m
and each has unique qualities and specialties.  i wish we could move a
way from androgeny a bit (the direction things seem to be going in...)
just long enough to appreciate the beautiful OPPOSITE qualities that 
both our sexes have.

(not a flame)

-mArK.

i think i'm in a rant mood today.  i hope i don't come accross
as just wanting to pick fights.  really.

but on the subject of Beltane making non-celtics feel excluded, i post
(that's POSE) this question:

"if a black-american had on a shirt with a picture of africa and the words
'black pride' (or similar) how would you look at that?"

probably without much judgement.  it seems fine to me.

but now turn that around and make it a white-american with a shirt on
that said "white pride".  all of a sudden that person becomes a racist.

the point i'm making may be moot...someone tell me.  sometimes i just
feel like a ton of crap gets thrown in the direction of young white
hetero males that haven't done anything to propagate this.  not all
black/white segregation is the idea of the white side, nor all het/homo
segregation the idea of the het side.

am i confused?  this is a real and serious inquiry, requesting a reply.

***also, if i'm pushing the boundaries of sfraves topics, just let
me know...it's monday, and i haven't had any coffee yet.

sincerely,

-mARK.

Mark asks:
>exactly what does this remark about not being 17 mean?? that you're not
>17 yet, or that you're no longer a spring chicken?

I'm 28, much older than the average raver.

>> When I spin guys crowd around the table.  I don't know whether they are there
>> just WAITING for me to fuck up or if they're trying to look down my dress, or
>> both.
>> 
>
>this just isn't a fair statement.  until i read that, i was thinking of
>how cool it would be to stand around and watch you spin, too.  now i have
>a different opinion.

See, I have no idea why these guys are standing there, and I have to wonder.
They don't stand around when male DJs spin, except for the very very good
ones like Lenny Dee, and I'm no where near that league.  So what am I to think?
Is it so freaky that a woman is spinning that they have to stand and watch?
Or what?  It's a bit DAUNTING to say the least.

>> I'm somehow preceived as a THREAT by some of the more egotistical/insecure
>> (funny how those two traits go hand-in-hand) male DJs out there.  They
>> crowd me while I'm spinning, or yell at me, trying to break my concentration.
>> 
>
>read this last part over.  then read the previous part.  a threat ALMOST 
>(<- note) sounds right.

Ahhh.  I never made the connection.

>i'm sure it's not easy, but are there ACTUALLY people saying, don't hire
>her, she's a girl, or are there just not a lot of girls that WANT to be
>a dj, like you said the guy in the record store said in your last post?

I think there are just not a lot of women who are willing to put themselves
out there to become DJs because of the stuff I described.  The *PROMOTERS*
and *ORGANIZERS* as a whole have been 100% supportive of me.  But when you
see the DJ old-boy network, getting involved is a bit nerve-wracking.  You
know how it is -- they all hang together in a corner behind the booth peering
out at the rave and talking amongst themselves, naming all the instruments
and producers involved in a track, and rating the current DJs mixing skills.
Most guys are socialized to be a bit more thick-skinned, and have little
problem dealing with this.

Laura

we also need to look at the fact that rave scene, at the level of organization,
and performance (the DJ's) are dominated by Men.  Might I also add that 
                ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
the person who said that we should look at it as 9 people was
a man and I did not feel that all of the women who spoke up felt
that the issue was solved, we just moved on thats all.
Let`s not sweep this one unde the rug guys, (and gals) we'll be making a
mistake if we do.

   So if there were more women dj's out there and less men dj's......
   You see it just doesn't make sense. Are you tring to say that all
   the men let them be organizers or dj's etc. that they don't allow
   women....hemmm? If that is the case then there is a problem.
   But I just don't see it that way. Are people supposed to go out and

> >Subject: re: cyberforum - rants & raves
> 
> >this is not to be confused with domination/subservency.  i don't think
> >that anyone should have more power, or more luxuries, or more of anything
> >because of their sex, but men and women ARE NOT EQUAL.  THEY ARE DIFFERENT,m
> >and each has unique qualities and specialties.  i wish we could move a
> >way from androgeny a bit (the direction things seem to be going in...)
> >just long enough to appreciate the beautiful OPPOSITE qualities that 
> >both our sexes have.
> 
> Hear, hear!  Differences DO NOt mean inequalities.  It is a shame that
> a difference in nature is so often interpreted as an inferiority/superiority.
> So, then... How can a feminine (sometimes seen as an inferior) quality
> be more incorporated into rave scenes without the "masculine" feeling
> threatened or "watered down?"  Why is this a threat?

come on andrea, you know me better than that.  re-read what i said.

i wish that the opposite and unique qualities of each sex could be
appreciated more for what they are, instead of creeping closer and
closer to completely non-descript personalities where it's even a
crime to use "he" or "she" words.

the key, i think, is balance, and a form of "common" sense that 
includes a double (maybe triple) heaping of treating others the way
you wish to be treated. 

the rave scene SOMETIMES works to acheive that. not always. :(

all the race/sex-pref/gender stuff is trivial.  these are merely
manifestations of the same problem.  if we all just treated other
PEOPLE like we want to be treated, we would have no problems.  instead
we waste time on stuff like this.  actually, i don't consider it
a waste of time at all, i just don't believe it's where the true
problem lies.

$.02

-mArK.

im going to bite on my lip REAL hard and be nice

im sorry, maybe im a different type of guy
maybe i hang around differnet guys
but i know that a lot of men including myself
think that a female dj is there to look good
more than to play good music

initial reaction female dj=babe behind the turntables

i know other guys react this way its not just me
so dont try to say it is

with this attitude comes two things
first - you think shes going to be bad so you
notice the mistakes she makes more
second - you objectify her and treat as something to be drooled on
not dealt with as a human being AND as a woman

i dont see that many girls crowding around the dj
to drool on him and when i do, its usually his friends
not strange people he doesnt know who are muhc larger than him

look the prevalent attitude in society is that woman cant
even figure out how to hook up a sound system much less
play the records, adn the funny thing is, women believe it too
so it becomes true

why arent there that many women dj's?
well shit, ive seen one
one

but i dont see any women to model myself after in the dj field

	id AA17800; Mon, 3 May 93 12:32:20 -0700
Date: Mon, 3 May 93 12:32:20 -0700
Message-Id: <9305031932.AA17800@netcom.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@medisg.Stanford.EDU
From: mcg@netcom.com (MykL G)
X-Sender: mcg@netcom.com (Unverified)
Subject: Re: Cyberforum -- Women DJs/promoters

Gregg Helt:
> Also, during the discussion 'bout this at the Cyberforum, someone from the
> audience stood up to say that she and some other promoters were going to
> do an event with all women DJs.  Does anyone else remember more about this,
> who/what/where/when?

I know a few of the people doing this... they haven't picked a date yet,
they're still in the conceptual/metaorganizational stage.  I'll post more
info about it when things gel a bit.

On a broader level, tho, I think the problem with the gender imbalance at
the CyberForum had as much to do with the format of the presentation (i.e.
the presumption that the people on stage were somehow MORE IMPORTANT than
people in the audience or others in the rave scene) as with any inherent
sexism in the scene.  I'm not saying that women aren't underrepresented as
DJ's or promoters, but I think there is a problem with assigning too much
significance and power to DJ's and promoters.  As Ernie Munson says constantly,
"there are no stars in this scene, every man and woman is a star."  I think
that view is shared by nearly every DJ and promoter I've met.

I understand the frustration women have in a society in which the power
relations are dictated by institutions that are predominantly male.  One
nit I've always picked with "classical" feminism is the idea that simply
by placing women in positions of power (CEO's, Boards of Directors,
Governments, etc.) society will magically improve and become more humane.
The problem is that as long as the nature of these institutions rely on
hierarchical power dominator relationships, the women who achieve high
positions are likely to exhibit the same cut-throat, corrupt tendencies as
the men who precede and surround them.  Witness Thatcher or Feinstein.

I met someone on Saturday who went to the CyberForum and helps promote
events such as TAZ, and we got to talking about this women-run event.
She was sceptical of the whole idea, and didn't think that exclusion or
separatism was something that would benefit the scene.  She told me that
the reason there weren't that many women promoters is that you have to
be really aggressive and cut-throat to be successful at it, and those aren't
traits many women want to have.  (Her words, not mine).

I wouldn't go as far as that, and I support the idea of this party (after
all, we guys are at least invited!), but I would rather see women (and the
rest of us) work for a world where domination and power-tripping are
obsolete, rather than simply wanting to take the reins of such a system.
The house scene could potentially be a model for this kind of world, but
only if everyone's voice and contribution is heard and respected equally,
whether male, female, promoter, DJ, or just a member of the community.

----____----____--__--__--__--__-_-_-_-_-_-__--__--__--__--____----____----
        MykL G                Use your wings.        mcg@netcom.com
____----____----__--__--__--__--_-_-_-_-_-_--__--__--__--__----____----____

	id AA24480; Mon, 3 May 93 13:24:23 -0700
Received: by netcom4.netcom.com (5.65/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id AA13191; Mon, 3 May 93 13:27:53 -0700
Date: Mon, 3 May 93 13:27:53 -0700
From: crunch@netcom.com (John Draper)
Message-Id: <9305032027.AA13191@netcom4.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Subject: Keeping big brother out of our faces....

Greetings fellow ravers.... From Cap'n Crunch

  John Draper here,  with a mission to inform you folks about a scarey
trend by certain government and corporate forces to strip you of your
rights to privacy in electronic and voice mail.    If you don't have 
a personal computer or use Email,  then please ignore this.   But if
you're on this sfraves mailing list,  you probably have a computer,  or
access to one,  or at least are probably going to get one.

  Briefly,  last Apr 15th,  an announcement was made about our governments
support for an encryption chip officially called the Clipper chip,  which
is to be used to encrypt phone calls,  cellular phone calls and Email.
So what!!  you might ask...   If you have nothing to hide,   never do anything
illegal,  and are a law abiding citizen,   you have nothing to worry about.
If you desire complete privacy,  or expect privacy by purchasing phones
in the future with the expectation that you can keep your conversations
private,
then you should take heed.

  It is planned by large corporate manufacturers of these future phones,
AT&T to be precise,  to register their internal serial numbers or "keys"
with a government controlled escrow agency so that "Big brother" can extract
your secret decryption key with an authorized court ordered wiretap.   Now,
I say this is BOGUS,  WRONG,  and pure BULLSHIT,  and defeats the purpose
of encryption in the first place.    I'm not going to get into all the details
or politics of this insanity,  other then to inform you all of whats going on,
and how you can get more information,  and better yet,  how you can help our
cause to "THROW A WRENCH INTO THE GOVERNMENTS PLANS".

  Eventually,  the trends we are observing now,  indicate that the government
will eventually OUTLAW private encryption.   This is like the post office
forcing everyone to use postcards and eliminate mailing envelopes.  Now this
is not only BOGUS but scarey as well.

  So,  I say,  what can we do about this...   Well,  I have several ideas,
and a lot of them was discussed in the Cypherpunks forum.    One such Idea
I proposed was to make up information handouts to be passed out at raves,
informing those folks about what they can do to spread the word around,  and
to fight this dangerious trend.

  Another such idea,  although not completly accepted,  and hotly debated,
is to set up some tables with laptops or small portable computers,  and make
them available to those folks who want to obtain copies of PGP (An encryption
program),  sign each other's keys (To prevent spoofing),  and to network and
exchange information about this controversial subject.   

  In my opinion,  one way we can protect our rights to privacy is through
technology,  by using military strength encryption and even deception by
folling the snooper into thinking an encryped message is a program.

  So,  I make a plea to those rave organizers to contact us Cypherpunks,
and work with us to help inform fellow ravers owning,  or having access to
computers and Email,  on how we can fight "Big brother" and keep its
"ear" out of our faces.

  Encryption can be a powerful tool in setting up and planning future raves
in total privacy,   communicating and organizing other sub-events or for
any other communication requiring provacy.   So I urge you all to support
us Cypherpunks in helping get the word out and fight this Big Brother trend
the government and large corporations are pushing in our faces.

  For more information,  you can Email me here at address below,  as I plan
on staying on the sfraves mailing list for about another week.    Please
understand that my Email traffic is HUGE (About 400 - 500 messages a day),
and that this mailing list is also adding to the problem.   If you have any
questions,  feel free to send them,  but don't delay,  because I cannot
stay on this list forever.

  I've been raving since the "Toon Town" raves started up several years ago,
and really enjoy the togetherness of the crowds,  but with some severe allergy
problems,  I avoid the smokey raves or places that have little or no
ventilation.

  And now I want to complement the organizers of the Beltane rave last Saturday
night on how it was set up.    There was a lot of places where I can enjoy and
dance to the music without discomfort from heavy cigerette smoke.   The dance
floor was less crowded than most,  so had plenty of room to "romp and rave"
around,  and I really enjoyed the "schmooze room" or stretch room with the
matresses for stretching and doing yoga.   Having that available allowed me
to recover from the stresses of dancing and rest my lower back,  so I was able
to rave with the best of them without having to use drugs as a crutch to keep
dancing and raving all night.    All in all,  it was the most enjoyable rave
I've been to in a long time,  and I plea to those rave organizers to try and
set up similar non-smoking areas where we can grab a breath of fresh air once
in a while wihout having to try and talk the goons into letting us back in
after getting fresh air.    Also I want to thank the organizers for permitting
me to give a helping hand in the setting up,  because I couldn't afford the
$20 door fees.    WOW!!  the prices for getting into these raves has really
gone through the roof.    Anyway,   I helped tape up the dance floor panals
and was instrumental in getting it ready for opening on time.

  If any rave promoter wants me to attend and talk to the group of make myself
available to other ravers,  just make sure I can get on the guest list.  
HINT HINT!!  as I'm still unemployed,  and the entrance fees are what is 
keeping me away from most raves.    Just Email me if you want me to attend,
and provide a small,  well ventilated area where I can get a breath of fresh
air,  stretch and do yoga,  and I can attend and rave with the best of them.

  So I say to you folks **RAVE ON** but watch BIG BROTHER and do your part
in keeping him out of your face..    So support your local Cypherpunks
and if you're interested in helping out,  you can join the cypherpunks
mailing list,  by sending Email to "cypherpunks-request@toad.com".   Like
sfraves mailing list,  it has heavy traffic (About 30-70 messages/day),
but is an excellent forum and information resource for those interested
in cryptography,  although some messages are highly technical,  and political,
you might find it enlightening.

  The cypherpunks also meet on a monthly basis in Mt view,  so for more info,
please Email me or join the list.

RAVE ON DUDES...

Cap'n Crunch
John D.

crunch@netcom.com
crunch@well.sf.ca.us

mark@ganymede.apple.com (Mark Baldwin)  says and I quote:

> 
> i think i'm in a rant mood today.  i hope i don't come accross
> as just wanting to pick fights.  really.
> 
> but on the subject of Beltane making non-celtics feel excluded, i post
> (that's POSE) this question:
> 
> "if a black-american had on a shirt with a picture of africa and the words
> 'black pride' (or similar) how would you look at that?"
> 
> probably without much judgement.  it seems fine to me.
> 
> but now turn that around and make it a white-american with a shirt on
> that said "white pride".  all of a sudden that person becomes a racist.

Well I can tell you how I feel from the heart, The first feeling I get
is shock, surprise, followed by fear, I think, did I get off at the wrong 
exit or something :) Then I think well who the fuck is this person and if
it looks like I'm not in any immediate danger (or at least the odds are
somewhat in my favor ) I might  scan him to see what kind of person he is...

What I'm saying is that I'm having a conditioned reaction.  In this society
words have coded meanings.  I fully realize that Black Power and White Power
are syntatically equivilent but society has non-equivilent meanings.  We call
this whooping body of knowledge "political correctness" and it SUCKS!.

It sucks because a white person should be able to express their pleasure
at just being white without being labeled a racist.  You can be proud to be
white and still not feel that that makes you better than some other group on
the planet.  I think everybody (uh oh I feel a rant coming on...)
	

	1. That from a global perspective, white people are a minority.

	2.From a global perspective, every ethnic group is a minority.

	3.From a global perspective we are all in the majority as far as
	  humans are concerned, half in male bodies half in female bodies.

	4. Currently a european based technological civilization is in
	  control of most of the resources on the planet at this time.

	5. No individual group of people in the world are at the cause
	  of the problems that face the planet.  We all share in the
	  cause, we all moust share in the cure.

	6. The Dominator culture wants things to go on as usual,  they
	  believe in the doctrine of crisis management, balence of power
	  (their power), and large scale infomation memes like money,
	  nations,nationalities, etc.

	7. This culture is about control, they will resort to violence
	  in order to secure their control over the future of resources.

	8. Currently this culture is centered around the USA-Europe axis
	and includes the former soviet union as well as japan, austraila
	egypt, israel, saudi arabia the current south african government
	and the ruling elite of china.

	9. It is not about left or right wing politics, it's about economics

	10.  This culture cannot be overturned, no physical revolution
	could over turn it or prevent it from posioning the planet.

	11.  we need a REVOLUTION of CONSCIOUSNESS which needs to happen
	from the inside-out. every person, culture on the planet has a part
	of the puzzle.

	12.  Europeans like everyone else have an integral and important
	part in the whole.

	13.  It is NOT white people who are dominating the planet,
	its a Dominator Culture made up of every race on the planet
	although the controlers of this culture at the top of the 
	pyramid happen to be white.

	14.  We need to start to see our similarities with each other
	and use our diferences as tools to interoperate for the common
	good.

if you like it, i would actually recommend anything else on that 
particular label also..  

(btw, excuse my mixing on the tape - the only rave so far i have been 
taped at and i get to mix with saturated slipmats..:)

On Mon, 3 May 1993, Geoff White wrote:

> > but now turn that around and make it a white-american with a shirt on
> > that said "white pride".  all of a sudden that person becomes a racist.
> 
> What I'm saying is that I'm having a conditioned reaction.  In this society
> words have coded meanings.  I fully realize that Black Power and White Power
> are syntatically equivilent but society has non-equivilent meanings.  We call
> this whooping body of knowledge "political correctness" and it SUCKS!.
> 	1. That from a global perspective, white people are a minority.

 uh-oh. Looks as if someone is afraid of losing his white male priviledge.
 From a global perspective, white people ARE NOT a minority. Minority
 status is not derived by numbers but by political status and other
 similar factors. Based on this, there is no-one better off in this world
 than the white heterosexual male. Society should have different meanings
 - it is neccessary for such things to me said. People who talk about     
 starting a white students union or "straight campus" to oppose our       
 universities Queer Campus make me laugh. It is not always the people
 themselves that they fear, but loosing the priviledges that they were born
 with.
 
--Fluid

From: winston@lurnix.com (Mark Guthrie)
Message-Id: <9305032315.AA00686@cassy.lurnix.com>
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu

Someone said:
>Does anyone have any comments or suggestions as to how we can begin
>to change this ?  

WE can't do anything unless you want to campaign to get more
girls interested in djing and promoting but if a person (girl
in this case) isn't interested enough to self-initiate a hobby
or profession, than how good are they gonna be at it and why
should they be given special attention?  I have absolutely no
interest in modern dance, a predominantly feminine art form
(doesn't have to be but it is) and if a group of woman tried to
recruit me because they needed more men on that scene, I would
still have absolutely no interist in it.  Or what if a bunch of
black people wanted me to join their step-dancing crew because
they needed more white people?  My point is, no matter what the
reason, if girls in general don't have the interest to persue these
matters than that's the way it is, I don't buy it that there's some
organized secret group of chauvinist, rave promoters keepin girls 
out.

Someone else said:
>The other thing I forgot to mention is -- I asked
>a DJ here in LA (who shall remain nameless lest he
>look like a chauvinist pig on both ends of this
>coast!) why he thought there weren't more female
>djs and he said that females are not into the music
>as much and are not willing to make the necessary
>sacrifices that being a dj entails...how can we
>win with that sort of attitude?

I think this person is right and shouldn't be called a chauvinist
for stating a (probably true) belief that absolutely does not imply
inferiority of woman to men, just a difference.  The biggest problem
with sexism and racism, besides their existence, is people who don't
know when they are and aren't occuring.  Like I stated before,
nobody's keeping girls out, they just don't tend to be interested
in these aspects of the scene.

So in essence, if your a girl on this list reading this, and you
have a strong interest in djing or rave promoting, get out there 
and do it.  But then, you didn't need me to reassure you because
if you were of the mind to do it you'd of done it anyway right?

-Mark

From: Monica Tauriello <monicat@gandalf.rutgers.edu>

Subject: re: women djs
Message-Id: <CMM-RU.1.3.736473666.monicat@gandalf.rutgers.edu>

mARK wrote that instead of asking ourselves why there aren't more girl(sic)
djs, we (women) should ask ourselves why we are not djs...

i would love to be a dj, and when i have the time and money i might start
learning...however, my point is that perhaps the rave community, particularly
in the promotions, dj arena, is male-dominated, not just in numbers but in
attitude.  laura wrote earlier of the difficulties she encounters with
many men in the hardcore community being uncomfortable with women.  another
woman, a promoter, wrote of the assumptions people make about her: that she
is just someone's girlfriend, etc.  historically rock music has been
male-dominated and sexist, and i don't see raves, etc. as being that much
diffeerent in that respect.  what we need to do is recognize the sexism women
face, and work against it.  it IS a political issue -it's not just about the
color of the wallpaper, whatever.  

monicat

From: ccat@netcom.com (Chris)
Message-Id: <9305040027.AA09102@netcom3.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@medisg.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Women as Promoters/DJ's

  I think a lot of people are neglecting the fact that quite a few women are al-
ready on the scene,and promoting / DJing. And enlightened ones..especially
those

involved in the scene a year or two ago,were *remarkably* open to people
of diverse flavors attempting to express themselves in this exciting new
medium... And  to a large extent, it's still happening..
 I think the biggest drag on this process has been the creeping 
commercialism of the scene..resulting in a dilution..basically of it's
creative people in a sea of sheep-like-ones. Even so, some of the most
successful promoters have been women..(Ive always felt that in some
area,women were inherently more stable than men !)
 Just look at Dianna (of ToonTown) and Heather (of Storm)
  Both entered a mans world and succeeded.. 
There must be more..
I know the Equinox promoter is a very cool woman..and Preston's partner when
he  started Groove Kitchen was a woman also..
 So-next time you see a woman dj'ing or promoting..I think the biggest
favor you can do her is to simply judge her event on it's own merits and 
leave it at that.Celebrate diversity..and nobody needs anybody's pity.
..does that ring true..?
 Chris.

> i would love to be a dj, and when i have the time and money i might start
> learning...however, my point is that perhaps the rave community, particularly
> in the promotions, dj arena, is male-dominated, not just in numbers but in
> attitude.  laura wrote earlier of the difficulties she encounters with
> many men in the hardcore community being uncomfortable with women.  another
> woman, a promoter, wrote of the assumptions people make about her: that she
> is just someone's girlfriend, etc.  historically rock music has been
> male-dominated and sexist, and i don't see raves, etc. as being that much
> diffeerent in that respect.  what we need to do is recognize the sexism women
> face, and work against it.  it IS a political issue -it's not just about the
> color of the wallpaper, whatever.  

It is undeniable that there ARE greater obstacles for woman DJ's in this
arena. You will find it different elsewhere. In NYC there are plenty of 
woman DJ's, but then this is a place with ample nightlife for all various
types. In the after hours lesbian dance scene there are more than a few
all woman clubs with woman dj's, but then again quite a few are not
very interested in spinning outside of their own community (why should they,
having solved the problem for themselves on an acceptable level).
It also goes the other way, and gets worse. If you think acceptance and respect
dont come easily in the house community, try being a woman DJ in the hip-hop
community. Try being a gay male DJ in the hip-hop community and on and on.
It is a pretty large problem, eh (recognition).
And only WE can change it.
just adding on.

Laura says:

>See, I have no idea why these guys are standing there, and I have
>to wonder.  They don't stand around when male DJs spin, except for
>the very very good ones like Lenny Dee, and I'm no where near that

>DAUNTING to say the least.

It is "freaky", we've all aknowleded that. There aren't many girl
djs, people gawk at things that are different, you are different,
people gawk at you.  Don't take it so personal or sexual or negative.
Take advantage of it and prove yourself like everyone else has to do.

>I think there are just not a lot of women who are willing to put
>themselves out there to become DJs because of the stuff I described.

I doubt it.  There just aren't that many woman interested in it
for some reason or another, although that reason probably has
to do with societal gender programming but that's a different facet
of this issue.  If any one is intimidated out of doing something
they realy want to do than they need to work on certain aspects of
their charcter.

>The *PROMOTERS* and *ORGANIZERS* as a whole have been 100% 
>supportive of me.  But when you see the DJ old-boy network, getting
>involved is a bit nerve-wracking.  You know how it is -- they all
>hang together in a corner behind the booth peering out at the rave
>and talking amongst themselves, naming all the instruments and 
>producers involved in a track, and rating the current DJs mixing
>skills.  Most guys are socialized to be a bit more thick-skinned,
>and have little problem dealing with this.

That's called trade jargon and it sounds like you need to be
there with them if you're realy worth your wax & 1200's.  Have you
ever tried to participate or are you creating intimidation for
your self by assuming that they wouldn't want you there?

From: Alan Michael Parry <brit@ravel.udel.edu>
Subject: Minority status
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu

In answer to someone who stated that I was wrong in my definition of what
a minority is:

 "The term minority [is] highly misleading. In sociological use a minority
  refers not to the numercial size of a group but to their socioeconomic
  and poltical status. In sociological use a minority is "a group of
  people who, because of their physical or cultural characteristics, are  
  singled out from the others in the society in which they live for
  differential and unequal treatment, and who therefore regard themselves 
  as objects of collective discrimination.""

               -"SOCIAL PROBLEMS" Frank Scarpitti/Margaret Anderson 1992  
  _
 (_ )  ) (  ) _(            
 (  (_ (_) ( (_(

Steve sez:

> Can someone post the titles and musicians on the C2 tapes in 
> the order taped.  Thanks.

Well, I think this is a bit of wishful thinking, with 5 DJs and only 3
of them here on the net, not to mention tons of different records, but
if it happens, cool.  This is what I have (again for those who may
have missed it):

layout for C2 cassettes

tapes are in chronological order and are complete except for 10
minutes of Lee's set edited out from between the ddagger and forall
sides due to record skipping

circle		Scott Hardkiss			43 minutes
bullet		Scott Hardkiss			12 minutes
		Jon Drukman unmixed		31 minutes

sharp		Jon Drukman mixed		43 minutes
		Moonpup				 1 minute
flat		Moonpup				44 minutes

dagger		Moonpup				39 minutes
ddagger		Moonpup				17 minutes
		Lee				22 minutes

forall		Lee				45 minutes
exists		BLURrrr				45 minutes

C2 setlist for David Kelly aka BLURrrr

monumental - 'geera'
organs musical clocks and boxes - 'still'
transform - 'transformation'
house pimps - 'zulu nation'
dance 2 trance - 'power of american natives'
blood runs dry - 'all of your mind'
mukkaa - 'buruchacca'
dr. atomic - 'schudelfloss'
robin s - 'show me love'

Feel free to send me your additions if you want to contribute and you
know for sure what something is... or if you were the DJ :-)

Bob

On Mon, 3 May 1993, Mark Baldwin wrote:

> i have a comment to anyone saying there are not enough women djs...or
> that the color of their wallpaper is all wrong...or their shoes are too
> tight...
> 
> do something.  instead of asking why there aren't more girl djs, ask
> yourself why YOU ARE NOT A DJ.  that might be a good place to start.
> or why you are not on the panel, etc.  not flaming, but i DO have a 
> big pet peeve about these kinds of issues, especially when it becomes
> a gender thing.
> 
> -mARK.
First - I am not a DJ because I barely have the time to write this
response let alone invest the time in hunting through record stores and
all the other time consuming factors that go into djing - I am a Chemical
Engineering student, and a good one at that which unfortunately precludes
some hobbies - such as dj'ing - maybe someday.

Second - I am not a woman.  But I think it is everyone's responsibility to
help foster an environment that is supportive to everyone - not just those
who are already establishd in certain positions.  When I started this
series of posts it was to see if anyone had suggestions as to how we can
all work towards making raves or dj'ing more open to everyone - not just
men.  So that women like laura wouldn't have to deal with all the sexist
bullshit they currently have to to get exposure.  

I was looking for constructive ideas - not broad insulting generalizations
such as " women always blame men . . . "

etc. . . 

I thought maybe we could start commenting to promoters and asking them
about women DJ's getting their ideas and if they think that they won't
attract people - tell them they would - if enough people did maybe a
promoter (assumed male here since most are) who had such preconceptions
would get over them - I'm not promoting giving women preferential
treatment - I'm promoting equal opportunity

Fran

Hmm... GK wasn't that bad, except that I was feeling kinda ill (too
much food wine drink and song at the larch-ranchidian mountain retreat),
so I didn't dance much. But the music was decent, the crowds weren't
pushing me around, and there wasn't too much gangsta vibe. Course, it
helped to get there late. We got there at 3, it didn't really start
going till 4. Not necessarily a rave-outing to write home about, but
then again, at least it didn't get busted... 

(actually, we arrived at Wicked around 5AM to arrive just as wicked was
getting busted. the plan was to avoid the big gangsta bumrush from
1-3AM at wicked by going to GK.... then make a late appearance at
wicked when the vibe had been created.)

To: ne-raves@gnu.ai.mit.edu

two words
tolerance
understanding

tolerating someone mean you deal with them as someone you have
to deal with
understanding means you deal with someone as who they are

stop talking
just listen
listen to what is being said, listen to why it is being said
listen to who is saying it
listen

think about it
think about where the speaker is coming from,
it doesnt matter that they are wrong
that they are not seeing what is obvious
just figure out why they are saying what they are saying
and
listen

understand why they think what they think
not from what you know from what they know
and in doing so lose yourself and gain their perspective
and see the world through different eyes

then explain why you think the way you do
not assuming you are right even though you are
not assuming that they are wrong even though they are

but do not talk
converse
communicate 
in both directions

i dont think anyone on this list 
is someone who would concsiously say or think
that a woman is a bad dj just becuase they have ovaries

but someone said taht the only thing more we coudl do
is ENCOURAGE women to dj 

YES
EXACTLY

women need to be encouraged
they have more discouragements than men
(REALLY, they do...)
so they shoudl get more encouragements

if someone is bothered by the people glaring at them
then it is a problem
and it is not one that should have to be dealt with
does it happen to more women than men?
well im sure some male djs get droolers
but how many females do?
and does it bother the men?
and does it bother the women?

women shouldnt have to put up with shit just becuase
they are women 
or becauase they are differnt
and we should actively try to stop it
its not a reverse discrimination thing
its a promoting equality thing

lets see
a guy wants to be a dj
he goes out buys a system and some records
the guy selling him stuff says
'cool, you want to dj? what type of music? good luck!'
he sets up the equipment and practices
and practices and is okay so he gets a gig
and hes not great but people dont run out of the warehouse
so he gets another adn gets good

a girl wants to be a dj
she goes out and buys a system and some records
the guy says
'why do you want this? OHHHH Youre going to be a DJ?
thats cool.. you know how to set this stuff up??
dont you think that music is a little to hard?'
she does have trouble setting it up because
daddy didnt teach her anything  about stereos cars etc
cuz shes just a girl and mommy didnt know anything about it
she gets it set up and practices and practices and practices
and is okay so she gets a gig
and shes not that great but people dont run out of the warehouse
but a bunch of people say 'well shes pretty good for a girl'
so she gets another and the guys stare at her and crowd
her at the turntables and she goes home
and buys a sewing machine

and no, it doesnt always happen that way
but denying that it isnt likely  is denying a lot
or at least so i think
but im often wrong
and just too egotistical to admit it

 ,
dana
