From: "Tim Hyland" <thyland.US1.oramail@us.oracle.com>
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Subject: More female DJs
Original-To: MAILSEQ:sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu


There are a few other female DJs whose names I haven't seen fly by.  There's
Evil-E (or does she spell it Evol-E?) who spun a couple times in the chill room
at Care*Free.  She also spins at the Eagle Creek Saloon (gay bar on Market in
SF) on Fridays and Saturdays.  Lots of ambient/trancey house -- loved her mix.

Another club DJ who really hasn't gotten into the raves scene is Page Hodel. 
She's the DJ *and* Promoter for two clubs:  The Box at the Kennel Club
(Divisaderoin SF), which is a very mixed (gay/straight, boys/girls, ethnicity,
etc.) hip hop, funk, and house club on Thursdays.  (Fun, nice energy, but not
ravey.)  She also spins and promotes for the Dance Factory in Berkeley on
Saturday nights.  

One woman who DJs who I haven't heard is Stephanie Phillips who spins with
Nikki Rivera at Product, I'm told, and a couple other lesbian/gay clubs. 
Another in this class is Lily Tran, who spun at a couple sunday afternoon raves
in Golden Gate Park last summer and now spins at the G-Spot (End-Up, Saturday
nights, another women's dance club).

The last one I can think of is Monique, who is a friend of Neon Leon and the
crowd at BPM, who I haven't heard play in public much.

Share and enjoy,

Tim

P.S.  In Amsterdam, there is a woman DJ named Isis who I hear is fabulous (but
have not heard) and is 18, I think.  She spins at Mazzo (cool ravey club) and a
number of raves in Holland and Belgium.

Subject: Sisters are doing it for themselves

As promised, here's more info on the women-run party Gregg and I mentioned
yesterday.

This will be a party organized and promoted by women with all-female DJ's
and production crew.  The working name is Our Sister's House.  It's going to
be a Thursday night event at a club, possibly on an ongoing weekly basis.
The starting date hasn't been decided yet.

The five or so women involved so far have lots of experience in the scene,
although not as primary organizers.  There's an organization meeting tonight
(Tuesday), and they told me any woman on SFRaves who's interested is
welcome, whatever your experience is.  Also, if you're worried about the
21+ problem, working at a party can be an effective loophole...

So if you're interested, show up at 7pm at 871 Page St. #3 (@ Scott),
home of Liz.  For questions, call Peace at (415) 431-2320.

Has anyone out there noticed that with multiple discussions
of various topics involving sexism, racism and world
politics, the traffic on the list has gone up to around a
quarter megabyte a day?  And that a lot of the traffic is
looking dangerously close to the dreaded usenet
flame-exchanges?  It greatly pains me to delete things on
this list without reading them, but that's what I've had to
do lately.

I mean okay, so this is a community, so that means that
various topics of discussion are fair game... but that
also means you should really make an effort to exercise some
restraint and try and avoid jamming the communications
channel...  

Personally, I'd like to see a little more priority given to
news and a little less to editorials.

To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
In-Reply-To: Monica Tauriello's message of Sun, 2 May 93 15:47:22 EDT <CMM-RU.1.3.736372042.monicat@gandalf.rutgers.edu>
Subject: Re: costs of raving

>>>>> On Sun, 2 May 93 15:47:22 EDT, Monica Tauriello <monicat@gandalf.rutgers.edu> said:

  Monica> guess that's cuz i started raving in brighton, england, tho,
  Monica> where most of the raves i attended were outdoors and FREE
  Monica> (donations for the generators)...clearly, this was because
  Monica> djs donated their time, and i don't expect them all to do
  Monica> that as they also have to make a living, and perhaps because
  Monica> the brighton police weren't as organized to crack down on
  Monica> raves as they may be here (nj, sf).  however, i guess i'd
  Monica> always seen it as a kind of countercultural, even
  Monica> anarchic/autonomous, thing.

Well, I'm just getting into raving, and at the moment here in
Cambridge, England, I mainly go to small parties, where 50 people on
the dance floor is too crowded to dance...  It does seem to me to be
very much a counter-culture thing.  It's all somewhat underground,
with locations generally not publicized in advance, and it's
completely non-commercial -- most of the parties are free.  Of course,
here in the UK, even the radio stations are underground (ie illegal
pirate stations).

That said, this weekend, I went to my first big commercial rave, the
Universe Tribal Gathering in Wiltshire.  Cost was 25 pounds, and they
were charging a pound for a small bottle of water, despite the fact
that flyer said free water... :-( But I was impressed at how friendly
the whole atmosphere was...  The place was BIG (25,0000 people) but
somehow the main tents had a really good vibe, and outside there was a
wonderful friendly festival atmostphere....  Cool.

I just got my C2 tapes from Bob (thanks, Bob!) and I've just started
listening to the first tape (circle).  My first reaction is that it's
very mellow and dreamy.  Excellent music, but have I got the tapes in
the wrong order?  For me, this is 4am music....  It's really cool to
hear tunes that I know and love -- I just wish I knew what they
were...

Peace,

	-roy

From sfraves-request@medisg.Stanford.EDU  Tue May  4 07:38:53 1993
Received: from medisg.Stanford.EDU by soda.berkeley.edu (5.65/KAOS-1)
	id AA23066; Tue, 4 May 93 07:38:53 -0700
Received: by medisg.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA23676; Tue, 4 May 93 07:38:10 PDT
Received: from soda.berkeley.edu by medisg.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA23672; Tue, 4 May 93 07:38:08 PDT
Received: from usl.usl.com by soda.berkeley.edu (5.65/KAOS-1)
	id AA22717; Tue, 4 May 93 07:34:53 -0700
Message-Id: <9305041434.AA22717@soda.berkeley.edu>
Date: Tue, 4 May 93 10:20 EDT
From: laura@usl.com
To: ne-raves@gnu.ai.mit.edu, sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Subject: djing and droolling
Received: from usl by usl.com; Tue,  4 May 1993 10:20 EDT
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 1904

I wrote:

>But when you see the DJ old-boy network, getting
>involved is a bit nerve-wracking.  You know how it is -- they all
>hang together in a corner behind the booth peering out at the rave
>and talking amongst themselves, naming all the instruments and 
>producers involved in a track, and rating the current DJs mixing
>skills.

>>That's called trade jargon and it sounds like you need to be
>>there with them if you're realy worth your wax & 1200's.  Have you
>>ever tried to participate or are you creating intimidation for
>>your self by assuming that they wouldn't want you there? 

Yes, I know my techno-trivia shit as well as the rest of them.  In fact, I 
learned it from some of the biggest instrument geeks on the net.  I just would 
rather hang out and have fun and groove at the party when I'm not working than 
be involved with the DJ rating panel / peanut gallery.  But the real fact is
that I don't like feeling like I'm being subjected to their comments.  I know
it's part of the game, but WHY does it have to be part of the game?  The guys
love to know all the facts, have all the answers, be able to play-by-play
analyze the mixes.  I don't HAVE to like what they do, and I sure as hell
don't have to assimmilate myself into their cliques.  Especially when raving 
as a whole is supposed to be so anti-clique.

I think another part of it is that there is a HUGE prejuidice against 
beginners, regardless of gender.  That's probably part of what I'm running up 
against, too.  Hell, my ex-boyfriend LAUGHED at me when I told him I was going
to learn to DJ.  A male A-list DJ verbally harassed me at my last gig.  If 
that's the kind of attitude people have toward beginners, especially female 
beginners, then can't you understand why maybe some people shy away?  The warm
fuzzy "come join our party" aspect of rave culture does not seem to extend 
into the realm of DJing.

Laura

From sfraves-request@medisg.Stanford.EDU  Tue May  4 08:07:18 1993

Received: by medisg.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)

From: barryale@symantec.com (Barry Alexander)
Message-Id: <9304047365.AA736531314@symantec.com>
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Subject: raves a movement?



i attended the cyberforum at the whole earth expo last friday and one theme
that was brought up was rave as a movement/community thing. and that it has the
potential for incorporating the positive aspects of "the vibe" into every day 
"mainstream" life. but there where no real specifics presented by the panel, no 
real time too.

a few raves that i've attended have influenced me in very positive ways by 
reestablishing in me a spiritual connection of self/community/cosmos through 
rythmic, shared trance.  these were mainly word of mouth/no flyer/map point 
raves of the $7-$10 outdoor variety.  i haven't had the same experience though 
at all club/warehouse (big flyer) raves where most people are there just to 
party/front/be cool.

i believe that the insight that can be gained by individuals not tuned into the 
vibe getting the vibe would benefit the well-being of the planet at large.  if 
the integrity remains strictly at underground events, will it have any long 
term effect/momentum to change society in a positive way?  or does it matter.  
is it just another rites of youth culture thing, something we'll all tell our 
grand kiddies about?

> i would love to be a dj, and when i have the time and money i might start

> many men in the hardcore community being uncomfortable with women.  another
> woman, a promoter, wrote of the assumptions people make about her: that she
> is just someone's girlfriend, etc.  historically rock music has been

ok, this may be true.  but i think that if the majority of a certain type
of person (i hate using that terminology, but for the purpose of communica-
tion...) typically fits a certain role in a certain scene, you tend to 
think that others of that same "type" (forgive me...) fit into the same 
mold.

i know that people get very offended by this.  like if you said something
like, "oh, is s/he black?"  or "oh, is s/he mexican?" (examples only) in
response to a statement about [put in your favorite minority-type-stero-
type here] you might offended a whole bunch of people, white, black, 
blue, red.... but that's the way the human mind works.  and it's usually
a good thing.  it's how you figure out where the square goes, and where
the triangle and the circle go.  of course, people aren't shapes, they're
people, and that mindset only works so well.   *sigh*
 
> male-dominated and sexist, and i don't see raves, etc. as being that much
> diffeerent in that respect.  what we need to do is recognize the sexism women
> face, and work against it.  it IS a political issue -it's not just about the

you're right, monicat, and i'm not going to say that this isn't true, but 
the other point of interest here is that if women (in general<---) didn't
allow this to happen it wouldn't happen.  you have to realize that LOTS
of women like this type of attention and do their best to propagate the
male/female roles that you've described above.  and a large group of men
like it too, so they say more power to ya!

	id AA26482; Tue, 4 May 93 13:06:43 PDT
Received: by soda.berkeley.edu (5.65/KAOS-1)
	id AA14014; Tue, 4 May 93 13:03:28 -0700
Message-Id: <9305042003.AA14014@soda.berkeley.edu>
From: bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu (Brian Behlendorf)
Date: Tue, 4 May 1993 13:03:28 -0700
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Subject: GUIDELINES FOR POSTING TO SFRAVES

Some guidelines for posting to SFRaves.   Print this out and tape it to
your computer for handy reference.  This list will be given to all new
members from now on.

1)  First realize that

	a) SFRaves is a large mailing list.

	b) The volume is already quite high.

	c) For every editorial or opinion there are hundreds of
	   possible replies.

	d) Topics of world import such as feminism and race relations
	   will *always* be with us, at least for the current generation,
	   and while discussion about them is important the issues *won't*
	   be resolved by just talking about them here on the list.  They
	   are appropriate here as long as they aren't more appropriate
	   in soc.feminism, etc.

	e) Ego has NO PLACE on the mailing list.

	f) Even with a high signal-to-noise ratio, a high volume means more
	   people skim articles than actually read them.  This is a bad thing.

2)  Now for the general rules:

	a) NO PERSONAL ATTACKS - even if someone is being a complete
	   jerk and everyone agrees, please refrain from flaming him/her
	   in public.  Send him/her all the private email you want.  If
	   they flame you first, be the wise one and take the argument
	   off the list.  If he/she is truely being a jerk everyone knows
	   it anyways.  The difference between a well-reasoned argument
	   and a personal flame should be quite clear.

	b) Try and set an upper limit to your number of posts to 2 a day.
	   Making more is fine, but as you're typing your third make *sure*
	   it's something that's worth the time of the 250 people you are
	   sending it to.

	c) BREVITY IS THE SOUL OF WIT.  Paragraphs prove you have a point.

	d) Ranting is the opposite of raving (thanks to rth@netcom.com for
	   reminding us)

	e) Don't reply to a post until you have read your entire mail
	   queue and made sure no one else has replied exactly what you
	   would say.

	f) Refrain from making "me too" posts, where you simply add "I agree"
	   to the bottom of a quoted message.

	g) If you reply to a post someone makes, READ EVERY WORD THEY SAY
	   CAREFULLY, and in the absence of facial and hand gestures interpret
	   their comments in the best possible light.  It's very hard for the
	   "TV" generation (which we are whther you own a TV or not) to know
	   how to communicate without visual cues.  Make sure you understand
	   what the other person is saying.  

	h) If a conversation turns into a particulary heated argument, wait
	   at least an hour before making your reply, to allow you to see 
	   what they are saying in the absence of a testosterone rush.

	i) Be SURE of what you are saying when you say it.  Proofread your
	   comments several times.  Make sure your use of certain words is
	   the generally accepted use by the community at large, not what
	   *you* think that usage should implicate.


We are at the brink of something BIG here, and SFRaves can be a part of
it.  But only if we keep ourselves as high quality as we've been in the
past, and these guidelines are a part of it.  Anyone who's spent a good
deal of time on the net knows these as part of an unwritten policy, but
they bear repeated for those who are new.  

The Conciousness Revolution has begun.

	Brian

I've seen girls crowd around Jeno, during New Years Eve, a bunch were
crowding him, trying to get him to look at them, (trying to pass him
phone numbers, the whole bit).  He almost ALWAYS has guys crowding him
hanging on EVERY cut he makes, scoping his style and trying to get
his label titles (he often puts tape over the titles :) I've seen
Jeno do what any good DJs do... ignore it all and keep spinning.  A good
DJ should be able to keep the vibe going even when the riot police are
busting through the door, that's their job.  Any guy DJ that will allow
his attention to be thrown cuz a woman (or man) with a killer body is 
dancing in front of him is not ready to playout yet.

>  uh-oh. Looks as if someone is afraid of losing his white male
> priviledge.

>um, first uv ahl, geoff didn't say that, i did.  and i don't know 
>what you mean by my 'white male priveledge', and second ov all, this
>kind of response is EXACTLY what i was reffering to!! 

>frequency. When the heterosexual white male realizes the situation
>and stops thinking that he is under attack, then things may begin to
>change -

I think the problem here is that many of us heterosexual white males
have never experienced these percs or priveledges because we are
and LOOK countercoulture and even those who don't look it but are
more "superior minded beings" than the Dominators don't like to be
classed with them just because they and we happen to be white, het.,
males.  Being a heterosexual white male doesn't automaticly add you
to the club.  It has a lot to do with social and economic class and
other factors which nobody seems to recognize.  I'm the kind of
person that the kind of person that would descriminate would
descriminate against just because of the kind of person I am (did
ya get that?).  I also live a lower quality of life than many
minorities and get "vibed on" (per Geoffs definition) by some
minorities because I'm white and by store/resauraunt owners, etc.
because of the way I look, and by some woman because I'm male so I
in some ways I am more of an "outcast" than anyone else because I
am not recognized as a minority class and feel that I'm unfairly
categorized with the white, het., male label.  If any of these other
descriminated against classes could realy know me than they'd know
that I was "one of them".  Descrimination and bigotry take many
forms and I think people need to see it's not just a color thing.  
I always get sneers and weird looks by lesbians here in Berkeley
and I was recently flipped off by a black guy driving by whom I'd
never seen (Not a traffic thing, we had no interaction) just cause 
I'm male and white (I guess) and I feel like just saying "Shut the
fuck up, I'm on your side!"  The ironic thing is I'm the only male
(except for my dog, Juma) in a household of 5 woman, two of whom
are my daughters, I don't see how I could NOT be a feminist, and I 
live in a black neighborhood, where the local posse of 10 year olds
come and kick it at my house all the time.  It sounds rhetorical but
all oppressed people need come together and to realize who the enemy
realy is.

-Mark

        Salt Lake City, UT 84101-1817

When in Utah call the T A S T E hotline 801-461-3375.

Trying to find these releases?  Try Ear/Rational Music:
FAX 805/893-8553, Phone 805/564-4949, email angst%cs@hub.ucsb.edu

Back issues are available from me by mail or by ftp'ing to soda.berkeley.edu.
They're in the pub/sfraves/music directory.

This is all my opinion.  Flames against a review are pretty pointless, so
don't bother.  Let me know if you have any other comments though.

BPMs provided courtesy of Eric Pederson's BPM calculator for the Sparc.

XDZebra Reviews may be reproduced without permission under one condition,
they remain intact and unchanged.  If you publish this in print, mail me a
copy via "Addiction".

Review #29 Contents:
68000: Technocolor
Sandals: A Profound Gas
Black Dog Productions: (Bytes)
Deep Forest: Sweet Lullaby
Julian Cope: Dancing Heads
AFX in his third Analogue Bubblebath
Polygon Window: Quoth
Colours - A Compilation Album


68000: Technocolor
Pulse Soniq: SR9221
1  129  05:31 M21
2  130  04:26 Mind Machine
3  132  05:03 I/O
4  134  04:50 Technohead (Down in It)
5   96  04:19 Funky Twisted Sound
6  128  05:12 Vivid
7  126  04:52 Juno Echo
8  130  04:54 Data Cloud 9
9  134  04:31 Technocolor
10 132  05:21 Benzine
11 120  03:22 "Life"
12 134  04:44 Technohead (Life Mix)
13 134  06:17 Technohead (Smart Edit)
14 129  05:31 M21 (Galaxy Surprize)
15 120  02:28 Analogics (Pure Analog Edit)

Comments: An utter misery to sit through.  68000 has created an album that can
excite you with appearance: "15 tracks! Cool name! Cool art!"  Then trap you
in a litany of sameyness.  It isn't so much that they don't have a lot of
spice in their melodies or rhythms, but the fact that they use the same
instruments over and over.  It wouldn't be too much of a stretch to guess that
this entire thing was composed on one synthesizer, but unlike some artists,
68000 didn't have time to mess with presets or at change them from one state
to another.

Summary: 2/10.  Hard to listen to in one shot.  No shakeability present at
all.


Sandals: A Profound Gas
Acid Jazz/London Records: Jazid 47CD
1  104  08:44 Vocal Mix
2  104  07:58 Chetali Mix
3  104  08:45 Ardens Bud Phase 1
4  104  03:39 Ardens Bud Phase 2
5  104  04:39 Profound Dub

Comments: Groovalicious and thrownback, Sandals bring slinky jazz to a modern
form.  I would have liked to seen a heavier use of the flute, and the vocals
seem to serve no purpose with a "we've got a singer, we've got to use him" air
about them.  The mixes are decent, but unspectacular.  They get boring after
about five minutes, most of them are too long.

Summary: 6/10.  I'd like to see an album from these people, this is some
intriguing work.


Black Dog Productions: (Bytes)
Warp: WARPcd8
1  122  05:44 Object Orient by Plaid
2  128  06:15 Caz by Close Up Over
3   98  06:43 Carceres Ex Novum by Xeper
4       01:00 Phil(1)
   126  04:42 Focus Mel by Atypic.
    71  01:30 Phil(2)
5  129  04:08 Olivine by Close Up Over
        00:38 Phil(3)
6  133  06:24 Clan (Mongol Hordes) by I.A.O
7  126  02:12 Phil(4)
   112  04:02 Yamemm by Plaid
8  120  00:54 Phil(5)
   135  03:42 Fight The Hits by Discordian Popes
   131  01:45 Phil(6)
9  120  04:34 Merck by Balil
10 125  00:47 Phil(7)
   122  05:00 Jauqq by Close Up Over
11 124  07:35 Heart by Balil

Comments:  I'm almost certain that a member of Black Dog Productions has been
mapping my brain to see exactly what kind of music I'll go ape over.  This
album does it.  I had no idea that they were responsible for the way cool
I.A.O track on "Artificial Intelligence".  That was only a brief initiation
into what kind of abilities they have.  How to describe?  Melodic, trancey,
sometimes acidic.  The most distinguishing feature is the fact that these boys
know how to lay down a rhythm.  Sampled or constructed, they send vibrations
down my spine as I attempt to sit motionless in a chair.  On top of that, they
score with a cover design that manages to be computer-cool without being
Mondo-stupid.  Decoding the track listing somehow reminded me of cracking
code.

Summary: 10/10.  Warp scores again.  You don't deserve to have ears unless
you've heard this album first.


Deep Forest: Sweet Lullaby
Epic/Sony: 49K 74919
1   88  03:54 Original Mix
2   88  06:08 (Remix)
3  124  06:00 Q-Bass Mix
4  122  06:50 Round the World Mix
5  130  03:08 Bonus A La Efx

Comments: As the liner says, Deep Forest is not a group or artist, but a
"concept".  A damn good one at that.  Record the songs of African rain forest
Pygmies, then throw a synth line and drum beat behind it.  Things are slow
moving, but very luscious and deep.  The fact that this works so well at a
slow rate, is forgotten by the remixers as they pump it up on the last three
tracks and lose every bit of original integrity.  The last remix sounds
slightly better than the other two, but only as a stand-alone and not a
variation of the original.

Summary: 8/10.  The album should be interesting.  What I fear is this is going
to be on the airwaves ala "Sadeness" for the next year, making me thoroughly
sick of it.


Julian Cope: Dancing Heads
Island: 422-868 909-2
1   84  03:36 Head (Remix)
2   89  06:09 Head (Long Meg and Her Daughters Mix)
3  113  06:52 Love (L.U.V.) (Beautiful Love Remix)
4   98  08:18 Easty Risin' (East Easy Rider Remix)

Comments: I've always enjoyed Julian Cope, but never expected to find anything
of his that could possibly hit the dancefloor.  While rummaging through a
promo-CD shop, I ran over this.  "Dancing Heads" takes the rippingest parts of
the three Cope songs from "Peggy Suicide" and does the funky beat thing behind
them.  Sounds simple, but it works excellently.  Hugoth Nicolson did a
brilliant job with this work, it is too bad that it has been buried under a
ton of other commercial garbage.

Summary: 8/10.  I have no idea if this is still being pressed or not.  If you
like Julian Cope, you'll love this.  However, Cope doesn't appeal to everyone.


AFX in his third Analogue Bubblebath
Rephlex: CAT 008
1  133  03:54 .215061
2  136  08:03 .1993841
3   79  04:15 .0180871a
4  145  04:37 .942937
5  128  03:53 .0180871b
6  141  04:48 .0008908569
7  154  04:20 .5527803773258
8  125  04:06
9  125  05:07
10 144  00:36 AFX 6/b
11      04:41
12      00:54
13 147  05:14

Comments:  Richard James does it again with another slew of incredible
material.  More in line with the "Ambient Works" album than the Polygon Window
releases, Analog Bubblebath 3 is less harsh than either.  There are a few
harsh tracks, such as 4, 5, 7, 10, and 13, but even these have a weird
softness overlaid that only Richard James is able to do effectively.  9 is an
unsually funky work for AFX, as is the beatless 11 & 12. 3 shows he isn't
afraid to use samples, and distort them beyond recognition.  The prime tracks
are 1 and 8.  1 is logical extension to Analog Bubblebath 2, and 8 practically
had tears running down my face.

Summary: 9/10. Despite the wacky packaging (bubble wrap), and no printing on
the CD itself, this is Richard's best album yet.  It is also the hardest to
acquire.


Polygon Window: Quoth
Warp: WAP 33CD
1  139  05:36 Quoth (Original)
2  140  04:31 Iketa
3  142  07:58 Quoth (Wooden Thump Mix)
4   92  06:00 Bike Pump Meets Bucket

Comments: The first single from Warp and Richard James.  "Quoth" is one of the
harder tracks from the Polygon Window album, and the "Wooden Thump Mix"
certainly doesn't soften things at all.  "Iketa" is in Richard's patented
ambient style while "Bike Pump" is smooth, bouncy, and almost jazzy.  The Warp
packaging is stellar as usual.  I also purchased the 12" for the ultra-groovy
clear vinyl that it comes on.

Summary: 8/10.  The first three tracks are fairly standard for James, but the
final "Bike Pump" stands out.


Colours - A Compilation Album
Union City Recordings: cducr 1
1  124  06:24 UFI: Understand This Groove
2  124  05:44 Metropolis: Metropolis
3  123  05:34 Mombossa: Cry Freedom (Malawi Mix)
4  121  06:38 M.K. Featuring Alana: Burning (Mk Remix Extended)
5  128  06:48 M.A.N.I.C.: I'm Comin Hardcore (Original)
6  122  05:14 TC 1991: Berry
7  135  07:29 Urban Jungle: Bad Man
8  126  07:39 TC 1992: Funky Guitar (Lion Rock Inna Milanese Stylee)
9  129  04:59 Metropolis: Hyporeel
10 120  07:41 B.M.Ex: Appolonia: Quatmix
11 123  06:25 M.K. Featuring Alana: Always (12" Underground)
12 140  04:41 Unity: Unity (Piano City)

Comments: A very housey comp with some real classics.  The majority of the
compositions on here have a lot of familiar samples that are used effectively
without stealing from the original sources.  Metropolis is especially skilled
in accomplishing this, their tracks are like trips through all sorts of dance
music.  The two included TC tracks are prime, and if you don't have them yet,
you're missing out.  As with a lot of good house music, piano is prevalent.
M.A.N.I.C. and Unity feature some especially fine riffs.  "Cry Freedom" is
very uplifting tribal.  The only thing I really don't like are the Alana
tracks, her vocals are a bit too sweet for my tastes.

Summary: 7/10.  One of the better collections of house in a while, but
available only on import.

To: sfraves@medisg.Stanford.EDU
From: mcg@netcom.com (MykL G)
Subject: Re: GUIDELINES FOR POSTING TO SFRAVES

Thanks to Brian for some very good rules o' thumb.

I have two to add to the above:

a)  If a discussion gets particularly hot and high volume, especially
    involving broader issues than the SF scene, it should be taken to
    private e-mail.  It's easy to make a local mail alias or just send
    the next message to only the people who have been directly involved in
    the discussion.  One final post to SFRaves can be made to invite anyone
    who's interested to join the private group.

    This should have been done a couple of days ago with the gender and
    race discussions.  It should *certainly* be done for any future
    messages on these topics.  As moderator, I think Brian should
    jump in and recommend when a discussion should go private before
    it gets too unwieldy.  (Don't be shy, Brian  ;^)

b)  If someone sends you a private message, PLEASE don't quote them
    and respond in public without asking their permission (OK, Mark G.?)
    There's a reason they sent you the message privately, if only to
    keep the traffic down.  This is the second time this has happened
    to me in the last week, and if you think about it, it's really rude.

To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu

There are rave-related images available via anonymous FTP at the following
locations:

archive for: alt.rave
site: cs.uwp.edu (Dave Datta's Music Archives)
directory: /pub/music/pictures/a/alt.rave

archive for: SFRaves
site: soda.berkeley.edu
directory: pub/sfraves/images

archive for: NE-Raves
media-lab.mit.edu (NE-Raves archives)
directory: pub/ne-raves/pictures

Also be sure to check the incoming directories at these sites.  If you upload
to the alt.rave site, please upload JPEG/JFIF compressed images if you can.
I got the space on the condition that it would be conserved!  There are
already some rather large GIFs there that may be deleted one day.  The
'readme' file there is getting kind of old; sorry, I'm *way* behind on
maintaining that filespace.
                                                            Mike Brown

From: rox@netcom.com (Roxanna Stieber)
Message-Id: <9305050427.AA16794@netcom2.netcom.com>

Cc: jslee@well.sf.ca.us, rth@netcom.com, sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
In-Reply-To: John S. Lee's message of Tue, 4 May 1993 06:37:13 -0700 <199305041337.AA00742@well.sf.ca.us>
Subject: Weekend Report   
    was: Groove Kitchen a rip off ...

Look enough jumping on my case already. I do know the promotors of GK (or
use to). I support Preston's endeavors alot. I just don't think it's fair
to walk in for 5 seconds and walk right out and not get my money back.
They wouldn't let us peek inside. Next time one of us will go in and check
it out and that way if it isn't happening we'll only be out $10 split
between us and not $20. I use to go to GK way back when it was on Thurs.
nights at One Step Beyond. Besides we left Beltane cuz the vibe wasn't
there for us. To me a rave has to reach critical mass for the vibe to be
there. That's the way it is for me and my friends, it may be different for
you. So anyway we left GK and went to Wicked ANOTHER $30 for 2) and got
there between 2:30 and 3:00 to find at least 3 cop cars outside. We went
in anyway. Around 5:00 or so the cops came in with flashlights and were
shining them in people's eyes. Waking them up and shining the light right
in their eyes if they were sleeping. This was up on the balcony where we
were. Needless to say I have never seen this happen before. Alot of strange 
energy that night. 
Oh by the way on the way into Beltane at the Fashion Center the cops 
were there and were saying that everyone who was under 21 had to leave 
by 2:00 and that they were going to come back at 2:30 and if 
there were any under agers there they would shut the whole thing down.
The security was really heavy handed there. It was like BGP. Goons every
place, even in the chill-out room. That was one of the main reasons we
left. The overly thorough search we got on the way in really turned us
off. I mean we don't even look like the type that would carry weapons and
were very open to being searched, but they went overboard. 
Back to Wicked:        
Anyway we were enjoying Wicked even though we sensed that something was 
going to come down. Strange vibe. So after it got closed down we went 
over to the DNA and waited till it opened.  We finally found the vibe. 
Doc Martin and Simon really ripped up the dance floor. Doc Martin is a 
personal favorite of mine and it was really a nice surprise to see him 
there. So all in all the night/day turned out ok even if it was expensive.
Any way I'll probably go back to GK cuz I usually like the vibe there.
Although I did like the space better at King St. It was really dark at
Big Heart City. I mean I like it dark but it was so dark we couldn't find 
the bathrooms so we waited until we got to Wicked.

Rox

From: Arthur Chandler <arthurc@sfsuvax1.sfsu.edu>
Subject: Heat, Light, Rules and Regulations
To: sfraves@medisg.Stanford.EDU
Message-Id: <Pine.3.05.9305042157.A22270-b100000@sfsuvax1.sfsu.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

 
   I have to (politely) disagree with the notion that the recent
discussions about race and gender issues in the rave scene are out of
place. These issues were raised at the Cyberforum panel on raves because
many people felt them to be real issues.  The fact that they generated a
good deal of light and heat on sfraves shows that the issues are genuine,
and cannot be wished away -- and should not be moderated away.  There are
some unresolved issues here -- issues that connect the rave scene to the
society at large.  It's all well and good to complain in chorus about the
intrigues of cops and unscrupulous promoters; but if there are internal
problems, shouldn't they be brought to light here and discussed?  If the
thread topic is listed in the subject, folks who don't want to listen in
on it can just hit the delete key.  If they do want in on it -- well, this
is the Internet: be prepared for heat along with the light.
  Having said this, I still fully subscribe to Brian's and Mykl's notion
that personal arguments should remove to email.  The essence of the
Internet [[ arthurc moves to the top of soapbox ]] is mutual aid.  If my
response to your views on patriarchy or racial exclusivity is, in spirit,
intended to foster ultimate harmony, then it ought to go out to sfraves,
IMHO. If the spirit behind my reply is to ding you for your opinion, I
should probably hold it in; but if send it I must, I should email you so
that we can duel it out by ourselves.
  sfraves should be large.  It can contain multitudes of emotions.
Discordant voices can make for profounder harmonies.




*********************************************************************
******************  The problem, and the solution, ******************
******************    Is bringing things to bear.  ******************
*********************************************************************

well- ive sent unsub requests to all the lists im on, but if for some
reason they didnt work, or i had a wrong address, please take me off the
list- but ill be back in late august.

id like to thank all the folks ive become friends with on the net and on
vrave, and am looking forward to coming back in the fall!

id like to thank the list administrators and all the folks who work for
the lists doing the rave guides and hookup guides- its adding a bit of
cohesiveness to a very disjointed scene and helps keep a lot of folks
informed!

if anyone wants to keep in touch, ill be at the summer address below... if
your interested in trading fliers or dj tapes- send me yours and ill send
you mine... i think im pretty good at doing that...

to everyone whos address i have- ill most likely be dropping you a line
this summer, but if i dont, that doesnt mean im not thinking about you!

Want to see the space savings converting the GIF images to JPG?

-rw-r--r--  1 csc        160093 May  5 12:14 cindy.gif
-rw-r--r--  1 csc         35328 May  5 12:16 cindy.jpg
-rw-r--r--  1 csc        400712 May  5 12:14 danabry.gif
-rw-r--r--  1 csc        194718 May  5 12:21 danabry.jpg
-rw-r--r--  1 csc        734146 May  5 12:13 garth.gif
-rw-r--r--  1 csc        351355 May  5 12:18 garth.jpg
-rw-r--r--  1 csc        413671 May  5 12:14 group1.gif
-rw-r--r--  1 csc        194746 May  5 12:19 group1.jpg
-rw-r--r--  1 csc        125845 May  5 12:13 heffa.gif
-rw-r--r--  1 csc         52770 May  5 12:20 heffa.jpg
-rw-r--r--  1 csc        311699 May  5 12:15 jeachim.gif
-rw-r--r--  1 csc        149176 May  5 12:14 jessbeth.gif
-rw-r--r--  1 csc         68687 May  5 12:21 jessbeth.jpg
-rw-r--r--  1 csc        162593 May  5 12:20 joachim.jpg
-rw-r--r--  1 csc        112973 May  5 12:15 leah.gif
-rw-r--r--  1 csc         58556 May  5 12:21 leah.jpg
-rw-r--r--  1 csc         89601 May  5 12:15 xdzebra.gif
-rw-r--r--  1 csc         34094 May  5 12:22 xdzebra.jpg

This is with a Q of 75 and a smoothing factor of 30. This results in
JPEG images virtually indistinguishable from the original GIF.
Scanning in images in 24 bit color and converting directly to JPEG
results in even more space savings with 24 bit color preserved.

I wonder why there aren't more pics? I'm an amateur photographer;
maybe I should set up shop at one of the parties or something :).


Sean

Hey dudes and dudettes!  I've finally found a gateway to the Internet so's I
can get back in touch with you all.  I could have done it through the White
House system, but my address was so long that messages kept getting bounced
around.
Anyway, life in the West Wing is hectic, constant, long, and very exciting. 
Sorry, I haven't yet been able to schedule a rave for the East Room, but I'm
working on it.  Been to a couple of kewl events, but the work schedule doesn't
permit as much partying as I would like.  Needless to say, certain aspects of
raving no longer exist-interviews with the feds, interviews with counsel, a
great session of wee-wee for Willie, etc, etc.  Details on the pee test for
those who are interested.
So, I'm glad to be back in touch.  Let me know what's happening.  I'm looking
forward to being back in SF at the end of June for the parade and other
parties.  Until then, ravishingly yours,
Paul

I've formatted all the info that's been posted so far into a single
list.  I thought I'd post it here to help keep all the info in one
place, and to save everyone else having to do likewise...  (If I've
missed any info that's been posted, please let me know....)

	Cosmic Roy

-------------

1. Circle

Scott Hardkiss (43 min)


2. Bullet

Scott Hardkiss (12 min)

Jon Drukman (unmixed) (31 min)
  Meat Beat Manifesto		I Got The Fear (Without Jack)
  The Shamen			Boss Drum (Twitch)
  Lemon Interupt		Minniapolis (Twitch)
  JFK				Here They Come Again (Brutal Mix)
  Sonic Solution		On The Move


3. Sharp

Jon Drukman (43 min)
  Eden Transmission		I'm So High
  Up Above The World		Straight Up Caffeine
  High Lonesome Sound System	Champion Sound
  Metropolis			Metropolis (analog)
  Outdance			Pump The Jumpin' (Deco Mix)
  Coco Steel and Lovebomb	You Can't Stop The Groove (Twitch)
  Shakedown Productions		Alhambra (Twitch)
  The Grid			Crystal Clear (Trimar Mix)
  Electrotete			I Love You (remix)
  Intermix			Monument (Twitch)
  Mental Cube			Q (Santa Monica Mix)
  High Lonesome Sound System	Testimonial

Moonpup (1 min)


4. Flat

Moonpup	(44 min)
?
  Coco Steel & Lovebomb		Feel It

(Great, now I suppose all the cat and dog lovers are going
to start arguing with each other...) 

The FMR worked amazingly well at the new surprise site,
within "1/2 hour" of San Francisco. Most everyone, me
included, expected it to be busted during Garth's set... but
we made it through Garth, Jeno, Markie Mark... then I
decided to leave at around 8:30.  And unfortunately, as I
was walking to my car, a lone police officer was driving in.
I also noticed a guy in a Park Service truck sitting in the
airport parking lot, talking to someone who looked like he
worked at the airport.  So maybe things were fine until the
airport employees showed up.  

And those little Cessna's trying to buzz in close without
getting too near the power lines were pretty funny.

From sfraves-request@medisg.Stanford.EDU  Thu May  6 15:27:20 1993
Received: from medisg.Stanford.EDU by soda.berkeley.edu (5.65/KAOS-1)
	id AA20979; Thu, 6 May 93 15:27:20 -0700

Received: by soda.berkeley.edu (5.65/KAOS-1)
	id AA20019; Thu, 6 May 93 15:17:26 -0700
Message-Id: <9305062217.AA20019@soda.berkeley.edu>
From: bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu (Brian Behlendorf)
Date: Thu, 6 May 1993 15:17:26 -0700
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Subject: F M R

        Wow, this was the best time I've had at a party since the first
FMR at Berkeley Marina.  

        First off, Geoff was actually the one who thought of and first
scoped out the locale;  I came down a couple times after that to see what
the patrol situation was like at night, and discovered that turning left
at the end of Embarcadero resulted in a better place than turning right.

        I was SO NERVOUS about this location, what with a) PA cops having
a reputation for "being bored" and b) East Palo Alto not too far away.
In fact I was so nervous I could barely see straight while driving there.
But we got to the lot, parked the car, and Geoff and Stevie and I proceeded
to plan out where to park cars in the huge lot.  This was about 1am.  Within
maybe an hour 100 cars had shown up, and over the course of the night a 
total of 260 cars were there (probably more, this is a count I did at 5am)

Anyways, by 3am the sound system was JUST getting set up, and still no sign
of cops.  I was flabbergasted, as I had totally expected them to show up by 
then.  The music switched on, and the 400 or so already there turned off
their car stereos and started dancing.  Instant "critical mass".  We were
now unstoppable :)

High points through the night:

1) walking out to the edge of the marsh walkway extending from the building
there and listening to the music from 1/2 mile away.  Why does House music
sound so damn good in the outdoors?

2) seeing a big Public Works "reclaimed water" truck pull in - I feared the
worst, like uhoh, he needs to do something here and we're here and he's 
gonna call the fuzz and have us shut down.  He turned his truck around and
parked in a side parking lot, got out of his car, and joined the party!  He
said he could hear the music from the recycling plant about 3/4 mile away,
and wanted to see what was happening :)

3) talking to a Palo Alto high school student in the morning who said, 
"I have to leave - I have a calculus final in 10 minutes!"

4) Standing on top of those Stonehengian concrete blocks and looking out
over the crowd.  EEeen-sane.

5) The cops finally showed up around quarter to nine (!!!!), and actually 
they would have never known about it had the park rangers not called them.
Someone walked up, explained what was going on, said we're a responsible
group, we pick up after ourselves, etc., and gave the cop his name and
number.  The cop said, just be gone by 11 or so... I was completely blown
away :)

6) EVERYONE was smiling, dancing on top of vans, speaker stacks, everything
spelled P-O-S-I-T-I-V-I-T-Y.

The bad points:

1) Too much alcohol and nitrous.  Thanks, Wally!

2) Even though the dance floor and cars were on a packed dirt parking lot
and thus not harmful to the environment, unfortunately there were a lot of
people walking through the plant life next to the marsh, crushing sensitive
plants and such.  The site would have been perfect if it weren't for this.

3) SOO much trash!  But it got cleaned up, most of it at least (and WHY is
it standard to throw cigarrette butts on the ground?  Come'on, people! Those
are SOOO hard to pick up and throw away :(   )

But that's about it for the bad points.  Overall, I was deliriously happy.
Peace to the huge SFRaves posse in effect there, and everyone :)

	Brian



From sfraves-request@medisg.Stanford.EDU  Thu May  6 17:54:43 1993

Date: Thu, 6 May 1993 20:19:19 -0400 (EDT)
From: Alan Michael Parry <brit@ravel.udel.edu>
Subject: UK article: Progressive House
To: ne-raves <ne-raves@gnu.ai.mit.edu>
Cc: sf-raves <sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu>, dc-raves <dcraves@american.edu>
Message-Id: <Pine.3.03.9305062019.A25411-c100000@ravel.udel.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII


 Call it progressive house. Call it instrumental dub disco. Call it what
you like, but now the rave scene is all but dead, progressive house has
reanimated dance music - and the best of it is being produced in Britain.
Progressive house was developed by DJs influenced by early house and the
Balearic club scene, who took advantage of cheap technology and turned
record producers and remixers. Thanks to DJs like Leftfield, Andrew
Weatherall, Darren Emerson, Fabi Paras, the Boy's Own team and Justin
Robertson, people have flooded back to nightclubs all over the country.
Robertson is a good example of how DJing has evoloved. Having run one of
the country's most respected nightclubs, "Most Excellent", he has been
hired to remix a succesion of tracks. Not only dance acts like TC1992 and
React to Rhythm, but also high profile pop acts such as the Shamen and the
Sugarcubes. Other club nights which have paved the way for the new UK
house sound in the last 18 months or so are Slam (Glasgow), Love Ranch and
Drum Club (both in London), Back to Basics (Leeds), Venus (Nottingham),
and Renaissance (Mansfield). "There's a new sound in the clubs, pioneered
by DJs sick of the rave scene," says Dave Wesson, progressive house guru
and owner of Zoom Records. "It's very much influenced by what's been
happening in Europe, but, in the end, it's just British dance music
created by a universal dissatisfaction with the rave scene." According to
Jonathan Richardson from Dance promotions outfit POP, "progressive house"
is "essentially an uplifting, dubby, percussive workout."
  POP look after The Grid, an early purveyor of the new style. Back in
early 1990 The Grid's first single, Floatation, had a set of so-called
"progressive" mixes on the 12" release. Richardson points to the success
of last year's Felix track, Don't You Want Me, as a demonstration of how
huge the progressive house scene has become. Guerilla Records, known as
the label at the forefront of the new sound, hate the "progressive" label.
"It's unhealthy to label anything - all music should be progressive," says
Guerilla's press agent Marion Sparks. A&M marketing man Richard Marshall,
meanwhile, reckons that the labelling of the new movement is essential
because "name tags are a necessary evil: they articulate the style to the
masses".
 But, as usual, it all comes down to money, and selling loads and loads
of records. So British-dub-disco ("progressive house" if you must) is
about to hit the mainstream in a major way. The current "massive" tune is
David Bowie's latest single, Jump They Say, as remixed by DJs and
producers Leftfield. Now thats progress...

  _                                -SKY Magazine: May 1993.
 (_ )  ) (  ) _(            
 (  (_ (_) ( (_(

advancement, and love. Instead I was detained by people who
have no interest in any of those ideals or civil liberties
for that matter.

searching for an attorney. If any of the SFRavers are
lawyers, and are interested in my case please contact me via
E-Mail (Zephirus@cats). I am not asking for donated legal
representation (Though it is quite welcome. As it stands I
will most likely be taking out loans to pay for my defense.
I am a student and not wealthy.) Above all, I am searching
for a good lawyer. In addition, if anyone can recommend a
lawyer, please do so.
 
     This incident took place on Highway 17 going from Santa
Cruz to Los Gatos. I was incarcerated at the Santa Clara
County Main Jail. I live in Santa Cruz. The trial will be in
Los Gatos on May 21st.

From: bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu (Brian Behlendorf)
Date: Fri, 7 May 1993 09:43:57 -0700
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu, sfraves-calendar@soda.berkeley.edu
Subject: This week's RAVE guide

Hi gang!  Sorry in the delay, I was waiting for more flyers to come
in but none did... hope this gets to everyone on time.

Tonight is looking kinda dry, so I'd take it easy tonight and maybe
hit Splash! in the morning.  I wonder if the pool will be open - bring
your swimsuits just in case :)  Obsession could be cool tonight, but
caveats abound about DV8 so who knoz.  And there's never been a post
to the list about Mr. Baked Raindrop, so I can't tell ya what they're
like, other than they must have decent production for the promoters to
keep using that name for the past 6 months...

BTW I *think* Mission Rock is happening, it's worth checking out too.

That Straight-Up Funk deal looks QUITE good - and since the GG park
party is STILL being negotiated (next weekend is the target date for
getting it started - if you want to vent your anger about this call
your friendly neighborhood GG Park permit office), this may be your
only chance this weekend to hear music in the lovely spring weather...

Saturday night:  Groove Kitchen and Where the Wild Things Are are
both highly regarded events, with the younger crowd tending to go
to WTWTA and the older crowd to GK.  I usually prefer the music at
GK, but the lineup at WTWTA looks great too.

And even though there won't be a sunday-in-the-park party this weekend
(hell, I even got on the phone and started calling recreation departments
to see about getting a site w/ sound permits and all - no luck) there
will be a gathering of folx in Marx Meadows around 1 I guess, with 
boomboxes and sunshine who could ask for anything more?

Enjoy yourself :)

Here are some weeklies - whether or not they count as real "raves" is 
debatable, but they were advertised by fliers and the music could be
good. If anyone can provide reviews of them, i.e., their 
appropriateness in being on the list, let me know....

Fridays - Mission Rock - DJ's James and Gavin (from Tweekin Records)
	& others.  Outside dance floor. In China basin at 17th and Illinois.
	Phone  415-241-8862  	Visuals by Synergy (hi Tony!)

        695-7887.  842 Valencia @ 19th St.

        [4/2 - Doc Martin, London's Paul Oakenfold]
        525 Harrison @ 1st, SF    415.543.1300

        "Hard hitting bass sounds radiating rightious (sic) vibes
         for your brain"

	400 south 1st street in San Jose - info: (408) 298-9796

CONNECTION 2 TAPES are still available from Bob Ramstad,
boccibob%groovy@us.oracle.com.  It's a 4-tape set, with music by
Moonpup, Scott Hardkiss, Jon Drukman, Lee, and Blurrrr - the tapes are
$20, plus $5 shipping (unless you pick it up in person) $5 of which
goes to the Malachy O'Brien trust fund.

I'm looking for a way to create the "DJ Transformer" effect using a midi
trigger and some off-the shelf hardware for my techno music compositions.
This effect is similar to that DJs achieve by rapidly flipping their input
toggle switch from phono to line and back...sort of a "chopper" effect.
I'd like to be able to sync it thru midi... I though of using a drum machine
and a noise gate in some combination...
anyone have any ideas?
Thanks
Chris (aka anode)

 ---- Included Message ----

 Received: 05-07-93 13:27                         Sent: 05-07-93 13:26 
 From: WRPYR:bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu
 To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu sfraves-calendar@soda.berkeley.edu

 X-Mailer:  Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)


 Hi gang!  Sorry in the delay, I was waiting for more flyers to come
 in but none did... hope this gets to everyone on time.

 Tonight is looking kinda dry, so I'd take it easy tonight and maybe
 hit Splash! in the morning.  I wonder if the pool will be open - bring
 your swimsuits just in case :)  Obsession could be cool tonight, but
 caveats abound about DV8 so who knoz.  And there's never been a post
 to the list about Mr. Baked Raindrop, so I can't tell ya what they're
 like, other than they must have decent production for the promoters to
 keep using that name for the past 6 months...

 BTW I *think* Mission Rock is happening, it's worth checking out too.

 That Straight-Up Funk deal looks QUITE good - and since the GG park
 party is STILL being negotiated (next weekend is the target date for
 getting it started - if you want to vent your anger about this call
 your friendly neighborhood GG Park permit office), this may be your
 only chance this weekend to hear music in the lovely spring weather...

 Saturday night:  Groove Kitchen and Where the Wild Things Are are
 both highly regarded events, with the younger crowd tending to go
 to WTWTA and the older crowd to GK.  I usually prefer the music at
 GK, but the lineup at WTWTA looks great too.

 And even though there won't be a sunday-in-the-park party this weekend
 (hell, I even got on the phone and started calling recreation departments
 to see about getting a site w/ sound permits and all - no luck) there
 will be a gathering of folx in Marx Meadows around 1 I guess, with 
 boomboxes and sunshine who could ask for anything more?

 Enjoy yourself :)

 Here are some weeklies - whether or not they count as real "raves" is 
 debatable, but they were advertised by fliers and the music could be
 good. If anyone can provide reviews of them, i.e., their 
 appropriateness in being on the list, let me know....

Subject: Re: DJ Transformer effect
To: clee@theporch.raider.net (Chris Lee)
Date: Fri, 7 May 93 18:04:56 PDT
Cc: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
In-Reply-To: <m0nrb6D-0009UPC@theporch.raider.net>; from "Chris Lee" at May 7, 93 5:41 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]

> This effect is similar to that DJs achieve by rapidly flipping their input
> toggle switch from phono to line and back...sort of a "chopper" effect.
> I'd like to be able to sync it thru midi... I though of using a drum machine
> and a noise gate in some combination...

I've done this using a drum machine and noise gate, a Symetrix SG200.
It's easy.  The noise gate has trigger inputs that open up the gates.
I use a drum sound, like a tom or something as the trigger, and use
a sequencer to control the drum pattern.  Because it's a two-channel
noise gate, I can create this effect in stereo, completely controlled
via MIDI.  Hope this helps.

Happy triggering,
-leg of eel

Hy D!
>
> what's banana??
> you mean smoking banana peels..
     Yep!!

> i always thought that was a flase myth..  it works?????

    It shure does. Here goes the recipe!

    1.- Take 10-12 normal bananas and peel 'em.
    2.- Take a knife and for each peal slice shred off the inner white fiber
that the peal has.
    3.- After doing this you have a bunch of white fibers which you have to put
in a pot with a little water added and heat this. When it starts to boil, drain
the liquid and keep heating this. Repeat the draining a couple of times (this
is just to take the liquid off the fiber... not to cook it!).
    4.- Then you will have a mass of brownish fibers which you spread on a
cookie tray *or somethin' like that) and put it on a preheated 200F oven. Put
the tray as far from the flame as posible... the idea is to accelerate the
drying process. Leave it there for about 15-20 min. then turn of the oven, and
leave it there for about an hour or so, so it finishes drying off.
    5.- Scrape it all off the cookie tray and enjoy!!!

    It's kinda mild (take a lot), but i guess you're gonna like it!

            Share and enjoy...
              |     MAX
              |
              |
              -------------> Feel free to repost it to the sfraves, since it's
                             always good to kinow there's still legal natural
                             stuff you can do (and in your own kitchen!!!).

To: sfraves@medisg1.Stanford.EDU
From: mcg@netcom.com (MykL G)
Subject: KQED raves?

Just saw a promo on KQED for what might be a really interesting
program, this Monday at 9 pm.  It's called "Dancing", and is an
in-depth look at the role of dancing in various societies around
the world (how society dictates how people dance, the function of
dance in everyday life, etc.)  They showed short clips of many
different types of dancing, (ballroom, African, Eastern European)
including about 1/2 second of some people at a rave!  Oddly, the
voice-over said "...to new-age rock'n'roll" over that shot... 

I hate to recommend people do anything to their TV aside from
killing it, but there's a chance this might be pretty good.
Sort of a "comparative religion" approach towards dancing.
Those with an eye for the "deeper meaning" of what we're doing
(Geoff, Robert J., etc.) should try to catch it.

----____----____--__--__--__--__-_-_-_-_-_-__--__--__--__--____----____----
        MykL G                Use your wings.        mcg@netcom.com
____----____----__--__--__--__--_-_-_-_-_-_--__--__--__--__----____----____

X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]

BLISSS!

OK, guys, this was the best rave ever in the history of ravekind!!!!
:):):)
The vibe was amazing!
So many good smiles and happy dancers
All the people that were there were dancing.
The whole thing started with Michael Joly who performed
an amazing ambient live set
The videoprojector was the best ever in the history of videokind!!!!!
Showing ORb`s Textures and Patterns... Absolutely AWESOME!!!
Most people missed that...
I`m sorry for them
:)
Donutz Spun great house
Then Laura spun an intelligent hard set
Lasers came on
One red and one green
OHHHH shit!!!!
Hope everybody enjoyed themselves (Why am I saying this?
I KNOW everybody was spacing out!!!!

HAtata
Urbo is the way to go!!
See you all at Frosted Rave!!!
We are again destined to create ravehistory
The world is transforming
And I`m spacing out
My question is QUEST
Hello

Chill, 
APPLEPIE


-- 
                            ol@chaos.cs.brandeis.edu

From ol@chaos.cs.brandeis.edu Sat May  8 16:30 EDT 1993
From: "Oz Lubling" <ol@chaos.cs.brandeis.edu>
Message-Id: <9305081939.AA07690@chaos.cs.brandeis.edu>
Subject: BLISSS! (Part II)
To: ne-raves@gnu.ai.mit.edu (NorthEast Rave List)
Date: Sat, 8 May 93 15:39:18 EDT
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]


Ok, since ApplePie did not want to write about himself, I have to!
Apple came on at 11:30 after laura..  He started the set with some
progressive house...  More people were flowing in by the minute..
By the stage, the ne-raves posse was flying high, dancing and grooving
to the sound...  The set progressed into some fucking awesome, chilled
out, urbo HARD TRANCE!!!  The best records known to man, were played
one after another in a progression leading all of us to heaven.  
I had an advantage over most people, because I recognized every 
track, and could not stop moving for 2 hours....  By 12:30, the
dance floor was packed with people... flying between the 
laser and enormous video screen... tranceformed by the fax sounzzz...
and then at 1:00 came my favorite part, the cybernetic BREAKCORE
EXPERIENCE....   All the way from Rabbit City to Frankfurt in 
30 minutes of intense breakbeats and extremely crazy, stoopid, PHAT,
fresh, and URBO mixing...(thanks arnold)....
For Christ sake, we even got the Brandeis people out of their fucking
chairs... They could not listen to this music while sitting down...

To sum up,  the vibe was awesome, the crowd was great, and thanx to
everyone who came: vanessa, tina, jesse, polida, mike, J P 3,
laura, darren, donato, john adams & sava, and the rest know
who you are....

hope to see you at QUEST,
oz
p.s. BLISSS! 2, coming soon....

-- 
                            ol@chaos.cs.brandeis.edu

     I would like to thank you all for the sympathy and the
referrals. It is good to have support in a situation like
this. I have decided that it would be best if I did not talk
about the details of what happened or comment on them in any
way until after the trial. My charge is not terribly serious
and I will not go to jail. It is more of a hassle than
anything. Never the less it is really easy to get depressed
in these circumstances and it is really nice to turn on the
computer and find so many kind words and so much help. Thank
you!
                         God love you,
                              Zephirus.

Subject: banana!!

		  Copied w/o permission from "Sex and Drugs"
			   by Robert Anton Wilson,
			      (c) 1973,1987,1988
				   (p.175)

BANANAS: The "electric banana" or "mellow yellow" fad of the late 1960s, in
which some people claimed to get high by smoking banana skins, is now
generally regarded as a hoax -- an attempt to make antidrug laws escalate into
total insanity by forcing the government to ban bananas. Actually, some banana
skins contain serotonin, a drug which is similar in structure to the
psychedelics, and might mutate while being burned. If so, this effect is
unpredictable and may depend on other factors (e.g., the ripeness of the
banana, or the temperature at burning, etc.) since the majority who tried this
experiment reported no result at all.

			      +++++++++++++++++
	...sorry to burst any bubbles. It seems to be a mainly placebo effect.
Supposed to taste really horrible, too, according to a former housemate of
mine who tried it years ago.

Pat

(from the calendar)

Fridays - Life @ the Sound Factory
        [4/2 - Doc Martin, London's Paul Oakenfold]
        525 Harrison @ 1st, SF    415.543.1300


Last Friday Gunther and Debbie (his S.O./girlfriend/she-Gunther/better
half/whatever) went to this and his one-line review was
"Danger...Danger Will Robinson".  They spent most of the time people
watching. 

Bad vibe, bad music, funny drunken stories...

Two highlights they mentioned were:
First this buff dude had his girlfriend sit and hold his drink while
he flashed his washboard belly at drunk club-women.  An argument
started when she no longer wished to do this.  Debbie was more than
slightly amused by this dude.

So then club-girlfriend splits and club-dude proceeds to dance.  High
Volume club-woman (nice way to say 'rotund') proceeds to 'dirty dance'
with dude, leaning back and grinding, then leaning farther back and so
on.  Unfortunately she had too much to drink, or extended herself
beyond her center of gravity, or both, as she proceded to fall on her
dirty dancing booty.

Our hero and heroine decided to leave at this point.

So, what _worthwhile_ has happened there lately?  Gun said it was nice on the
inside... 

-H-

oops...  in my haste, i left out a song.  here's my set again, with the
correction. i hope nobody went and labeled their sets in indelible ink. :)

6. Ddagger

Moonpup (17 min)

Lee (22 min)
  The Good Men			Give It Up (remix)
  Unomas			Escuchar
  Zeony Lee Experience		Love Energy
  Soul Sacrifice		Sacrifice Dub
  Paradise 3001			Beautification


7. Forall

Lee (45 min)
  Sublime			<white label--released before The Theme>
  Double FM			Sound of Amnesia (remix)
  La Camorra			Te Quiero
  Aquastep			Carousel (remix)
  Sound Clash Republic		Not For Sale
  Lion Rock			Lion Rock
  K&M				Funk and Drive
  African Juice			Love Me (uk dub mix)
  Original Rockers		Push Push (remix)
  Deja Vu			Never Knew the Devil


btw, "remix" here means not only that the song is a different version of
the original, but that it's on a different record as well.

lee

From: crunch@netcom.com (John Draper)

To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Subject: Raving on,  with the best of them...

Greetings fellow ravers...

  I survived yet another weekend of total rave mania.   Hit the Groove
kitchen first,   danced until it got shut down,   then moved over to
the Boogie Kitchen and raved some more.    I talked to a lot of people
to get an idea of how many have PC's and are on-line,   and I am
surprised at how many there are.    Most on Netcom,  lots from the
Universities,  and ALL are interested in keeping big brother out
of our faces.

  This was the first rave I have outlasted,  WITHOUT DRUGS!!   But
lots of coffee over at Boogie Kitchen.    GREAT PLACE!!  I recommend
it highly.

  Craig Larson is now back from the HUGE rave in the UK,  and was
showing the videos at Boogie Kitchen this morning.    I noticed the
Brits dance to faster music than we do,   is this a typical difference?

  Anyway,  (Yawn!!) I'm now in Zombie mode,   so gonna grab the last
batch of mail and shut down till next rave weekend.

  So,  how was the Wild Things rave up in Marin?   We were thinking of
making that one,   but since I already drove from Santa Cruz to groove
at the GK,   than I had to driva all the way back to drop Craig off,
then get back home to Fremont.   Returned by 6pm.    WOW!!  Whotta
All-nighter.....  I even skipped by health club workout,   after dancing
for more than 12 hours.... 

Rave on..

Crunch

Subject: straight up funk and beyond?
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu

        Leah Reich <diva@uclink.berkeley.edu>,
        Brian Behlendorf <bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu>
Message-Id: <Pine.3.05.9305092325.A21538-d100000@uclink.berkeley.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; CHARSET=US-ASCII


I went to "Straight Up Funk" last Sat. in Daly City, and what went on
there affected me enuf that I felt I had to post something about it
(although I've been on sfraves for a few weeks now, I've been content to
observe...until now).  If anyone else was there, I'd like to hear
your impressions of the party - here are mine (as briefly as I can :).

Although it was supposed to start at noon, lugging equipment by hand and
wheelbarrow down a cliff postponed things til about 3, and people starting
accumulating soon after.  From then until we left, around 7:30, I had a
great time (I'm basically convinced house music can be appreciated much
better out in the sun than some smoke-filled crowded "house" :).  But just
as we were getting ready to scale the cliff, we noticed a guy up on the
hillside with his pants around his ankles, grabbing his crotch and yelling
something like, "come and get it, bitch," to someone below.  This was
fairly disturbing, but we then noticed one of his friends (I think)
attacking another guy, punching him in the face and siccing his dog on him
until a woman stepped in and managed to stop him.  I don't remember seeing
any of these guys around until this happened, and it seemed pretty clear
to me they were starting something just for the sake of starting it.

Before I say anything about this incident, there's a 2nd part to add: we
came back around midnight, and to be blunt, someone accosted (I won't
presume his intentions) one of our female friends when she went to the
bathroom in the bushes.  She was able to run back to the party unharmed,
but how she will deal with what happened, and what this implies for the
well-being of the scene are hardly trivial matters.

I think I have some idea now what people mean about becoming _truly_ concerned
about an issue when it affects you directly - hearing about shootings and
fights and sexual harassment (or maybe this sounds more familiar: "He
was high, he wasn't thinking straight," or "He didn't _mean_ anything by it!"
or "What's the problem, the girl can always say no!") at raves is
worrisome and frightening, but you're can't really understand it til you
or someone close experiences it.

Both of the incidents I described were first-time occurrences for me, and
for them to happen at what had promised to be a trouble-free, enjoyable
event for all is pretty ironic, I guess.  I feel safe in assuming the guys
at fault here are more than just "outsiders" to the rave scene.  I hate to
make that insider/outsider distinction, but by outsiders I just mean people
whose motives for raving are, say, less than positive, caring,
respectful, etc., people who don't know why the scene began and what it
means to people that truly support it, people who cause stuff like this to
happen.  The question to me is then, do we try to "educate" such people,
maybe by setting some sort of positive example?  By the way those guys
acted, I would tend to say no, better to strengthen the existing "rave
population" before we try to draw in the masses (or "untuned," as the
Merry Pranksters would put it :). 

How to strengthen the scene, then?  (I hope I don't sound utterly
omniscient and dictatorial here, I don't mean to be, and if I'm missing
the point in any way, clue me in)  Once again, I don't believe the scene
should be based around exlusivity, but I feel that when promoting anything (50
people on a beach or 5,000 in a warehouse), _some_ distinction should be
made between people who will boost the party vibe and those who won't. 
Obviously, you can't do this club-style ("What's that, a flannel shirt? 
Sorry, don't think so."), but hopefully by how you promote your event and
what sort of party you throw.  This idea leads to a powerful argument for
smaller, "community"-type events - look what happened at Toon Town New
Years 1991: 7,000+ people, alcohol served, of course there'll be fights.  

I don't think I have any particular point here, and I'm sure this talk is
nothing new to a lot of you, but I do feel that as the "rave" scene
(buzzword alert!) as it is progressing (good argument for regressing too,
though :) right now is not going to do anything but bloat and be further
co-opted by mainstream culture (well on its way already).  I guess my
point is that to stop that from happening, or to provide an alternative to
that, we have to start thinking in new terms about what "raving" means,
what a "rave" can or cannot be, and what direction we want to take this
thing we've created (sounds like a _really_ bad sci-fi movie to me :).  To
do this means maybe we can't recreate the scene circa 1991/2, or that
we can't and shouldn't try to "clean up" the massive events to please us. 
Maybe it means our definition of "rave" should change.  The early SF
undergrounds provide a lot of good examples of how the scene can remain
pure and positive - why not use them as examples, but take the party
further, higher?

With that in mind, some friends and I formed the Mother Earth Sound System
around late February, and threw our first outdoor party at the Berkeley
Marina in early March.  We're trying to explore some of the possibilities
opened up by the FMRs, the DIY ethic, and the wonders of Mother Nature. 
What better way to keep spirituality and love in the scene than to put
people in a beautiful location with good music?  (Personally, I'll take
the rain, wind, mushy dancing, and sticky oranges of C2 over the usual $20
laser-fest any day :)  

Size isn't really the issue, though.  The last FMR w/ 400 (?) people
proves that (wish I'd been there).  We're small right now cuz we're
spreading our message the hard way: "we're having a party, tell a friend" 
At least this way we've got a pretty good idea of what kind of party we'll
have.  No voice-mail or 4-color flyers, thanks but no thanks.

Anyway, if you've been faithful enough (or maybe masochistic enuf) to get
this far, you'll might be interested to know that we've got gatherings
scheduled (hopefully) for late May and (definitely) for summer.  We'll
keep you all posted, but in the mean time, if you're interested in helping
us in ANY WAY, please get in touch with us.  We can use anything,
especially a generator at this point (we have sound system and DJs, but
people that can "do stuff" are welcome (I dislike the audience-performer
separation)).

Feel free to email me (or via sfraves to allow public discussion) or call
me at 510.549.6253.

OK, you've suffered enough.

peace,

			   s  c  o  t  t  i  e

			MOTHER EARTH SOUND SYSTEM   

 			>>>respect your mother<<<

really impressed, and that's unfortunate if they have stopped that as
well.  106.1 also played techno Friday nights past midnight, but they
interrupted the music a lot and that was pretty frustrating.

In-Reply-To: <Pine.3.05.9305092325.A21538-d100000@uclink.berkeley.edu>; from "Scott Everett Swiger" at May 9, 93 11:05 pm

Hello Scottie -

 My sympathies for your efforts! Also - I wouldn't mind attending one of
your "parties" in the near future ; it sounds like you have the right
attitude!


[ And, to SFRaves in general ] 

 Re: Negative antisocial/antipersonel behaviour at raves : I've been  
thinking recently that a "membership-only" setup with ID tags ( like a
convention ) might discourage random interloping troublemakers , empower
the promoter to enforce "membership behaviour guidelines" ( for 
example , 'members will refrain from harassing others ', 'members will 
refrain from fighting at club events' ), and concentrate the kind and 
sincere ravers together at special members/guests only raves.

 Tables could be set up at raves , and a potential ClubRave (tm) :-) 
member could get an application card . She gets the card stamped every
time she goes to a rave that has a ClubRave table - when she gets some
magic number of stamps ( 4, 5 ? ), she qualifies for a full membership.
To join full-up , and application with ID check would be completed ,
for the ClubRave files.

 A ClubRave member would get ClubRave event info via phone tree or snailmail
or email. S/he would be allowed to bring guests. ClubRave members would 
pool their $$ together to hold events. I don't see why a member couldn't 
be younger than 18/21 . 

 The issue of selling "single event memberships" ( which would legally
be tickets by any other name , methinks ) would have to be resolved. It
may put ClubRave events into a different legal/permit zone than a purely
members/guests only event.

 What do you guys think??? It's already obvious to me that it's an 
abusable idea , but that would depend on the implementation and the
implementors.   

				Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com
 
--

scene, bringing raves to a popular club where pretensious people normally go. 
Pretensious clubbers still go to alcohol induced raves but at least they had to
make an effort.

other way around its already happening.  

I went to the "Attitude Factory" last Friday with some friends and saw alot of
familiar faces, too bad I didnt see Gunther.  My feelings were the same as his.
It is gross.  However it is a really cool place with the different rooms the
absolute best computer graphics I have ever seen!  and great lasers and lights.
 The people were gross.  

I personally feel very betrayed and dissapointed with Wicked on this move. 
Hell why not continue to have it at King St. and limit the people that can go
in.  I know the place is small and have always made an effort to get there
early.  Now that it is at "DEATH" ( a more appropriate name than Life).  


Whats the situation on the King Street garage anyways, maybe somebody else can
take over thowing raves at that space.  I really liked the space I think it has
alot to do with making the parties fun because it was such a small hot place.

In-Reply-To: Larry Ching's message of Mon, 10 May 93 6:56:03 PDT <9305101356.AA06097@netcom.netcom.com>
Subject: Re: ClubRave(tm)



  Larry>  Re: Negative antisocial/antipersonel behaviour at raves :
  Larry> I've been thinking recently that a "membership-only" setup
  Larry> with ID tags ( like a convention ) might discourage random
  Larry> interloping troublemakers

There's a "members dance club" which I sometimes see adverts for here
which operates a membership policy, presumably precisely for the
purpose of discouraging random interloping troublemakers.  I've never
been there, so I don't know how effective it is.  The way they seem to
work it is that they won't admit anyone to any of their events unless
you show them your membership card at the door.  Membership is open to
anyone, is completely free, and I think lasts for life _but_ there's a
24 hour lag between applying for membership and being issued with a
card.  Seems like quite a neat idea...


[Just a bit of context: here in the UK, we have the problem of our
rather arcane alcohol licensing laws.  Pubs are only licensed till
11pm, so around 11.30pm you get hoards of pissheads streaming out of
the pubs, and potentially causing trouble.  In addition, because
nightclubs are generally licensed till 2am (or later), you get an
element who just go along to a nightclub to find somewhere to carry on
drinking -- despite the exhorbitant bar prices.  This is perhaps at
least part of the reason why nightclubs often have dress codes -- it
means you have to decide in advance that you're going to go out
clubbing, rather than just going in on a whim...]


Rave on,

   Cosmic Roy

many of the "old school" don't go anymore.  Why?  I dunno, everything from

been a bit on the drunken side with fights happening more and more often.
This last time there were just TOO many people.  WIcked ALWAYS packs them in
but at some point there is a thing called overcrowding which is VERY uncool
and unsafe.  The fire marshall called the last one off.  I think that WICKED
should try to find a space that can accomodate their crowd.  Unfortunately
there aren't that many spaces in SF that can do so without alienating some
of their supporters.  Between a rock and a hard place.

	id AA08918; Mon, 10 May 1993 09:51:39 -0700
Date: Mon, 10 May 1993 09:51:39 -0700
From: Ethan Isaac Miller <nrg@well.sf.ca.us>
Message-Id: <199305101651.AA08918@well.sf.ca.us>
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Subject: Sunday Night Tilt-a-Whirl

Howdy gang, well Tilt-a-Whirl not only had a Sunday morning gig yesterday,
but also a Sunday night gig; whether or not this will be regular thing
remains to be see. However, I hope it will be as it is showing a lot of
promise; what it needs right now is more people; and they would be wise to
come as thee is good time to be had there.

New to Tilt-a-Whirl is a much improved sound system run by a cool guy named
bob, who, I am told also provided the same system for the recent FMR. He's
got two Crown 1200 wpc amps that power the mid range and high end cabinets
and one Crown 2400 wpc amp that drives his bass cabinets. he said he's
rebulit the crossovers and gates...Anyway sounds friggin great. Loud as shit
too... first time I went home with my ears ringing in a while.

On the music side, very interesting: Surge started it off adn laid down a
solid set. Next a surprise appearance by Chicago's Mark Farina was a real
treat; he's a really nice guy. Dutch showed up and also another dj I was
unfamilar with. The three of them proceeded do spin a 2-hour tag team set
that ended up really covering a lot of ground. interesting dynamic having
one dj throw out a couple tunes, have the next repsond to these and so on,
great variety. Following this, Goa Gill comes on, unplugs the turntables and
proceeds to spin :) ??? a set of fast Real Hard Shit, heacy percussive,
trancy 150bpm+ stuff  on two Sony DATmans. No pitch control so he's matching
beats in his head; a few awkward transitions but all in all a heavy sound
that got people moving in a hurry; totally different sound than I'm used to
hearing in sf. For $5 Tilt-a-Whirl continues to be a great value as Mark
(the promoter) keeps pulling great djs out of the hat. Now if more people
would start going it could eally get great...

Too, God was doing some live Video Toaster stuff which at times was really
killer.

Enjoyed seeing MykL and Neils there Hi guys :)...

peace, and let the good times rave!
nrg

I don't think 107.7 does it anymore and 106.1 is on Friday and I think 
Saturday nights from 12:00 - 3:00 a.m. (After the Kink Tec Wake Up Show - 
Best hip-hop show in the area, IMO).  106.1 isn't as good as it used to
be.  You used to be able to switch back and forth from 106.1 to 107.7 and
back again as the music got slow or repetetive and it was great.  106.1 is
(Oh, I just noticed I spelled King in King Tec wrong, that's king, not kink)
more house now and tends not to be as good as it used to be, not because of
that but it just isn't as good.  Dj EFX is on a lot (every time?) and so
is Pete Avila with occasional guest djs.
