you know i was thinking the other day
and it was really obnoxious and tiresome

but i came up with a kind of neat idea
a friend of mine goes and hangs out with cops on campus a lot
he goes on ride alongs and talks to them
when we through a dance type thing on campus
he asked them if it was okay and they said sure
when they stop by he is there, they recognize him
and dont really hassle us
and he really helped out the time they did get a little miffed
and threatened to arrest me

soo... it occurs to me
why dont we start going on ride alongs with cops
get to know them, hang out with them, whatever

two things get accomplished
1) you understand them better
2) they understand you better

so you know most of the cops in a certain area
they come to bust a rave that youre at/helping put on
and you say 'hey bob, howsit goin?'
'pretty good.. whats going on here?'
'me and my friends are just throwing a party..
nothing much going on.. just playing some music
some dancing and what not.. just hanging out. you know'
'thats cool.. im just gonna look around and make sure its safe'
'okay'
<look look> 'seems okay.. have fun!   you gonna be by the station this week?'
'dunno.. its finals week.. maybe next week'
'okay see ya round'

Received: by hac2arpa.hac.com (4.1/SMI-DDN)
	id AA27376; Mon, 10 May 93 12:48:29 PDT
Date: Mon, 10 May 93 12:48:29 PDT
From: PLUI@iossvr.gm.hac.com
Message-Id: <9305101948.AA27376@hac2arpa.hac.com>
Received: by DniMail (v1.0); Mon May 10 12:48:17 1993 PDT
To: hac2gm..arpa.."sfraves@medisg1.Stanford.EDU"@hac2arpa.hac.com
Subject: 808/MBM/SupremeLoveGods 

Sey, 808, MBM, and Supreme Love Gods played in Vancouver last night...

Supreme Love Gods started at 8:00. There was a crowd spanning the front of 
the stage about 5 bodies deep. People were mostly watchin' and the other 
9/10ths of the dance floor was empty. They played for 45 miniutes. It was early
and I 'spose people weren't into the heavy guitar sounds (?)

The floor had been filling up during the intermission, a dj in the balcony 
was playin some very good music. The crowd was a mix of ravers, motorcycle
jackets, and the usual club faces. By 9:15, the crowd at the Commodore Ballroom 
had grown to about 1600 (capacity, I think) and MBM started their set. 

It was very loud.

Since the dancefloor was packed, I moved off to the side of the stage, by the
bass bins :) There was more room to dance and the carpet was a little easier 
on my feet.   It was very loud :)  The floor was bouncing for the hour and 15 
that MBM played (no one was diving into the crowd, but I did notice a tall 
skinnyish guy being passed around over people's heads).

Again, another intermission. This time the dj played a more jazzy interlude
with Ramsey Lewis (?) samples, and a track that sounded a bit like the theme
from the Jetsons. The house lights came up for a bit and it was nice to see
the large crowd full of smiling faces.

808 came on at 11:00 with a kewl Alsa Spracht Zaratustra (sp?) and laser intro.
The lasers and intellibeams hadn't been used so far, so it most thoroughly
tripped me out.  20 minutes into the set, they played some older acid. There
were 2 people being passed around over people's heads now. 

It was very very very loud.

Close to the end of the show, I was dancing away, happy as a bird, a few feet
from the speakers, with my back to them, facing the crowd. My hair was standing.
Just as I turned to face the stage, I caught a glimpse of one of the big 2x15
bins vibrate itself forward and off the platform it (and the rest of the 
speakers) was placed on. As it came crashing down on me (still blaring), I 
caught it, and was suddenly reminded of a scene in The 10 Commandments.
The speakers were arranged in a 3 on top of 3 pattern. The one I was holding
was the bottom middle speaker. My attention shifted from the one blaring in 
my lap, to the others directly above me that were inching forward and downward.
I managed upright the speaker and reach over it (still blaring) to try and 
hold back the rest of the PA. By this time a bouncer or security guy noticed 
me messin with the PA and decided to find out what the hell I thought I was 
doing. He noticed my predicament and the day was saved. 

I continued dancing to the very very loud music until the show ended at 12:20

I picked up my kid sister (bar shift ending) and we went to the after party. 
My ears were ringing (still are) so we didnt stay. Fun night altogheter, but
I was bummed that the ticket price had gone from $18 to $25 the day of the show.
A smallish price to pay for such excitement, tho.
                                ____
                               |   /|            __
Patrick Lui   aka cato         |  { | BOOM      / '>  tweet!
plui@iossvr.gm.hac.com         |   \|   BOOM   /\ /\

Subject: Re: ClubRave(tm)

>  Tables could be set up at raves , and a potential ClubRave (tm) :-) 
> member could get an application card . She gets the card stamped every
> time she goes to a rave that has a ClubRave table - when she gets some
> magic number of stamps ( 4, 5 ? ), she qualifies for a full membership.
> To join full-up , and application with ID check would be completed ,
> for the ClubRave files.

>  The issue of selling "single event memberships" ( which would legally
> be tickets by any other name , methinks ) would have to be resolved. It
> may put ClubRave events into a different legal/permit zone than a purely
> members/guests only event.
> 
>  What do you guys think??? It's already obvious to me that it's an 
> abusable idea , but that would depend on the implementation and the
> implementors.   
> 
> 				Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

Well my first reaction was NO WAY, this is NOT what raving is about!
But then after I thought about it, there are zillions of parties out there,
I/we can still go to/throw free parties and the like and there is nothing
stopping the doorman from letting people in who are not full members.

This might be a good way to have members only parties where you know that jerks
CANT come in.  I for one am more interested in going to primarily outdoor
clandestine events these days and you can't really limit access to this type of
event.

Stewart, Scott* says:
> Hell why not continue to have it at King St. and limit the people that can go
> in.  I know the place is small and have always made an effort to get there
> early.  

Except for the people who get stuck in line bumming... Or the people who
walk out for a breath of fresh air and can't get back in because they've
already let too many people in... Or when the fire marshall shows up and
sends everybody home...

It seems like Wicked is becoming synonymous with this type of scene which
is (IMHO) counter-rave.  Why?  --  Why not just put Wicked to rest and start
up something else?  What's in a name?  Take it back underground.  The music 
is always brilliant.  The core community will find it and spread the word.
Or have we forgotten already?

Well I'm not overly chummy but I do try to talk to them as much as possible,
answer their questions and basically provide a familiar face.
I know the Santa Cruz cops recognize me, which is a good thing.
I'm not sure if I want the SF police to know me by sight, but Dana
I think your right, I don't know about going on rides with then or offering
them water from your bottle or a hit off your balloon :) but It does pay
to stop and talk to them a little and make them feel as if they are humans
some cops NEED this type of reminder so that they don't go off.  Others
just find it plesant and become easier to deal with.  Some folks ask me
why I talk to cops at raves and I tell them that they can't bust anybody
while their busy talking to me!

Sorry this is so late but I've been away from the computers for a bit.


The greatest ever!!!

	I must second Brian in his comments about the event...this was
the best event I have ever been to.  My mind has been reawakened to 
the incredible aspects of raving!!! The people were incredible, the vibe
was incredible.

	Truly it was "religious."  With the 400 or so people, a killer 
system with great dj's spinnin their hearts out, and the best location 
along with the marina. :)  It was incredibly beautiful watching the lights
across the bay dissapear as the sun came up...the whole sky turned red...

	Anyway I drove all the way from Davis by myself (since I wasn't
returning till today) to get there at around 2 am.  Many cars where comin
in still and I just roamed about listening to the car stereos blastin away.

	Thought I met Brian (was that you in the funky black and white hat) but
he was busy parkin cars...so I just hung out till about 3:45 when the 
system  fired to a screaming crowd...the vibe grew instantly even with
a few problems in the dj's department (a couple bad transitions etc.)
	
	I danced away till the morning broke when I had to take a rest...
everytime I moved away to the benches or the stone outcropping I 
couldn't keep my head from bobbing then my body writhing to the beat!!!
It was great!
	Though I kept to myself and didn't meet anyone else :( I had a 
killer time but I wish I had met all the sfravers present...I was the
ordinary looking guy with glasses and a white hat with the "G" on the
front.  I felt pretty out of place with all the nice but strange lookin
peoples...   
	
	I always thought those PG&E commercials were stupid till I 
saw a couple of ravers climbin the electrical towers over the marshes...

	I had to wonder what all the old fart joggers thought as they 
looked across the baylands to see several hundred people dancin away
to some kickin loud toons...   =)

	Overall it was the best I've been to and can't wait for the 
next!!!

By the way what was the dj linup???

Later all,

Gioni


						
G  
of the Pasquinelli Clan              What doesn't kill you makes you stronger
gdpasquinelli@ucdavis.edu 
Late...

It's really hard to say which way it's heading.  I was a clubber-type
until some friends brought me to a Wicked, a couple of Groove Kitchens,
and some tapes to listen to.  Finding alt.rave wasn't a problem, Brian
introduced me to sfraves, and every-now-and then I get on vrave and spend
a few minutes chatting with people I have never met.  One of these days
I'm going to hit an FMR, and so on and so forth.

I must admit, most people won't have net access, but I do try and bring
some friends into the scene to show them what I like to do and what I
don't like about the atmosphere around DV8, OZ, and other dumps like
that.  Sometimes it backfires;  hell, I tried, and I won't try it with
them again.
>

'tuders will be?  Sound Factory has the best sound system and the
lighting is not bad either (I *really* wish they wouldn't shine those 
lasers at people; It's *dangerous*).  It does get a little warm and damp,
especially when the fogs roll through, imho prime location for a Wicked.
Let's show the clubbers what a party is really all about.  Hell, I'll 
even bring shitloads of lollypops and hand them out to the worst looking
of them all %)

	Actually, I believe (I'm almost sure) that it's against the law
to use lasers this way.  I've never been someplace that did this, but 
performance lasers are NOT supposed to touch anyone.  I learned about this
in the context of some story about how concert producers wanted to get
this rule changed because they don't think it's dangerous.

away and don't stand there in a haze trying to see how intense the visuals
get.  Reminds me of all those stupid stories about staring into the sun
til you go blind 8*)

	id AA18968; Mon, 10 May 1993 20:17:35 -0700

Message-Id: <199305110317.AA18968@well.sf.ca.us>
Subject: Re: LASER HAZARDS
To: sfraves@medisg1.Stanford.EDU
Date: Mon, 10 May 93 20:17:34 PDT
In-Reply-To: <9305110255.AA15688@chief>; from "Richard Langston x247" at May 10, 93 7:55 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3test PL45]

Actually, lasers ARE/CAN BE quite hazardous to people's eyes.  I work for a
company that manufactures visible laser scanners to scan barcodes.  Federal
regulations require us to provide a "laser hazard" sticker on *everything*
that has a laser in it, even though the things are quite weak by most
standards.  We are also required to put a watchdog timer in each unit which
will guarantee that the laser can be on for no more than 2 seconds.  This is
to prevent any possible long term harm should someone accidentally activate
the laser while pointing it in the direction of their eyes.  (By the way, I
should say that we're happy to comply with the regulations because they do
represent good safety precautions.)

I have worked with the scanners, and had them come on in my face--i can tell
you all from personal experience that i don't recommend it for anyone.  i
had a temporary blind spot once for a couple of hours.  also, i have "felt"
the imprint of the scanner on my skin for quite some time after my skin was
exposed to it for bits of time (just had to try it on myself to see the
pretty colors (!)).

i'm quite concerned that an industrial power laser is flying around at
people level in a club--seems like an opportunity for unpleasantness
waiting in the wings.  I second the recommendation to the club--keep the
laser out of the crowd, please.

BryceR
TAZ mobile1
"You fill me full of X-stacy!"

--------------------------- Message Contents------------------------------
Sometimes when were at a
difficult time in our lives,
we don't reach out for help
Maybe its because we are proud,
Maybe we think we'd be bothering
someone with our troubles.
Perhaps were embarrassed,
or we might think that whats
troubling us has never
bothered anyone else before
and we are afraid to
show our tears, our feelings
If any of these thoughts are true
for you, You can reach out to me.
I don't know what I can do to help, but
I can listen, and understand,
and Love you know matter what.
I can remind you what a special
person/wiseman you are B
And how much you have to offer so many.  I'd
like to put my arms around you and
hug you and let you know how much
I do care and I'm here for you,
If you need me now and Forever.

-----------------------------------------------------

Always Remember, you cannot abandon what you do not know
To go beyond yourself, you must know yourself.
The real voyage of discovery consists not in seeking
new landscapes but in having new eyes.
Please grant me weak eyes for things that our of
account and strong eyes for all thy truth:
We walk by faith and not by sight.
In all cases the respect you show yourself and other
Lifeforms determines how you the Planetary family.
If you allow others to be destructive in your Sacred
space, on some level you don't have the guts to be
disliked. It is not important to be liked by others,
but it is important to be able to live with yourself.
   HAPPINESS BEGINS WITHIN

As long as the laser is being scanned into a sheet or cone of light,
or is drawing a pattern or some sort, then it's perfectly safe.  If
it's a diverging beam, it's safe, too.

If, however, it produces one (or a few) small bright spots, say half a
centimeter across, then they shouldn't be shining it into the crowd.

	Cosmic Roy

> 

  Richard> 	Actually, I believe (I'm almost sure) that it's
  Richard> against the law to use lasers this way.  I've never been
  Richard> someplace that did this, but performance lasers are NOT
  Richard> supposed to touch anyone.  I learned about this in the
  Richard> context of some story about how concert producers wanted to
  Richard> get this rule changed because they don't think it's
  Richard> dangerous.

As long as the laser is scanning, it should be safe to point into a
crowd, and it's a cool effect to have a sheet of light or cone of
light sweeping across the dancefloor.  The reason there are
restrictions (in the UK) on doing this is that if the scanning
mechanism were to fail, then it _would_ be dangerous.  But did you
know that in the UK there are restrictions on using strobes for more
than two minutes at a time....?  

Actaully, I'd be interested in a description of exactly what these
lasers do when they're scanning the crowd.....

    Rave on,

	Cosmic Roy

Hi,

This last weekend after "The Brand X Juggler /  BLISSS" I asked dj  
Thirteen about her favorite record store.  She said "PLANET X IN NEW  
BRUNSWICK, NEW JERSEY".  If you read her review about Rave En Colour  
that Francois Dion hosted in Mntreal, she said that most people  
drooled over the records she and Ed were spinning--which came from  
*guess where*.

I had to try Planet X, so I looked up the number.  Called and asked  
for Spike.  He spent about 20 minutes with me chatting about records,  
scenes, and dj's.  He tried to guess what I would like given a few  
titles I gave him.  Now he's putting together a package for me that I  
should have by the end of the week!  Too, he said if I sent a tape  
with snatches of music I liked, he'd build from that.  Talk about  
service.  I'm learning about the scene, but I definitely get the  
feeling this guy is going to be a big asset in this part of my life.   
This guy is not running a shop to stroke his ego.

If you do end up calling him, be sure to mention the net.  He's not  
on the air yet, and he think its cool how the thread travels.

Thank you very much Laura, Ed and Eileen for making "Juggler /  
BLISSS" a cool event and for recommending Planet X.  


Brendan

From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Message-Id: <9305111720.AA03794@pilot.njin.net>
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Subject: Re: LASER HAZARDS
In-Reply-To: <27611.9305111252@wundt.harlqn.co.uk>
References: <27611.9305111252@wundt.harlqn.co.uk>
	<9305110255.AA15688@chief>

At "Where the Wild Things Are" they had a 5 watt Co2 laser firing
directly into the crowd, sometimes as a straight line. I thought this
was *really* unsafe, so I took a closer look. I found that the
straight line wasn't really straight, that it diverged to about 5
inches in diameter by the time it reached the back of the (large)
room. The reason it diverged was that the apparent beam wasn't really
a beam at all. Even when the beam appeared stationary, it was actually
being scanned in a very small pattern. Perhaps this explained why
people weren't going blind.

I predict:

1. Something will go wrong. Either due to stupidity, equipment
   failure, or participant stupidity, someone's going to get a
   serious dose in the eye, perhaps damaging a significant part of
   their retina or optic nerve. I consider this quite likely given the
   wattage involved and the "homebrew" nature of the laser shows.

2. A lawsuit will ensue, probably from the parents of the now
   partially blind participant. This suit will hit the promoters of
   the event and any deep pockets possible, especially if it was a
   "legitimate" site. A criminal suit may follow as well, if there are
   regulations on laser use and those were broken.

3. The "fallout" phase. Expect extra media attention. The cops may
   make it a point to hassle us. Legitimate sites may refuse to let us
   run events there. Forget ever seeing a laser at a rave again.
   Perhaps expect more stiff enforcement of age limits.

Okay, even if there's no lawsuit or fallout, it would be awful to
have someone's sight damaged by a laser. That's not what we're about,
right?

So maybe we could speak to organizers and voice our concerns. 
Let them know that there's an unsafe situation, and that you want
everyone to have a good time. All it would take I think would be to
not allow lasers to fire directly into the crowd.

Sean

From: bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu (Brian Behlendorf)
Date: Tue, 11 May 1993 10:47:21 -0700

To: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey), sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Subject: Re: LASER HAZARDS

It was explained to me once that laser regulations fall under the same
headings as hazardous materials regulations, and that if one gets cited
for directing a laser beam towards people (even a _reflection_ of that
laser beam) the laser operator and/or the promoter of the event could be
responsible for up to $100,000 in fines (even more than if they had
dumped a couple gallons of toxic waste on the dance floor - now THAT would
be interesting!)

	Brian

From: don@vestek.com (Don Labutay)
Message-Id: <9305111853.AA06825@vestek.com>
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu

Speaking of hazardous lasers, here's a discussion I got from the
sci.electronics newsgroup:

----------- begin      
From: wellison@kuhub.cc.ukans.edu
Subject: Re: laser shows - legal ?
>A few years ago there was a standing debate regarding the legality of
>laser light shows because of their potential harm, as well as for
>the potential danger to airliner crew and passengers.  Are laser light
>shows legal ? Indoors ? Outdoors with 3 W argon lasers projected to
>the sky ?

All laser light shows in the U.S. are controlled by regulations set forth by
the FDA's Center for Devices and Radiological Health Department (CDRH) under
regulations 21 CFR 1040.10 and 1040.11 (legally of course ;-). Lasers with
power levels below 5 milliwatts (Class II and Class IIIa) do not require a
varience, which is a long and complicated form that must be submitted to the FDA
for approval on a yearly or bi-yearly basis. Any laser above 5 milliwatts
require a varience (Class IIIb and Class IV lasers). All laser light shows for
public viewing must has a shutter to block the beam should it stop scanning for
whatever reason. All laser light shows above Class II must have a key switch
interlock to prevent someone from turning it on.

The low power (<5 milliwatts) is what most night clubs use as they don't
require a varience, but I have seen argon lasers (much >5 milliwatts) in night
clubs. These are illegal in an enclosed space where the beam might strike a
person (yeah, I've seen them scan the audience with them as well, glad I'm not
thier insurance company ;-)

Outside laser shows use multi-watt lasers (Class IV) to get the effect. The FAA
must be notified as to the location of the laser and the direction in which the
laser beam will scan. If you hit a plane with a high powered laser, you are
responsible for the aftermath. These shows are run by trained laserist and
technicians and they are VERY careful as to where they point the laser. 

The laser shows that I build as a hobby are mainly in the <5 milliwatt range. I
have build some in the 2 watt range in which I had to go through the varience
paperwork with, but those I run and am responsible for. The little one's I sell
for permanent installation or for a D.J.'s use. Whoever buys one of my shows
signs an agreement that I am NOT responsible for their actions as I have no
control over it. I sell the larger ones only to experienced persons who have
used laser shows before and are aware of the dangers. Laser shows are neat, but
stricly controlled by the goverment. In Europe though, they don't have a CDRH
regulation to follow, so its pretty much open game.

-----------------------
From: jeh@cmkrnl.com
Subject: Re: laser shows - legal ?

In article <1993May4.100320.49786@kuhub.cc.ukans.edu>,
 wellison@kuhub.cc.ukans.edu writes:
>Lasers with
>power levels below 5 milliwatts (Class II and Class IIIa) do not require a
>varience,which is a long and complicated form that must be submitted to the FDA
>for approval on a yearly or bi-yearly basis. Any laser above 5 milliwatts
>require a varience (Class IIIb and Class IV lasers). 

I think it is pretty amusing that these folks came up with power limits that
completely ignore wavelength.  

If the primary concern is for eye damage (a real concern at high power levels
and close range), the shorter wave lengths are FAR more dangerous.  The retina
reflects a fair amount of red light but wavelengths of "argon green" and 
down are absorbed almost completely.  

This is not to say that the regs aren't necessary, but if they are going to
have regs at all they should have some grounding in fact.  

---------------------------
From: zlau@arrl.org (Zack Lau)
Subject: Re: laser shows - legal ?

Actually, the ANSI standards that cover lasers are wavelength dependent.
ANSI Z136.1 has a range of .4 to 200 microwatts for class 1 visible
and Near Infrared lasers, for example.

If you want to buy the a copy of the ANSI standard, 
you can call the American National Standards Institute
at 212-642-4900 in New York. 

If I recall correctly, a complete library of their standards
runs over $50,000. 

As I understand it, the FAA, the FCC, the Bureau of Radiation Health,
state and local governments can all regulate lasers, in the USA.  In
addition, the property owner may have a say.  The world record amateur
radio operator laser contact (248 km or 155 miles) had to deal with
the issue of bats (flying mammals) possibly being blinded.  Planes were
supposedly a non-problem--photomultiplier tubes used as receivers
no difficulty locating aircraft at night.

-------  end

da watcher

From: gwh@lurnix.com


>As long as the laser is scanning, it should be safe to point into a
>crowd, [...]

It depends.  Laser pointers are low-enough power that you have to
stare at them for ten minutes to get any permanent damage.
Many industrial lasers will do permanent damage if you get
a good look into the beam even if it just scans past.

Lasers more powerful than a laser pointer should NEVER be pointed
at a crowd for any reason.  3 milliwatts is the absolute limit
for safe use like that.

-george

Just out of curiosity I called the Exploratorium to find out what the
rates were and availability, etc. and here's what I found out.

It's available any week night except wed.
We can bring a sound system, she mentioned bands playing there but
we'd have to make sure it's on a night that nothing is happening at
the theater next door.
There is a $1,000 deposit.
It would cost $4,200 for about 500 people.
It is only available from 6 p.m. - 12 a.m.

Great idea for a rave spot but the price and time slot barely don't
cut it IMO.  We could possibly hold one there on a Friday night so
that we could all go to other events from there but we'd have to
charge $12-$15 to be able to cover costs.  We'd probably have to sell
tickets in advance because I don't know how they feel about us renting
it and then charging an admission to the public.  We'd have to make it
like our "computer users group" has to "take up a collection" because
we can't afford the fee from our "budget".  Anyway, just an idea to
toss around.

-Mark

From SFRaves-request@medisg1.Stanford.EDU  Tue May 11 20:51:12 1993

	id AA28280; Tue, 11 May 93 20:41:57 -0700
Received: from netcom3.netcom.com by netcom.netcom.com (5.65/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id AA25395; Tue, 11 May 93 20:45:22 -0700
Message-Id: <9305120345.AA25395@netcom.netcom.com>
Date: Tue, 11 May 1993 20:44:31 -0800
To: "Stewart, Scott*" <stewart#m#_scott*@msgate.corp.apple.com>
From: rth@netcom.com (Robert Hughes)
Subject: Re: LASER HAZARDS
Cc: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu


There's a Federal standard that sets a limit for wattage/cm and duration at
certain
wavelengths, so a Krypton beam at a certain spread and wattage can fall on
the eye for only so long, but a weaker beam can hit the eye longer, and
vise-versa. Last show I worked had about 6 tubes, mixed Krypton and Argon,
but the company running them would not let any beams strike the audience,
but the beams were hitting some of the crew and as long as it was a swiftly
moving beam, it was OK as they had calculated their safety limit and all
the crew knew to look away if they did get hit in the eye. There was a
video projector that used lasers as a light source, but as long as one was
20 feet away you could look directly into the source for as long as you
wanted, it was scanning so fast. 

Thing about hitting a crowd at a rave is some folks might be in a mood to
stare into the laser source instead of glancing away. That could prove
damaging.

Hey, did I ever mention that KHDC, 90.9fm in Salinas has a underground
house show every tuesday night and wednesday night? (or technically
Wednesday morning and Thursday morning.)
It's called "Liquid Radio," and it's on from 1am to 5am.
I like it well enough, and you should too!
PS:
I went to the FMR, and it was my first FMR, and it was the best rave I've
ever been to. (But then, it was the only one where I've stayed till the end,
and I've only been to about 8-10 total) I liked it very very much.

aloha,
peter

From SFRaves-request@medisg.Stanford.EDU  Tue May 11 21:00:12 1993
Received: from medisg.Stanford.EDU by soda.berkeley.edu (5.65/KAOS-1)
	id AA01852; Tue, 11 May 93 21:00:12 -0700
Received: by medisg.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA00365; Tue, 11 May 93 20:57:03 PDT
Received: from netcom.netcom.com by medisg.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA00361; Tue, 11 May 93 20:57:02 PDT
Received: from netcom3.netcom.com by netcom.netcom.com (5.65/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id AA26839; Tue, 11 May 93 20:57:16 -0700
Message-Id: <9305120357.AA26839@netcom.netcom.com>
Date: Tue, 11 May 1993 20:57:21 -0800
To: sfraves@medisg.Stanford.EDU
From: wicked@netcom.com
Subject: What is Wicked?

        Wicked is a state of group mind integrated physically through the
attendees bodies and grounded into the earth, using music as our medium in
the psychedelic dance forum.

        It is a precious magikal time/space that can be created anywhere
that the tribe congregates and communes. The music we take very seriously.
This is our focal tool. Our means and modes of expression. Expression of
freedom. Freedom to be, to live and love together.

        Essentially Wicked is a tribe of people, friends, lovers, allies -
FAMILY. We share common understanding through consensual appreciation of
modern dance music orchestrated by our Shamen - The D.J.'s  Garth, Jeno,
Markie, and Thomas and our Artefacts - The Records and The Sound System.

        Wicked can happen anywhere it is safe for us to practice / play. It
is an energy ritual. Ideally it should be in San Francisco. We regard
Wicked as essentially a San Francisco phenomenon but appreciate the
necessity of experimenting throughout the Bay Area. It is important to us
to maintain strong, consistent parties within the city.

        This of course has to be balanced with direct contact to the planet
and universe. By marking the lunar passage with free outdoor dance parties
(FMR) we are essentially synchronising and harmonising to the natural
rhythms and cycles.

        We have tremendous responsibility to look after each other, be it
the collective responibility of a FMR to the compliance of health, safety,
fire, and ordinance permits of an upscale commercial event.

        It's fun for us to use different venues as it keeps it fresh and
ever changing/mutating. Wicked dance parties are charged energetically and
have the ability to transform people and/or places - energy dynamics. We
always hope to leave our vibe wherever we party.

        The Sound Factory, regardless of what has been there before, is a
suitable space for a large, publically attended event. It is correctly
permitted and developed for safe gatherings. There has until recently, been
a boys gay dance club on saturday night - Cyclops. Now this is finished,
there is a space before the next regular club happens. We have a chance to
do a one-off Wicked at this venue. This prospect excites us greatly, as it
will give us an opportunity to dispel any past negative vibes and re-lay it
with safe positive vibes. 

        With this in mind, we invite all our positively orientated friends
and family to come and celebrate being alive Here & Now. We would also like
to extend the invitation to those who need healing. We hope to generate a
group shared experience capable of uplifting everyone's spirit.

                 
                 ********************************
                 ******** You Have Been  ********
                 ********  Listening To  ********
                 ******** A WICKED SOUND ********
                 ********   Communique   ********
                 ********************************

> Forwarded message:
> >From SFRaves-request@medisg1.Stanford.EDU Tue May 11 18:25 BST 1993

> Message-Id: <9305111720.AA03794@pilot.njin.net>
> To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
> Subject: Re: LASER HAZARDS
> In-Reply-To: <27611.9305111252@wundt.harlqn.co.uk>
> References: <27611.9305111252@wundt.harlqn.co.uk>
> 	<9305110255.AA15688@chief>
> 
> At "Where the Wild Things Are" they had a 5 watt Co2 laser firing
> directly into the crowd, sometimes as a straight line. I thought this
> was *really* unsafe, so I took a closer look. I found that the
> straight line wasn't really straight, that it diverged to about 5
> inches in diameter by the time it reached the back of the (large)
> room. The reason it diverged was that the apparent beam wasn't really
> a beam at all. Even when the beam appeared stationary, it was actually
> being scanned in a very small pattern. Perhaps this explained why
> people weren't going blind.

People in the UK have been using lasers at raves and in clubs for years 
now. ( They have been used at other musiacal / theatrical events for
even longer ). So far there have been no accidents and from what I have
seen, and this has never been a point for the police force / council to stop
a rave. However, UK side, 99% of lasers are hired from legit companies that
specilise in rave lighting effects. No one I know of has of yet taken a 
laser printer and used that in a rave ! ( With a few modifications ;-) )
NB. Biggest laser I've scene used at a rave was: 25Watt twin head water
cooler argon laser. 
All lasers that mention a high wattage output tend not to be industrial 
lasers ( or they'd `burn' though the crowd, ) and the beam, as you meantioned,
is refracted and spiltt in smaller beams of less intensity.

Anyway multicolour lasers used in a rave with smoke machines and mirrors/
crystal balls positioned in the right place is a wicked effact.

I don't know what the police are like in the SF area, I'll find out in
August!
	
Can someone mail me back confirming this mail got to the sfraves group
as I don't subscribe ( Can't, too much mail and too much work here! )
Simon.


Suddenly it was all clear......		We got some serious problems here,

	id AA05707; Wed, 12 May 93 04:41:38 PDT
Date: Wed, 12 May 93 04:41:38 PDT
From: nineball@remarque.berkeley.edu (9ball)
Message-Id: <9305121141.AA05707@remarque.berkeley.edu>
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Subject: Straight up funk at the beach
Cc: scottie@uclink.berkeley.edu


I was there too, with my contingent of four Canadian ravers who
flew down to spend two weeks with me doing the SF scene again
after they had been gone for almost exactly a year.  I'll post
more about the whole visit soon.

This is the kind of event that has really been puzzling me about
the scene here.  Remember the amazing three day Memorial (Labor?)
Day event at this site (end of John Daly Blvd near Ft. Funston) last
year?  This promised to be a followup, starting on a sunny Sat.
afternoon with the phone line promising to go as long as they could
until they got busted.  Thinking it could again be lots of cool people
dancing in the sun straight through the night to a Sunday morning
with acres o' vibe, idyllic setting and weather and a sunset to
boot, we went to find about 60 people sitting around apparently bored,
one person dancing, no real vibe, and what felt like (in the words of my
Canadian friends) an "after-grad" party (reeeeal young).

We left after about an hour and walked back
up to the parking lot where high school kids would come tearing
donuts through the lot glaring at us, and with each passing group
of teenage pseudo-gangsters (including one very loud in-your-face
drunk group with a rottweiler fetching sticks with the command
"sic it boy" -- I'd bet my last zorkmid they were the group that
Scott saw making lame-ass gestures at the top of the cliff) we
were more and more glad we were leaving and more sad the scene
at this place had seemed to deteriorate to this point.

What happened?  Man, this shoulda raged.  I dunno
anymore about the SF scene, and didn't know how to explain it
to my friends.  Oh well, rave on, I guess....

        Personally, I think the master DAT's should go to the DJ's (ie. the
artistes) and it is they that should be consulted if any taping of their
sets is to be done. If a promoter wants to tape their event they should
first get clearance from the DJ's concerned.

Markie  !)

From: Derek Chung <dhchung@us.oracle.com>
To: dit@sybase.com, saeedi@shell.portal.com, sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Subject: Re:  Word has it..

Together is still pretty hot and getting hotter... Last night
Gavin, Pete Avila, and Simon heated up the floor, all with 
strong sets (at least while I was there), Gavin especially.  
Synergy visuals look great in the chill room (which is very
well-furnished), and also from the dance floor - before it
gets crowded, you can look across the room through the doorway
between the rooms, and the way the screen is set up, it looks
like there is room full of color beyond...

The energy is great, but dress for the heat - it gets quite 
warm like a basement-of-1015 Wicked.  DJs change every week,
previous Togethers have featured Jeno, Garth, Thomas, Scott
Hardkiss and others.

People start filling it at around 12:30, enter through the
Jessie Street door (in the back), call 979-8825 for weekly
DJ lineup.

-Derek

From: "Stewart, Scott*" <stewart#m#_scott*@msgate.corp.apple.com>
Subject: RE: Straight up funk at the beach
To: "9ball" <nineball@remarque.berkeley.edu>, sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Cc: scottie@uclink.berkeley.edu

This a replyy to 9 Balls previous post I am refering to it all so I didnt want
to copy the whole thing.

I went there too, arriving at about 6:00 Saturday evening.  I took my
Wife(seperated for a year) to it.  This was here first Rave(which I didnt
consider a rave")  I am glad that other people had the same feeling I did, I
felt the same way as 9Ball.  I was pretty burnt out and I thought that was the
situation.  I didnt enjoy the scene either, no vibe at all.  

What bothered me was when they were gathering resources for a camp fire.  First
they grabbed anything lying on the ground. Hell I used to do that too, now I
have learned how detrimental that is too the ecosystem. One of it was a 20 foot
tree branch. Then a bunch of guys started Pulled a large tree branch that was
still attached to one of the treess.  I couldnt beleive this mentality it
immediately depressed me.

The music was really good so I stayed a little while after a killer sunset. 
while standing by the fire I saw several people put there cans and bottles in
the fire.  Yeah if the fire is hot enough they will melt completely but what
usually happens is someone has to pick up the burnt cans and broken glass.  I
went to one guy who just put his beer bottle in the fire and asked him nicely
that it would be better to put it in the trash pile 10 feet away.  The guy went
into so speal about how it will melt completely and the N02 tanks causing more
envioremental damage.  Being brought down further I soon left making excuses to
my wife how this is not a real rave and how I will take her to a good one next
time.

The only high point to this outing was the incredible sunset meeting a few
SFRAVERS and seeing Carlos play.  Carlos is one of the hottest DJ's.  He is the
only DJ I know that totally gets inot his music and dances, I love watching him
spin.  I also think he has the most unique funky sound.

NUT

>From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>


I went to straight up funk from 2:30-8PM sat and 2-7:30PM sun. I thought
saturday was pretty iffy, but i enjoyed myself anyways. sunday was
alot better, as the vibe was unmarred by rotweiler-toting gangstas and
the music was alot better too. More people were dancing on sunday...

i think the party also went off nicely around 8PM sat when carlos
showed up to spin. However, we were hungry and tired so we left and had
a delicious indian repast. The next day, I had heard that the party
lasted all night! (But then again, given the reports of the near-assuault
that occured sat night, perhaps it wasn't that cool of a place to be).

and yes, the gangsta-folks with the rottweiler were the idiots who
started the fight. There are times when a lysurgic acid mace-gun would
be a useful form of chemical warfare. Spray it in their face and watch
the ego melt. then again, why waste good acid on fucked-up crack-addled
scumbags?

PS: I too had hoped that the event would be similar to the 3-day
extravaganza put on by "Rave Called Sharon" last year. It wasn't, but
it was a nice way of spending two summery spring daze. I managed to
stear clear of some of the mishaps that occured on saturday day and
night, so perhaps i have a more positive view of this than most.

forgot to mention the eco-damage aspect in my last post about
s.u.f.a.t.b. -- yes, the  macho shirtless-hunter-gatherers on saturday
were up there in the hierarchy of vibe-killers at the party.
fortunately, like the gangstas, they were gone on sunday.

To build a fire, the macho-shirtless hunter-gatherers (mshg's) decided
to not only grab every spec of dead wood in the canyon (which is sorta
ok)... they also decided that the 40-foot tall dead tree had to come
down.  They tried to draft me to help them  but i told them that it was
a stupid idea and that there are plenty of other pieces of wood
around... so the next thing you know, there's twenty mshg's grunting
and pushing and shoving and climbing and rocking the dead tree. it
looked like WW-II photo of the iwo-jima capture, or like a bunch of
guys jerking-off a oversized phallus.... once that tree was down, they
proceeded to try to break off the lower branches of living trees.
Grrrrr!

From: Craig M. Kanarick <kanarick@media.mit.edu>
Message-Id: <9305122316.AA19495@media.mit.edu>
To: ne-raves@gnu.ai.mit.edu, sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Subject: Rave Flyers article in Print Magazine




There is a *very* good article in this month's Print Magazine about
the graphic design of rave flyers and rave-club flyers.  The article
is quite well written but the visuals are incredible.

There are full-color reproductions of over 50 flyers from the
California rave scene.  Most of the are by Mel Marcelo, but there are
a lot of others, including Syd & Scooter, deeblur, Steve Levy, Richard
Duardo, David Horn, Mike Messex, Silas Hickey, David Orr, Rick Klotz,
and Stan Endo.

I'll try to scan in the images in my free time.... :-)

-- cmk

Beyond the ultraworld of Lee An:
> 
> On Wed, 12 May 1993, Francois Dion wrote:
> 
> > Burning by M.K. on Union City recordings.
> 
> There are also domestic releases of M(arc) K(inchen)'s "Burning," original
> mixes included, so you don't have to go out and spend $10 on the UCR import.

We get UCR at domestic prices here, which is 9.50-10$ CDN. Imports are 12.99-
13.99$ (REPHLEX cat008 was 18.99$ to give an idea on how prices are crazy).
(1$CDN=0.8$US)

Even at these prices people buy a lot of recordings in Montreal... In fact
Montreal is the city in Canada where they sell the most recordings.

To cut on expenses i buy in the states (mail order  or when visiting).

Ciao,
-- 
Francois Dion

From: crunch@netcom.com (John Draper)
Message-Id: <9305132003.AA12860@netcom.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@medisg1.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Raving in SJ last night

Well,  I'm here in San Jose this week at the Mac Developers Conf,
but I can still check Email here because of a nice setup that
allows me access to Internet.

I just want to report on two raves I attended in san Jose.   One
at the Club St John (Which I later learned as a gay bar),  but it
had totally awsome music sets,  but clientel was rather boring,
so we left for the Circus Cirsus rave on 2nd and Santa Clara st
in SJ,  and this one was truly dynamic.    It was free,  which 
really attracted me,  and the DJ's were reallyu creative.   

Great dymanic sets kept us hoppiing until 1:30 when things had to
shut down (Which was OK with me because I had to get up early).

Sound system was rather wimpey (Don't think it was anywhere near
the killowatt range,  but I managed to find a place near one
of th4e wimpey speakers that gave me SOME energy,  but to rave
while at the Computer conference was really great,  and I got my
body all loosened up,  and raved with some dudes from Wash DC
that I also met at the GK in SF last weekend.    All in all,  we
had a wecome break from all this computer conference humm drum
stuff (Land of the nerds).

Anyway,  thats a report on the rave,  should someone find it
useful..

Rave on..
JD

From SFRaves-request@medisg1.Stanford.EDU  Thu May 13 14:58:44 1993
Received: from medisg1.Stanford.EDU by soda.berkeley.edu (5.65/KAOS-1)
	id AA23481; Thu, 13 May 93 14:58:44 -0700
Received: by medisg1.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA06966; Thu, 13 May 93 14:55:13 PDT
Received: from leland.Stanford.EDU by medisg1.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA06962; Thu, 13 May 93 14:55:11 PDT
Received: by leland.Stanford.EDU (5.57/Ultrix3.0-C)
	id AA25376; Thu, 13 May 93 14:55:09 -0700
Message-Id: <9305132155.AA25376@leland.Stanford.EDU>
To: sfraves@medisg1.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Meat Beat and 808 State
Date: Thu, 13 May 93 14:55:07 -0700
From: doom@leland.stanford.edu


Well, courtesy of Pat Dote and KZSU I managed to get on the
guest list at the Edge last night, so I walked over there at
around 10 PM or so.  I expected I'd be early, but Meat Beat
Manifesto started soon after I got there.

Bunch of ravers were around... Ravi, Rox, a bunch of people
who aren't so active on the net (not to mention the folks
who's names I'm spacing on).  

Musically I thought 808 State's stuff sounded really good,
(particularly with the assist of what I gather were members
of UB40, though maybe I'm confused)... but I was bothered a
bit about the way they hide their instruments behind big
white ovals spelling out "808".  You could hardly see what
they were doing at all... I couldn't tell you if the whole
show wasn't on tape/sequencers. 

Meat Beat Manifesto was more interesting to watch, though it
took some work to figure out what instruments were supposed
to be doing what.  "Hm, you hear that pinging noise only
when the guy on the left hits the upper part of his drum
pad... and I guess he's shaping the electronic howling tones
by twisting those knobs up there."  At one point he says
"here's some *improvised* music" and walks across the stage
to press a button that turns on a complicated dub beat. 

So by and large, "live techno" is really silly.   But then
live performance is a pretty silly idea, in general. 

The crowd was interesting.  I was last at the Edge to see
Einsturzende Neubauten, and the contrast was pretty amazing.
Not as much black leather, fewer tattoos, elaborate
piercings, etc.  Brighter colors, and the Regular Guy look
were much in evidence.  None of which prevented the 7 foot
tall jocks (and a few of their shirtless male companions)
from forming a mosh pit.  There would be guys moshing at the
Edge during a chamber music recital.  I spent some time
playing energy absorber, essentially dancing in something
like a football blocking position for an hour.  

I tried to talk some people into checking out Dante at 2:30
over at Brian's party, but they weren't into it.  I went
home to kill some time, but the coffee wasn't working and I
wound up going to sleep myself.  Anything happen? 

(Oh, by the way, there's a room for rent over at my place,
for $365/month.  You too can know the joys of the Palo Alto
group housing communal living experience.  Within walking
distance of the Edge!  Inquire within.)

meet me at a club in the city Wednesday night and we'd go down to the 
site around 2:00.  I gave up around 3:00 and went down to the site,
hoping he'd either gone down himself or is just "running late".  To make
a long story short, nope, nothing happened, and thankfully we didn't
make Dante drive to the site (I told him to wait up in the city, I'd call
him as soon as the sound arrived), and hopefully Lee got my message in
time (did you, Lee?).  Anyways, I am sorry to everyone who stayed up late
and made the trek out there.  This was something of a "dry run" - I was 
there from 3:30 until 5am, and saw maybe 2 cars use the road the whole
time... so it's a safe spot for future use :)

	id AA09420; Fri, 14 May 93 04:11:05 PDT
Received: by remarque.berkeley.edu (4.1/1.31)
	id AA17868; Fri, 14 May 93 04:10:58 PDT
Date: Fri, 14 May 93 04:10:58 PDT
From: nineball@remarque.berkeley.edu (9ball)
Message-Id: <9305141110.AA17868@remarque.berkeley.edu>
To: sfraves@medisg1.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Good and bad news about the FMR.
Cc: bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu, geoffw@nexsys.net


More about the parts of the scene that I and those friends from
Canada I've been referring to recently experienced in the last 2 weeks....

Man, we had a good time at this one.  This FMR was certainly the
high point of the whole 2 weeks; one of the high points of the
last year for me.  It reaffirmed the faith for my friends who
hadn't been around since about a year ago at the peak.
The one thing that stuck out for me was that it
seemed like all the old regulars showed up again, the ones that it
has been so damn hard to find out and around in the SF scene recently.
Saw Brian helping direct traffic & all, and Geoff firmly
emplanted in an otherworld-trance in front of the stacks.

Everyone still had the same story to tell of not going out much in
the scene anymore, but for this they were in the best of
spirits, all ready to go nuts.  The setting was great, what with
the baylands, the relatively remote feel to the location, the perfect
sized crowd for a FMR, the freshness of the space (thank god, finally
a new space), the cement blocks to look over the crowd, the powerline
towers to climb on, everything.  The music raged.  Bust free.  Very
little attitude to be found; dammit, everyone seemed to be happy.

When we got there, some doubt remained in my mind whether a sensitive
part of the Baylands was a good location for the FMR, but thinking
of how last summer everyone seemed over-eager to leave any location
cleaner than it began calmed my worries.  Unfortunately, as we were
the VERY last car to leave the site, we saw what was left behind.
As I was picking up trash around our car, the two rangers who
came in those green trucks in the AM had just about completed an
hour of picking up trash.  One ranger had just busted someone
for peeing in the bushes in plain sight of two portapotties.
His came up to talk to us, and hoping he would give one of those
surprisingly encouraging comments about the people or the idea, he
instead pointed out the damage to the marshland and
told us that there was "human excrement and trash
everywhere" and that "this is not a good place to hold a party.
Next time you hear of one of these things forming, tell them to
take it elsewhere.  We don't want it here."

Even as the scene seemed to show a bit of life and promise, it was
already proving itself changed and in danger of furthering its
persecution.  Oh well.

From: bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu (Brian Behlendorf)
Date: Fri, 14 May 1993 12:11:43 -0700
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu, sfraves-calendar@soda.berkeley.edu
Subject: This week's RAVE guide

	Hi gang!  This week has a few pretty solid possibilities.  Tonight
Mission Rock looks like a clear winner for the SF area, but if you're down
in the South Bay Chapter One looks like it has a great DJ lineup too.  And
going from Mission Rock to Splash (with a travelling-through-SF-at-night
interlude) is probably what I'll do.

	Saturday night my vote would be for the last Groove Kitchen, coz of all
the 21+ parties I've been to for the past 6 months I would say this one
has the overall best vibe and most consistantly surprising DJ selection 
(despite being empty one week).  Coming in a close second, though, would
be Earth Beat - I _believe_ this is being thrown by an all-female group
of promoters, and the 18+/no alcohol thing is BIG in my book.  Oh, and 
Saturday evening from 6 to 9pm is a cool shindig at BPM, with the Hardkisses
spinning (imagine - dancing at a party, hearing a song you love, walking up
to the turntables and looking at the record, and being able to run down and
buy it!  Ha!  genius!  :)

	And Sunday afternoon the same people who are trying to get GG Park
for us are gonna throw a party at Fort Funston - call the # for more exact
locations.

	As a final word, next time you go out to an outdoor party, PLEASE
be conscious of your impact on the ecosystem.  Both the FF party last Saturday
and the FMR the Wednesday before that have been marred by people who don't
realize the sanctity of the environment - I know I'm prolly preaching to the
converted, but if you see others doing this, don't be afraid to walk up and
say HEY! KNOCK IT OFF!.  End of sermon. :)

	Have fun this weekend!

	Brian

debatable, but they were advertised by fliers and the music could be
good. If anyone can provide reviews of them, i.e., their 
appropriateness in being on the list, let me know....

CONNECTION 2 TAPES are still available from Bob Ramstad,
boccibob%groovy@us.oracle.com.  It's a 4-tape set, with music by
Moonpup, Scott Hardkiss, Jon Drukman, Lee, and Blurrrr - the tapes are
$20, plus $5 shipping (unless you pick it up in person) $5 of which
goes to the Malachy O'Brien trust fund.

hardkiss at least doesn't buy any of his records at BPM, so if he plays a song
you want, you might have to look a little harder (or buy the tape when it comes
out)...

Subject: Life is Music
To: sfraves@medisg1.Stanford.EDU (Bay Area Ravers)
Date: Fri, 14 May 1993 18:45:57 -0600 (MDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL21]
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 1197      


    What is most intimate to life is the evolutionary process, the creative
    process.  When we hear music, we find that the background of sound is
    maintained and the foreground of sound comes up, maintaining the
    continuity of melody and binding together in harmony the single notes
    that come up as waves on the silent bed of the ocean.  This is precisely
    the creative process.  The wholeness of Being in its eternal silence
    warms up and produces the background of the music of life, and on the
    foreground of Being spring up the waves of relativity, waves of life.
    So music reminds us of what one is; it displays the story of life.  When
    one finds what one actually is, one is attracted to it.  Whether one is
    aware of it or not, reality of life is found in music and therfore it is
    natural that music should have a universal attraction.

						- Maharishi Mahesh Yogi

brians@ios.convergent.com				 a funkin' bass,
A lowly raver without a glowstick.			 for a loving race."

Hello...

I have a question..  About 6 years ago I used to D.J. little house parties
in my town.  I had a few records from local bay area DJ's.  One was
Juanito (Oakland), and the other was DJ EFX (SF).  I had pulled out those old
records the other day and me and my friend got into a argument about what
type of music they were.  The songs were basically just mixes comprised of
10-20 second bites of the days latest hip-hop dance music.  Anyway.  My
question is this.  Would that type of music be considered Acid House???  My
friend seams to think so..  I totally disagree and think it is just a mix
of dance and hip hop music.  Nothing special..  I have always thought that
Acid house was the same thing as house.  BTW  Does anyone know if DJ EFX
is still around??  I think he is, and is still Dj'ing at the clubs.  Anyway
thats about it.

UnIbRoW

Hi Everybody,

This is FYI.

Apologies for any overlaps if you get this twice. Note: I was in the
Netherlands last year and crashed/partied with these guys and gals and
they're ALL RIGHT kinds-a folks. This should be a real feth-ti-val for those
who can make it over there. The central Netherlands area is noted for the
lack of a "There" there, but what they lack in "There-ness," they more than
make up for with a wonderful sense of wackiness.

   Subliminal Hint:  l e t ' s   a l l   g o ...

Peace,
          ^ ^
  dave    '['                      ...Clip the Clipper Chip!
           u 
 
-------------------------------------------------------------------
H A C K I N G   A T   T H E   E N D   O F   T H E   U N I V E R S E
-------------------------------------------------------------------

                                     An 'in-tents' summer congress
H U H?
-------

Remember the Galactic Hacker Party back in 1989? Ever wondered what
happened to the people behind it? We sold out to big business, you
think. Think again, we're back!

That's right. On august 4th, 5th and 6th 1993, we're organising a
three-day summer congress for hackers, phone phreaks, programmers,
computer haters, data travellers, electro-wizards, networkers, hardware
freaks, techno-anarchists, communications junkies, cyberpunks, system
managers, stupid users, paranoid androids, Unix gurus, whizz kids, warez
dudes, law enforcement officers (appropriate undercover dress required),
guerilla heating engineers and other assorted bald, long-haired and/or
unshaven scum. And all this in the middle of nowhere (well, the middle
of Holland, actually, but that's the same thing) at the Larserbos
campground four metres below sea level.

The three days will be filled with lectures, discussions and workshops
on hacking, phreaking, people's networks, Unix security risks, virtual
reality, semafun, social engineering, magstrips, lockpicking,
virusses, paranoia, legal sanctions against hacking in Holland and
elsewhere and much, much more. English will be the lingua franca for
this event, although some workshops may take place in Dutch. There
will be an Internet connection, an intertent ethernet and social
interaction (both electronic and live). Included in the price are four
nights in your own tent. Also included are inspiration, transpiration,
a shortage of showers (but a lake to swim in), good weather
(guaranteed by god), campfires and plenty of wide open space and fresh
air. All of this for only 100 dutch guilders (currently around US$70).

We will also arrange for the availability of food, drink and smokes of
assorted types, but this is not included in the price. Our bar will be
open 24 hours a day, as well as a guarded depository for valuables
(like laptops, cameras etc.). You may even get your stuff back! For
people with no tent or air matress: you can buy a tent through us for
100 guilders, a matress costs 10 guilders. You can arrive from 17:00
(that's five p.m. for analogue types) on August 3rd. We don't have to
vacate the premises until 12:00 noon on Saturday, August 7 so you can
even try to sleep through the devastating Party at the End of Time
(PET) on the closing night (live music provided). We will arrange for
shuttle buses to and from train stations in the vicinity.


H O W ?
-------

Payment: In advance only. Even poor techno-freaks like us would like
to get to the Bahamas at least once, and if enough cash comes in we
may just decide to go. So pay today, or tomorrow, or yesterday, or in
any case before Friday, June 25th 1993. Since the banks still haven't
figured out why the Any key doesn't work for private international
money transfers, you should call, fax or e-mail us for the best way to
launder your currency into our account. We accept American Express,
even if they do not accept us. But we are more understanding than they
are. Foreign cheques go directly into the toilet paper recycling bin
for the summer camp, which is about all they're good for here.


H A !
-----

Very Important: Bring many guitars and laptops.


M E ?
-----

Yes, you! Busloads of alternative techno-freaks from all over the
planet will descend on this event. You wouldn't want to miss that,
now, would you?

Maybe you are part of that select group that has something special to
offer! Participating in 'Hacking at the End of the Universe' is
exciting, but organising your very own part of it is even more fun. We
already have a load of interesting workshops and lectures scheduled,
but we're always on the lookout for more. We're also still in the
market for people who want to help us organize this during the
congress.

In whatever way you wish to participate, call, write, e-mail or fax us
soon, and make sure your money gets here on time. Space is limited.


S O :
-----

> 4th, 5th and 6th of August

> Hacking at the End of the Universe
      (a hacker summer congress)

> ANWB groepsterrein Larserbos
      (Flevopolder, Netherlands)

> Cost: fl. 100,- (+/- 70 US$) per person
      (including 4 nights in your own tent)


M O R E   I N F O :
-------------------

Hack-Tic
Postbus 22953
1100 DL  Amsterdam
The Netherlands

tel     : +31 20 6001480
fax     : +31 20 6900968
E-mail  : heu@hacktic.nl

V I R U S :

by all means slip it in. Echo-areas, your favorite bbs, /etc/motd, IRC,
WP.BAT, you name it. Spread the worm, uh, word.

Received: by NeXT.Mailer (1.87.1)
Received: by NeXT Mailer (1.87.1)
To: sfraves@medisg1.Stanford.EDU
Subject: house spirit in Aikido
Reply-To: rnj%lila@us.oracle.com

how is the japanese martial art of Aikido like House?  i was reading Aikido  
Primer by Eric Sotnak, and was struck by the closing of the document:

	The following are some of the founder's teachings concerning
	the essence of aikido:

	Aikido is a manifestation of a way to reorder the world of
	humanity as though everyone were of one family. Its purpose is to
	build a paradise right here on earth.

	Aikido is nothing but an expression of the spirit of Love for
	all living things.

	It is important not to be concerned with thoughts of victory
	and defeat. Rather, you should let the ki of your thoughts and
	feelings blend with the Universal.

	Aikido is not an art to fight with enemies and defeat them.
	It is a way to lead all human beings to live in harmony with each
	other as though everyone were one family. The secret of aikido is
	to make yourself become one with the universe and to go along with
	its natural movements. One who has attained this secret holds the
	universe in him/herself and can say, ``I am the universe.''

	If anyone tries to fight me, it means that s/he is going to
	break harmony with the universe, because I am the universe. At the
	instant when s/he conceives the desire to fight with me, s/he is
	defeated.

	Nonresistance is one of the principles of aikido. Because
	there is no resistance, you have won before even starting. People
	whose minds are evil or who enjoy fighting are defeated without a
	fight.

	The secret of aikido is to cultivate a spirit of loving
	protection for all things.

	I do not think badly of others when they treat me unkindly.
	Rather, I feel gratitude towards them for giving me the opportunity
	to train myself to handle adversity.

	You should realize what the universe is and what you are
	yourself. To know yourself is to know the universe.

the Primer is 25 pages.  if you'd like a copy, let me know and i'll send you  
back the LaTeX source.

Hmmm.....a brief word about Earth Beat for those who missed it. It was great, as most parties associated with Martin are, it was cool to see a team of female promoters pumping up the scene...anyhow, it was in some heavy-metal club on Gilman street, not the best location, but the music, vibe, people made up for it--just an indicator that the promoters were there for us, when they ran out of waater temporarily, they started giving away juices that they were previously selling...cool..a final word...MARKIE IS THE MAN!!!...incredible set, tweaked everyone over the top into la la land......peace....aaron

From SFRaves-request@medisg.Stanford.EDU  Sun May 16 17:59:34 1993

>From: dms!curly!grigsby@netcom.com (Spiral Death Trap)
Message-Id: <9305170053.AA19255@curly.agames.com>
To: sfraves@medisg.stanford.edu
Subject: Earth Beat location?


By "some heavy metal club on Gilman street" I hope you're not talking
about 924 Gilman street, the nucleus of the Bay Area punk scene for the
last 8 million years.  Cooperatively run, shows are never more than $5 +
$2/yr membership, no asshole security.  I've seen some of my favorite
shows ever in that space over the past several years.  If raves were 
run with as much attention to people before profits it would be viewed
as miraculous.  They're about as cool as you can get and still be legal.

Of course, I can't speak for the promoters that used the space, but it
sounds like everyone had a good time.  This could be a good bridge between
two groups that normally don't get along: punks and ravers.  Unless it
was someplace else, in which case I'll say that you should try going to
a show there sometime anyway.  Info line is 510-525-9926.

// g

From SFRaves-request@medisg1.Stanford.EDU  Mon May 17 09:03:46 1993
Received: from medisg1.Stanford.EDU by soda.berkeley.edu (5.65/KAOS-1)
	id AA28877; Mon, 17 May 93 09:03:46 -0700
Received: by medisg1.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA12844; Mon, 17 May 93 09:00:26 PDT
Received: from orca.es.com (ES.COM) by medisg1.Stanford.EDU (4.1/1.34)
	id AA12840; Mon, 17 May 93 09:00:23 PDT
Received: from slack ([130.187.198.23]) by orca.es.com (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA21055; Mon, 17 May 93 10:00:22 MDT
Received: by slack (4.1/E&S_client-ver1.5/SMI-4.1)
	id AA22184; Mon, 17 May 93 10:00:14 MDT
From: pashdown@slack.sim.es.com (Pete Ashdown)
Message-Id: <9305171600.AA22184@slack>
Subject: A raver's view of the Grateful Dead
To: sfraves@medisg1.Stanford.EDU (SF Raves)
Date: Mon, 17 May 1993 10:00:13 -0600 (MDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL21]
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 5776      

I managed to get tickets for all three days of the Sting/Grateful Dead show in
Las Vegas.  Becky, the girlfriend of my best friend John, is a big Deadhead
and through her talents, we all managed to snag an entire weekend.

I'll be blunt.  I went to see Sting.  I had seen the Dead once before, in 1986
when they had come to Park West, Utah.  It was more out of curiosity than
appreciation for their music then.  There was a large amount of curiosity in
play this time as well, since I wanted to compare notes between the Deadhead
scene and the rave scenes that I had become so enamored of over the past year.

The first day, Friday, I only got to see the last song of Sting's set, "When
The World is Running Down".  I was surprised to see how energetic Sting was.
The last few tours he was musically strong, but visually limp.  This time he
was running around, jumping, and even stirring the audience on.  I was
surprised at the reception the Deadheads were giving Sting as well, warm and
appreciative.

Most of the Friday's Grateful Dead performance was lost in the muddle of my
mind.  John and I were both disinterested after a few songs.  Once the drum
solo of "Space" had occured, we returned to the floor to check things out.
Amazingly enough, we found that we were boogying quite nicely to this almost
tribal improvisation.  John wanted to see what the speaker stacks were like
close-up, so we walked right up to them.  I doubt you could that at any other
stadium concert.  Feeling the beat rushing through us, and the occasional
whooshes of bass from something he was hitting, we almost felt at home to the
thump thump thump of our own rave's bass bins.

After the show, we wandered the "mall".  I bought a tie dyed shirt with Winnie
The Pooh on it.  We met some friends, then took off for the motel where we
were staying.

Saturday, I made certain that we got there EARLY, so I could see what I came
for.  Sting put on another strong performance.  I was about fifty yards back
from the stage.  Again, I was amazed at the treatment given to him.  Someone
had even made a banner, "Welcome Sting" to go along with several other Dead
banners.

I'd started to notice the shirts.  It seemed that everyone had a unique
version.  The practice of stealing product logos by ravers for their T's had
long been in practice by Deadheads, and frankly they do it better.  Some
absolutely hilarious versions.  My favorites was definitely the dosed Calvin
& Hobbes.  I also got involved in a large marshmellow with a hundred other
people.  This, plus the tossing around of large balloons and beach balls made
it a concert event that was quite different from anything else I'd attended.
Yet still, their music failed to move me.  The prime example was the final
song, covering "Lucy in the Sky With Diamonds".  The audience would clap the
beat out before the chorus, then it would fall off a cliff into s mush of
netherland.  Why?

After the concert, we returned to the mall again.  This time stumbling upon
the "disco bus."  A large white bus where they had turned their internal sound
system external and were playing bits of 70's disco over the loud speakers.
There was an absolute MOB there and it was pumping hard when we arrived.  I
must have kicked myself a thousand times for not bringing down the sound
system and setting up the tables.  John and I had discussed doing it, but we
feared that nobody would accept the idea and we'd have wasted our time.  Now,
seeing 200 or so people jumping in a parking lot to "YMCA" made me ache to
have brought the rave culture together with the Dead culture.  I took a wild
chance and asked the people in the bus if they had any Orb.  They looked at me
like I was from a different planet, and I'm not even sure if they knew that I
was referring to music.  Oh well, maybe next year.

The last day, I caught all of Sting's set again, and it was completely
different from Saturday's set.  The highlight was hearing "Everything Little
Thing She Does is Magic" live for the first time.  The crowd absolutely
stormed over that.  The rest of the day was spent with a new found friend, who
unfortunately, had to leave early to catch her plane back to Seattle.  During
the first intermission between Dead sets, we spent some time in the drum
circle, then I walked her up to the phone booth where she had to phone a cab,
then leave.  She asked if I wouldn't rather be watching the show and I
guffawed over that comment.  Nothing about their music had ignited me to dance
yet.  As we were waiting in line for the phone, I could hear the Dead
returning to the stage again.  A half hour later and my friend was gone.

I walked back into the stadium and to my amazement, heard a funky 4/4 beat
coming off the stage.  Not only that, but Jerry was throwing off this lilting,
absolutely beautiful guitar line.  I looked at the audience itself and could
*see* the vibes flow over the entire arena as the beatwaves moved to the back.
So, THIS is "Morning Dew", the only song I'd seen a shirt for.  I couldn't
help myself, I ran down to the floor and danced like mad.  The energy was so
powerful at that time that the air was almost sparking.  I felt that the two
scenes weren't so different after all.  Each of them striving for that one
solitary moment where you just don't care about life's problems anymore.

As I was walking out, I saw a person's shirt which seemed to fit the moment
exactly.  "Were they ever here at all?" it read.  There was something
mystical, etherial and strange about the entire weekend.  It was like I was
visiting a different planet after all, but it was one that I could somehow
connect with anyway.  The square peg had fit in the round hole and I enjoyed
my stay.  This could become an additional addiction in the years to come.

get here but I think this summer it will explode.  The crowd is becoming more
and more diverse and the smiles are getting bigger...and more extatic!!!

From: geoffw@nexsys.net (Geoff White)

Subject: Groove Kitchen


	Well, the last Groove Kitchen went out with a bang!
	By 4 a.m. the Vibe was so thick you needed a hack saw to cut it :)
	Jon ? started with some great tunes, including some break beat which
	I actually got into., Jon Williams worked OVERTIME and comeout as the
	hero of this Groove Kitchen laying down a serious set, followed by rick
	preston who pushed us all through the StarGate into the next dimension.
	I was great to see so many familiar faces around me and for the first 
	in a long time, amybe the first time this year, I felt completely safe
	to TOTALLY TRANCE and completely go off, I danced from midnight to
	7 a with about a 30 minute break in between When Doc Martin didn't
	show Jon Williams came back and throwed down an even more intense
	set than the first one!  I think the lot of us went past just trance
	to the level of "group mind" (for lack of a better word) that place
	where all ego is gone and you all just merge into one psychic ball
	of consciousness.  This was the kind of a party that makes you glad
	that you are a speaker-tweeker.

	After splitting at about 8, I got a ride from ark Ameba over to
	boogie buffet but it wasn't happening so we split, got some breakfast
	and then I crashed for about 3 hours got up and heaed to the beach
	on foot (bus actually, my car is not fixed yet).  I arrived at the 
	original site only to find it deserted.  I saw some ravers that told me
	it had been moved to sloat street.  So I started the 2 mile walk down
	great highway toward sloat. Got picked up by nrg and family along the
	way, we got conflicting reports that nothing was happening, that it was
	happening, etc. Eventually we rounded to corner and found about 100
	ravers lying out in the beach with a reasonably good sound system
	and Carlos spinning but no one dancing.  This group eventually
	grew to about 200 people and out of the blue up pops Jon Williams again
	(boy this guy is everwhere) who plays yet another killer set!  He got
	a lot of people off their collective butt and on the dancesand :)

	All in all a great weekend.  I did make some observations and some
	personal decisions this weekend which I will share in a separate post.

From: "Glenn Fajardo,USA" <glenn.fajardo@aldus.com>
Subject: From the Seattle posse- A Rave Called Sharon:Prophecy
To: "MykL G" <mcg@netcom.com>, sfraves@medisg1.Stanford.EDU

Hi Mykle,

A Rave Called Sharon:Prophecy turned out to be pretty good despite some
organization setbacks.  The fliers weren't distributed until a few days before
the event and the location wasn't pinned down until late that night.  Rumors of
a cancellation were also being spread around by one of the promoters who was
throwing a party that night as well.  It was held at the Omni in Kent.  An OK
location, not the greatest.  The vibes were HIGH that night.  From my
experience, it was a really friendly event.  And the DJ's were fantastic. 
There was a woman spinning at one time, i forget her name, who was Excellent! 
She came up with some excellent excellent trance and tribal mixes that had
EVERYONE grooving.  Someone said that she was from England.  The grooves and
vibes really started kickin' around 3am.  Spun started his magic at about that
time.  Need I say more??? 

Everyone up here in Seattle is hoping that we get a bigger influx of promoters
from the Bay Area.  The one big promoter up here doesn't really have a clue as
to what vibe is about and tends to be hardcore LA style in the way he does his
parties.

Tigger

Anyway, message continues...

fwd'ed from humbm@lut.ac.uk:

Had an intersting lecture on Friday on models of heat control and
thermoregulatory enviromental models....And there I had a great idea for
my project, it would go something like this:

	o Calculate the body's metabolic rate and sweat rate whilst raving.

	o correalte this with different in takes of MDMA

	o Assess the isulatory values of typical ravers clothes/hats/gloves
	  (measured in clo.)
	
	o Assess the thermal enviroment in different clubs at different times.
	  This would include: -Air temp
			      -Relative humidity
			      -Air velocity
			      -Radient Air temp.

	o Using a mathematical model of the Human (already on our human 
	  sciences lan) it would be possible to produce a database of how
	  many pills/time actually dancing you need to pass before suffering
	  heat stroke and death. Now this sound morbid, but just imagine
	  being able to say as you enter a club, for example AWOL, that you
	  can:
		-allow half an hour to "come up"
		-after x amount of time you will enter the model's warning
		 level. But because you have calculated that your heat balance
		 is being disrupted by the thermal storage value of your white
		 gloves and hat, you can take them off, your body will be 
		 thermally balanced and you can continue with coplete exertion
		-After y amount of time the club is beginning to seriously
		 heat up. There is no air movement and your sweat rate is
		 insufficient to allow normal evaporation. Carry on like this
		 and you'll be exhusted before your time. Hence the model
		 tells you to take a break. The body can also handle another
		 Heart, but NOT a China White.
		-After a short rest, you can continue, following the guidance
		 of the model.

And hence you will have a database of optimum drug intake within different
clubs at different times wearing different clothes. The possibilities are
endless....You could calculate your dress at a do on the North pole, working
out how many layers to wear to commence, and how long you'd need to be 
dancing/how many pills you'd need before you could be raving butt naked.
Obviosly in such a condition a psychological dimension on the model would
also reveal how raving mad you are as well.

The possibilities are endless. With the coming of Cyber Tribe, the 
technologisation and miniturisation of our society, imagine the ulimate
E-Heads application. The database inside your wrist watch work station, with
MDMA carefully delivered into the bloodstream via a form of osmosis from the
watch, at the precise intervals to keep you going, warm you up or, by
withholding doses, cool you down. Various settings would be availible:
experimenter, weekend raver, nutter, seriously caned, mashed beyond belief,
suicidal, and a variety of user programmable options. Just tell the watch
which club your in, fill it's tank with your choice of MDMA and away you
go.........


Fwd,ed message ends.

So this is what students do! Wonder if I can get a paying job
as a student. ( Does not include grant ).

> What is a "large marshmellow"? Inquiring minds, well, you know the rest...
> 
> >I also got involved in a large marshmellow with a hundred other
> >people.

I noticed this unfortunate typo after it was too late.

"large marshmellow fight"

It is where someone brings a couple bags of marshmellows and then starts
hucking them at random targets below them in the grandstand.  There was one
point where it was like living in a hot cross-fire area, and there were
zillions of marshmellows in the air.  It was light activity the first day,
moderate the second day, then the third day, it seemed like everyone brought a
bag.
