In-Reply-To: Pete Ashdown's message of Mon, 17 May 1993 10:00:13 -0600 (MDT) <9305171600.AA22184@slack>
Subject: A raver's view of the Grateful Dead
Reply-To: boccibob%groovy@us.oracle.com


maybe I should have retitled this "a raver's/deadhead's view of a
raver's view of the Grateful Dead" :-)

If you aren't interested in hearing some comments on what Pete said
about the Vegas shows, plus a brief tie-in with raving, delete this
sucker NOW!  You have been warned.

Sting's set on Saturday was virtually identical to the one on Friday,
which bothered a lot of people, me included.  "He's got a great
repertoire, why the hell is he playing exactly the same songs?"
Sunday was completely unique, including a ripping "Purple Haze" of all
things, except for "Every Little Thing She Does Is Magic" which was a
repeat from Friday.  

Why all the wonderment at how Sting was received by the 'heads?  A lot
of people I know were skeptical, but by Sunday, they were all pretty
happy with having Sting along for the rest of the (major venue shows
on the) summer tour.  Sting has EXCELLENT professional musicians
backing him up, and frankly, they wail, a kick ass band.  'Nuff said.

> As we were waiting in line for the phone, I could hear the Dead
> returning to the stage again.  A half hour later and my friend was
> gone.

> I walked back into the stadium and to my amazement, heard a funky 4/4
> beat coming off the stage.  Not only that, but Jerry was throwing off
> this lilting, absolutely beautiful guitar line.  I looked at the
> audience itself and could *see* the vibes flow over the entire arena
> as the beatwaves moved to the back.  So, THIS is "Morning Dew", the
> only song I'd seen a shirt for.  I couldn't help myself, I ran down to

Actually, this was almost certainly "Terrapin Station", my all time
favorite Dead tune.  And a lot of other 'heads feel the same way...
plus it got a strong strong reaction, because no one was expecting it
(it was too late in the set to go into a long song, most people were
expecting the start of Drumz, me included, even though I told friends
that I was hoping for a Terrapin and an Other One before the show.)

Setlist for Sunday for the record:

 I: Touch of Grey, Walking Blues, Althea, Masterpiece, Row Jimmy,
    Cassidy.

II: Samson and Delilah, Help on the Way > Slipknot! > 
    Franklin's Tower > Looks Like Rain > Terrapin Station >> 
    Drumz > Space > The Other One > Wharf Rat > Throwing Stones > 
    Lovelight.

 E: Brokedown Palace.

and yeah, Terrapin started about 30 - 35 minutes into the second set.
Oh, and there are a LOT of shirts for Terrapin, too :-)

> the floor and danced like mad.  The energy was so powerful at that
> time that the air was almost sparking.  I felt that the two scenes
> weren't so different after all.  Each of them striving for that one
> solitary moment where you just don't care about life's problems
> anymore.

Precisely.  The goal is the grand "ego dissolve", which occurs when
the feeling that life's problems don't matter anymore is strengthened
and generalized.  This happens at raves and at Dead shows, people on
drugs and people sober.  Another symptom is an increasing feeling of
unity with everything and everyone.

Enough of my blithering, but yes, there is a strong strong connection
between the peak moments of the rave experience and the peak moments
of the deadhead experience, the routes are different, but the result
is the same.  I absolutely see this, and have had equally intense
moments at both events.  Call me a dual-citizen, if you will.

And boy, if you think Vegas is a marginally weird place, try visiting
when 60,000 deadheads are in town :-)

Bob

From SFRaves-request@medisg1.Stanford.EDU  Mon May 17 13:28:07 1993

	id AA23045; Mon, 17 May 93 13:14:39 PDT
Received: by nexsys.nexsys.net (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA09147; Mon, 17 May 93 12:59:03 PDT
Date: Mon, 17 May 93 12:59:03 PDT
From: geoffw@nexsys.net (Geoff White)
Message-Id: <9305171959.AA09147@nexsys.nexsys.net>
To: sfraves@nexsys.net
Subject: Some Thoughts on the Scene


	I did a lot of thinking this weekend about the Scene, its potential
	and it's fate.  These are my observations and decisions.  They are
	based on my observations of not only the Scene as it is today but
	the things that "went before" (Since I'm a little older then some,
	I do remember the summer of love although I was a mere 10 years old
	at the time). I'd like to get comments from some of the "elders"
	on the list like will who has seen and done much more than I have...

	1. Eventhough their are retro elements to this Scene with regard to
	   the "hippy" Scene they are not the same.

	2. Human Nature has progressed some since the 1960`s but not as much
	   as some of us would like to belive.

	3. Even if the Scene dies as did the "hippie" movement, it will still
	   make an impact.  Remember, it is part of the natural order of an
	   ecosystem to experience birth, life, reproduction and death.

	4. Much as many of you younger folks resist it, the rave Scene is
	   the child of the hippie movement, many of the people in the 
	   Scene were born around 67 - 70, at the hight of the vibe of this
	   movement, many of your parents had high hopes for what you would 
	   do and, in many ways, the Scene is a continuation of many of those
	   principles.

	5. As with any form of energy, as you get further away from the source
	   in time and space, there is a diminishing and coagulation.  As the
	   Scene gets bigger and more exposed and available, it will change,
	   some for the better, but largely for the worst.  Out of the wake-up
	   of the 60's we had a major push in civil rights, the ending of an
	   unjust war (many of the flower children went away to vietnam and 
	   came back in a box, this mobilized many of them to action, how 
	   would you feel if Brian got drafted and then 6 months later, he was
	   dead, followed by leah, or dana... it would have an impact, I tell
	   you.) some people decided that the only way to fight fire was with
	   fire, they formed groups like the Black Panthers, the Weathermen,
	   SLA, etc. While I may agree with the causes that a lot of these
	   groups fought for, I can clearly see the result of meeting violence
	   with direct violence (at least in these cases). Eventualy a lot of
	   people got "lost" in the 60's, but not all, some "went back to the
	   land" and are still there, raising kids and silently trying to seed
	   a new generation.   Some used the rock group that they already had
	   as a vehicle for social change, some started Ice Cream stores and
	   some ran for public office.  Some were murdered, imprisoned or
	   exiled by the government (yes this DOES happen in america).
	   The question we must ask is how do we learn from what happened before
	   and use this knowledge to our best advantage.  Maybe it can be 
	   different this time, maybe not.  My guess is that we will have so
	   incremental progress like before that we will bequith to OUR
	   children, who will carry on.  In evolution, things take time.

	6. I think the major contribution that the House Movement can make is
	   the KNOWING that we are all ONE.  Anybody who has been on the dance-
	   floor of a good rave at 4 am feels this, for some it is a religious
	   feeling, for some it is a physiological biological one but when we
	   experence relentless  drumming, it puts us in contact with something
	   that we all did a long long time ago, whether you are a soul sista
	   or a white boy, your ancestors all did this one primeval thing...
	   when we rave, we remeber.  In the 60's this was different, there
	   was ego loss but no awareness of group consciousness, accepting
	   someone of a different race, sexual preference, etc. was a concept
	   that was considered ideal but not practiced on an everyday sort of
	   way as it is in the rave scene, we as a group have gone beyond that
	   one, (we still need to work on sexism though!)

	7. What's next? I don't know.  I personaly think we have to learn new
	   models of government, based on consensus,.  Since we now have 
	   appropriate electronic communications mediums available, this is 
	   possible.  It was not possible in the 60's or even 80's.  It can
	   work but we have to unlearn some conditioning first, we are already
	   good ast this and have created a technology of de/reprogramming that
	   seems to work quite well :)

	8. Well for me, I will be throwing most of my energy into outdoor
	   alcohol free, all ages events.  I love clubs like Wicked and 
	   Groove Kitchen, but the smoke and the bad air are too much even
	   for a healthy person's immune system to fight off on a weekly
	   basis.  Also something special happens when we perfrom the rave
	   ritual out of doors,  Mother Earth talks to us (well she talks to
	   me :) shee communicates with here children in a deep way.  I think
	   Malachy knew this to be true, which is why he wanted to have small
	   outdoor intimate events.  I'm going to focus my energy on creating
	   real outdoor rave rituals of sound.  If they can be legal, fine.
	   If not well, I hope we don't have to resort to the tactics of the
	   Spiral Tribe here but if that has to happen then so be it.

	9. I don't know exactly what turn this will take with me.  I keep
	   telling myself that I don't want to be a promoter, it's to hard
	   to do the job with integrity all of the time, and I would try
	   to hard.  But maybe the way to do it is to just buy a sound
	   system and DIY do it yourself.  I think it will work better if
	   each person or at least no more that two people at a time buy
	   things jointly, this way we have more diversity of schedualing
	   (no committees to ask and no profits/losses to have to deal with
	   on a large scale, It's easy to get an oK schedual confirmation
	   from 2 as oppose to 20. But if we, as a group have a FEW people
	   around with sound systems, it increases our odds of making sure
	   that a lot of good parties will get thrown.  We already have an
	   ample pool of DJs some old and many new rising stars that need a 
	   chance to be heard. We have the Net for communication and
	   infrastructure, what we need are people with the fillowings
	   skills/resources:

		1. Sound Systems, or parts of sound systems, including
		   turntables and mixers.

		2. Access to Energy (Generators or easy access to rented 
		   generators, (we should start buying our own))

		3. People willing to work security for free. Outdoor events
		   need security.  Security is mostly looking around you 
		   for things in destress or things out of place, often the
		   problem is corrected by just standing in the vacinity.
		   There  already is an unofficial security network of sorts,
		   just people like me and a few others that look out for 
		   people in distress, we've began to recognize each other
		   but it needs to be a little more formal, like cpr and
		   first aid training.

		4. People who have cellular phones.  and/or portable laptops
		   with modems. I've even thought about this as a
		   safety device.  The cheap phones that are light and
		   reasonable are around $350, you can get deals on air
		   time including "unlimited weekend access" for about
		   $60. The light phones that support conventional modems
		   seem to be around $700 but if anyone has any better info
		   let me know. (Who says you can't bring vrave to bonny dune?
		   :)

		5. People willing to invest/loose :) money throwing events.
		   Some folks can afford to invest various amounts of
		   money without it seriously impacting their life
		   style, we can think of a way that they can feel good
		   about doing this.  They should go in knowing that
		   the primary purpose of the event is to generate the
		   Vibe in the best way possible and that they will
		   every effort will be made so that at least they
		   don't loose money and hopefully gain.  If money is
		   made they should feel as if they could take their
		   profits with out feeling guilty and also know that
		   they will be invited to donate their profit to the
		   group or to some other endevor.

		6. People who have various forms of transportation, from 
		   Trucks, 4-wheel drives, bikes, mobile homes, sports cars,
		   boats and planes.

		7. Ravers who are Hams. Are there any out there?

		8. People who love to volunteer, who can take orders as well
		   as give orders. (Anybody out there remember logistics teams?)

		9. People who love to take risk, we need these people to do the
		   thinks we're afraid to. :)

	       10. Law Hackers or Lawyers to help with those sticky situations
		   that we hope don't have to happen.

	       11. Media assasins, people who want to talk to the media and
		   are good at it.

	If anybody out there is interested in exploring this with me, write
	to me and maybe we can have some conversation off line or on another
	list.  I think if we want to have the Scene be good then we need to
	set an example for others to follow.


					G

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Editor/Instigator/Catalyst : Geoff White <geoffw@nexsys.net>

                                (stolen from monicat :)

It's funny that you mention this.  The variables that you mentioned
is one reason I don't partake of e in big hot warehouse parties.  It is
also why I feel that you really need to stay healthy to be a hardcore raver.
I've found that when I want to really do a good underground on the edge rave,
I go sober cuz I'm more awake and my body can take more abuse, with out having
to worry about how much more my blood pressure is elivated by the drug.
But then, I've even cut out most of my coffee so just call me a health nut.

I for one believe in a.

It doesn't alter your body temperature much and has a much lower effect on
your heart rate, and blood pressure.


FOR THE NSA LINE REAPER:
I in no way shape or form condone or advocate  the use of illegal
or controlled substances.

From: crunch@netcom.com (John Draper)
Message-Id: <9305172108.AA01562@netcom4.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Subject: Some suggestions to the organizers

Geoff White writes:

>        8. Well for me, I will be throwing most of my energy into outdoor
>           alcohol free, all ages events.  I love clubs like Wicked and 
>           Groove Kitchen, but the smoke and the bad air are too much even
>           for a healthy person's immune system to fight off on a weekly
>           basis.  Also something special happens when we perfrom the rave
>           ritual out of doors,  Mother Earth talks to us (well she talks to
>           me :) shee communicates with here children in a deep way.  I think
>           Malachy knew this to be true, which is why he wanted to have small
>           outdoor intimate events.  I'm going to focus my energy on creating
>           real outdoor rave rituals of sound.  If they can be legal, fine.
>           If not well, I hope we don't have to resort to the tactics of the
>          Spiral Tribe here but if that has to happen then so be it.

I totally agree...   I go to raves not only to schmooze and enlighten folks
on how they can protect their privacy,    but I also go for the totally 
awsome vibes,  exercize and refreshing mind enhancement that happens at
a rave.

Unfortuately,  raves DO take a lot out of my 50 yr old body.   The 12 hours
of continious dancing hardly phases me as long as I recognize my limitations
and deal with it in my own way,  by making good use of the chill out rooms
to do my yoga and stretching every so often.   I can proudly say that I can
do this WITHOUT DRUGS,  but I don't abhore the use of them by others,  as
I have always adopted a "Live and let live" attitude.

My biggest complaint is the heavy smoking going on EVERYWHERE... with no place
to go except outside (And THAT don't work if the establishment don't allow
"in's and out's").    I suffer immensely but it's a relativly small price I
have to pay to enjoy the rave scene.

I make a plea to the rave organizors to establish a smoke free chill out room
where allergic people like me can have a refuge and a break from the stale
smokey air.    This will not only increase the amount of ravers,  but will
get and encourage others to enjoy raving that normally cannot do it.

My recovery times take about 2 to 3 weeks,  depending on
the amount of smoke exposure I'm subjected to,  thus severly limits my raving,
unless I can catch an "outdoor event" which I haven't yet done.

I think that raves are a very healthy thing,  in fact,  it's the most heathy
trend thats come down the pipes in a long time.

Someone else has asked for some comments on the 60's era for those that have
been around that long.   I think the 90's are lots more healthey than the
60's were,  because of the rave music energy and lots of dancing that goes
on.    But remember,  that all it takes is for some dude that cannot handle
his drugs to ever-exert and die.    This will give raving a bad name,  so
lets do this with SOME moderation....  So far,  the scene is really great
and I promote it whole heartedly...  With that,  I got nothing else to say
other than "Rave on dudes!!..." and "Fight the clipper chip!".

Cheers
Cap'n Crunch
(An old hacker from another era)

Correction: after hashing it out in email, the song that Pete really
dug at the Sunday Grateful Dead show in Las Vegas was "Franklin's
Tower", with the lyric "You better roll away, roll away the dew".
This is not even remotely similar to "Morning Dew" which is a
beautiful ballad, and it also not remotely similar to "Terrapin
Station" which is an epic poem... I just took the +30 minute figure
and the 4/4 with incredible Jerry guitar, and decided that he must
have meant Terrapin.  Sorry.  I'll spank myself now.

Yeah, you say now "who cares?" but remember this, and you'll be able
to bond more fully with your deadhead brothers at the next post-show
atomic rooster type gathering :-)

Bob

From SFRaves-request@medisg1.Stanford.EDU  Mon May 17 16:28:06 1993
Received: from medisg1.Stanford.EDU by soda.berkeley.edu (5.65/KAOS-1)
	id AA06685; Mon, 17 May 93 16:28:06 -0700

Subject: Earth Beat

Earth Beat was a great time out there in Berkeley.  The party was nice and 
small in an appropriately sized place with lots of good vibes and dancing
energy.  Had a map point too, which I think is a good thing these days.

Mike was talking to Martin and he said that a Basics was coming up sometime
this summer.  Is this cool or what?  I can't wait to see all those familiar
faces again....

Went to DNA (afterlife) and had abig bummer:  those booths upstairs by the 
windows (my favorite spots there) have been moved out and replaced with
pool tables, and the windows covered with black shades.  Oh well, no more
afterlife for me, unless they move somewhere better.

The beach was happening nicely, basically a chill spot with a big stereo
to listen to.  I love these things.  I wish they had decided to locate at
the end of John Daly blvd. as the other party last week.  Maybe next time.
At one point a guy got on the mike and said that the party would be there
every weekend from now on, so hope to see you all there in the future.

Peace
Zak

From: bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu (Brian Behlendorf)
Date: Mon, 17 May 1993 16:43:07 -0700
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Subject: Weekend Update

        Groove Kitchen was definitely the place to be.  No attitude, lots
of smiling people, lots of familiar faces and at the same time lots of new
faces of people who seemed eager to mesh with the crowd.  The sound system
was nice and superclean (those Community speakers are great!).  The visuals
were great, especially downstairs in the wondeful ambient lounge (the best
ambient lounge I've been in inawhile, perhaps EVER - very little sound
bleeding from the main floor upstairs, tons of visuals, two Van Der Graff
generators (those balls of glass filled with plasma and an single electrode
shooting sparks to the surface, especially to where you touch it).  However,
my knee and back have been hurting me, and I couldn't dance for more than
about 15 minutes at a time :(  So I spent most of my time doing my Rip Van
Wrinkle imitation downstairs.... I didn't sleep Friday night (project at
work) so I couldn't help but catch some Z's there.

        So anyways, the next morning I hook up with Graham (one of the
guys responsible for trying to get the permits for GG Park).  The GGNRA
people are really dragging their feet on the whole issue and basically 
treating us like dirt as far as getting the permits and such.  The next
target date, bvtw, is May 30th to get the ball rolling, but if these 
parties at the beach can continue Graham might just stop trying to get
GG Park going.  

        Anyways we made a couple of trips playing "rave taxi", went and
picked up a generator, and planned on getting something together at the end of
Noriega street, about 6 blocks south of Lincoln in the sunset district,
where Noriega meets the ocean.  To make a long story short, the sound system
never arrived, and Graham and I told the approx 150 people who showed up
there to head down to Sloat where the other party was.  We left to return
the generator and go home, rather angry at the sound not showing but happy
that there was at least another party going on.

        Anyways, this is the second time a party I've been involved with
has had sound system problems.  This is not a good trend :(.

        Glad people had fun at the beach, I was just too exhausted by
all this to try and make it (plus I had an exam this morning to study for).
Hopefully the people throwing those parties will allow a wide variety of
DJ's to spin there.....

        Take care.

        Brian

Hi all!

Hope everyone had a good weekend.  I sure did!

Decided to try something new this week--got massive
sleep on Friday night hoping to be fully charged
for Saturday.  It made a BIG difference.  Try it.

that I will ever dance the same way I used to.

From: Fred Heutte <phred@well.sf.ca.us>
Message-Id: <199305181103.AA05536@well.sf.ca.us>
To: pashdown@slack.sim.es.com, sfraves@medisg1.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Re:  A raver's view of the Grateful Dead

I'm glad to see pashdown had a good time at the Vegas Dead shows!
I wasn't able to make it thanks to an overloaded work schedule,
but  I will be down in California for the Shoreline (Mountain View)
and Cal Expo (Sacramento) shows next week.  Definitely will catch
some ravetime too, I had a fairly disappointing stint on my last
swing at the end of last month with only the moderate enjoyable
GK at Big Heart City to show for it.

I think the rave and GD scenes are perfectly well compatible as long
as one accedes to the fact they are basically in parallel universes
with little awareness of each other (although that's changing a little).
Some of the Dead's drums-n-space time has been pretty ravey itself
over the last year (I'm waiting for someone to go back through the
tapes and grab some of the better GD samples to throw down with the
usual platters ;).

As for microraves at the Dead 'mall,' it's already been done at least
twice -- Atomic Rooster (Chinese New Years) and Shrove Tuesday (Mardi
Gras) at the Oakland Coliseum parking lot.  I missed the first but
had a fine time at the second after the Dead show -- a pretty decent
crowd going on at least two hours past the end of the show.  Took
a Deadhead friend of mine through, someone with totally no rave
experience, and he thought it was great!

I find the Dead and rave scenes each to be curative of what I perceive
to be some of the shortcomings in the other.  But just as jazz and
bluegrass are two quinessential forms of American music that have very
little crossover points culturally, I think rave and the Dead scene
are destined to go their separate ways.

>> I felt that the two scenes
>> weren't so different after all.  Each of them striving for that one
>> solitary moment where you just don't care about life's problems
>> anymore.

>Precisely.  The goal is the grand "ego dissolve", which occurs when
>the feeling that life's problems don't matter anymore is strengthened
>and generalized.  ...

>Enough of my blithering, but yes, there is a strong strong connection
>between the peak moments of the rave experience and the peak moments
>of the deadhead experience, the routes are different, but the result
>is the same.  I absolutely see this, and have had equally intense
>moments at both events.  Call me a dual-citizen, if you will.

--- End of included mail from ames!us.oracle.com!groovy!boccibob

yes, i agree, the 2 scenes *are* remarkably similar in intent, i got
that impression at 2 dead shows I attended last December.  There were
lots of ravers at those (Oak Coli.) shows too, which added to the feeling
that there was a connection.  Now *some* ravers CAN'T STAND the dead
(yo lowone) and I'm sure there are dheads that hate raves but still,
the common points greatly outweigh the differences.  so......on that note...

Date: Tue, 18 May 93 10:04:02 -0700
From: ccat@netcom.com (ccat)
Message-Id: <9305181704.AA10288@netcom3.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@medisg1.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Sound system

   One alternative as far as the speakers are concerned
is to build our own.The markup on speakers is astronomical.I have a friend
who used to build professional speakers who could give us advice..
Good drivers don't come cheap..but they are far cheaper than buying
manufactured speakers of low quality..
 I'm not a professional sound person,but I do know that the quality
of sound depends largely on the speakers and cabinets...and a good
speaker of high efficiency,can make even a low powered amp sound much
more powerful than it would sound on a speaker of lower efficiency.
Ported, "bass reflex" designs are the easiest high efficiency speakers to
manage...   A+S speakers (23rd and Shotwell in SF) sell lots of drivers and are
a great local resource..We should get several opinions..

Just a data-point.
-Chris.

Brian last time I was out.  "Tribal" is an understatement when it comes to
describing it, and it certainly wouldn't be out of place at any rave.

of metal.  Made me wonder if we'd be seeing Einstuerzende Neubauten opening
for them next year.

Subject: Re: Sound system/Miracle

speaking of sound systems, i have a couple of questions:

1.  anybody got the phone number for shredder?

2.  anybody got the phone number for other sound systems rental people?

3.  anybody got any solid info about what sound companies are good to work
    with and which ones to avoid?  in particular, who are the sound company
    or companies that have been flaking and not showing up?  that i *do not*
    need to deal with if i can avoid it...

4.  if i wanted to rent stuff in another city, can anyone tell me what 
    power/capacity/quality requirements and/or brand names to look for
    and/or avoid?

Beyond the ultraworld of ccat:
> 
>    One alternative as far as the speakers are concerned
> is to build our own.

It is a good way to go, but do not cut corners. Use flimsy wood and you will
have to start again. You also have to think in terms of size. What size can
you move? If you only have a car, you will find it problematic.

>The markup on speakers is astronomical.

It's very true, but if you count the numerous hours of work you'll have to put,
then maybe it is not as attractive to build your own. If i had the money, i
would buy a stack of Community speakers and monitors. They are small, efficient
and they sound incredible. But i didn't have the $ so i built mine. They are
very efficient but they are HUGE. I will probably do the same design in
hybrid for road use.

>  I'm not a professional sound person,but I do know that the quality
> of sound depends largely on the speakers and cabinets...

And the xover is also very important. A passive crossover is the cheapest
solution while an active xover with dual amping sounds much better, is more
efficient and saves you lots of work but cost a lot because of the bi-amps.

> and a good
> speaker of high efficiency,can make even a low powered amp sound much
> more powerful than it would sound on a speaker of lower efficiency.

And not to forget that you have to double the wattage to add 3db of SPL.

> Ported, "bass reflex" designs are the easiest high efficiency speakers to
> manage...

Hybrids can achieve the SPLs of bassreflex designs while taking 1/4 of cubage.
They are more stable in terms of impedance and you can design 2ohm or 4ohm
systems easily (of course the amp must be designed for these loads so that the
power transfer is maximized). The disadvantage of hybrids is the cost: you
need two bass drivers (connected together with the rim and electrically
connected in a push-pull way: the + of the first connected to the - of the
other and vice-versa). I have a lot of experience in cabinet designs, so if
help is needed, i'm here. In the case of drivers, i have no idea which to use.

Ciao,
-- 
Francois Dion

>   Has anyone ever seen a mixer that varies *reverberance(delay _time_) and
> level control via a joystick control....

Think "modular".  Don't go for the mixer just because it has a built in
sampler, effects unit, or ice maker.  It is much better to have things like
this external.  One thing you should look for is the ability for the mixer to
cue effects or treat them as a separate line.

As for effects boxes, the Boss SE-50 (and now SE-70) is probably the most
robust and powerful.  The Ensonique DP4 is also really hot because it can do
spatial processing which I haven't found from any other company.

From SFRaves-request@medisg1.Stanford.EDU  Tue May 18 16:04:11 1993

To: "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@medisg1.Stanford.EDU>
Subject: Re: Sound system idea.. Holophonic/cybersonic
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Tue, 18 May 93 12:43:03 PDT."
             <9305181943.AA03494@medisg.Stanford.EDU> 
Date: Tue, 18 May 93 15:17:43 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>


From: ccat@netcom.com (ccat)
>Anyone familiar with programming audio dsp ..particularly simulating different
>binaural environments..? Lets make the future SFRaves sound system _truly_
>a force to be reckoned with and _truly_ representative of our computer based
>background! ;)

Well, you can get a roland sound space (RSS) unit from Roland Pro
Audio, the only problem is that (a) you have to pick the appropriate
sound sources (e.g. a voice or lead instrument) that can be distinctly
localized in 3-space; (b) the units cost approx $21,500 for 4 channels
(i.e. place 4 distinct sound sources somewhere in <x,y,z> 3-space). The
unit does come with a controller that allows you to dial-in sounds in
3-space, and is  MIDI controllable as well.

Unlike many of the VR-ish 3d sound environments, the RSS claims to 
work over loudspeakers. In actuality, i think you have to pick your
sound sources and overall soundscape quite carefully in order for the
3-D sound effect to work. Various albums have been recorded w/ this
technology, including some techno stuff whose name escapes me  right
now -- you can tell whether RSS was used because the cover or track
listings contain a box with the letters RSS....

More affordable systems are available to plug into your computer.
The following are oft used in creating 3-D sound for virtual reality
environments -- as far as know, these only work over headphones:

	(1) Bo Gehring, In Focus Systems of Toronto sells  a 3-D sound card 
	    that plugs in to your macintosh.... (toronto-area-code)963-9188
	(2) Crystal River Engineering Convolvotron -- plug it into
	    yer IBM PC -- ask the company for software to do the 3-D synthesis.

Alternately, you can put the 3-D effect into your source material. Bob
Clearmountain audio sample CD roms have some sounds that have been 3-D
enhanced by RSS. I've also sampled sound effects off of roland's RSS
demo CD and that can be fun too....

There are other systems available as well, but they're all in the 
astronomical price ranges suitable only to pros and studios, e.g.
Archer Communication Q-Sound (rental only, $300.00/day includes
technician), Audio+Design "Ambisonics" ($12,000). There are a bunch of
me-too products out there on the market to capitalize on this exciting
field, however, at least one of them that I saw/heard was pure
unadulterated snake oil. So be careful.

Or wait. I expect this stuff will come down in price in the next 5
years, and hopefully all the sleazy snake oil vendors will be out of
business. Furthermore, for an SFR sound system, we should probably
stick to the basics -- you can buy a significant amount of PA and 
amplification for the cost of any of the above 3-D audio processors.

I was actually trying to CON-vince my previous employer (Hewlett-
Packard Laboratories) to purchase one of the above 3-D systems for some
computer controlled 3-D audio experiments I was doing in Human-Computer
Interaction and Multimedia. Unfortunately, instead of doing that, they
nuked our lab and offered us all generous voluntary severance payments
if we promised to quit... well, I'm 3.5 months into my 11 month paid
vacation, and I'm loving it...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==           Niels Mayer -- netcom!mayer -- mayer@netcom.com               ==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

PS: want more info -- here's an old article I posted to netnews:

Newsgroups: rec.music.synth
From: mayer@hplnpm1.hpl.hp.com (Niels P. Mayer)
Subject: Re: Roland Sound Space
In-Reply-To: mir@chorus.chorus.fr's message of 14 Oct 92 14:02:27 GMT
Date: Thu, 22 Oct 1992 03:42:28 GMT
Organization: Hewlett-Packard Labs, Media Technology Lab, Palo Alto, CA.


From mir@chorus.chorus.fr (Adam Mirowski):
> Has anyone heard the new Roland Sound Space system?
> Does it work in your opinion?

Yes. I picked up the Roland demo disk at AES -- the effect works, IMHO. The
music on it is pretty sucky, some bad rap, bad pop, bad soul, bad heavy
metal, and bad film music. I guess demomusique is not much of an art form...

From: smithj@hpsad.sad.hp.com (Jim Smith)
> Suzanne Cianni used it on (I think) "Hotel Luna."  On her piece "Rain,"
> for example, she said she used it to put each note in just the right
> place.  Well, maybe I heard it and maybe not.  I'm still not sure.  It's
> certainly a subtle effect for the money!

This piece is on the RSS sampler disk that I got from Roland. It is one of
the poorest demos of the 3-D effect. (and the music is kinda lame too; then
again, i'm not into effete new age/classical crap).

Fortunately, the demo disk is an excellent source for 3-D'd samples :-)
(speaking of 3-D samples, i noticed that some of the bob clearmountain drum
sample cd-roms claim they use RSS...).


--------------------

The papers I've read on the RSS indicate it uses a combination of
techniques. The RSS's "binaural processor" uses HRTFs (head related
transfer functions) to calculate the spectral shaping caused by the
interaction of the pinna (earlobes) with the sound source location.  The
RSS "transaural processor" uses some means of crosstalk-cancellation in
order to make the output of the binaural processor work on speakers.
The HRTF'd output from the "binaural processor" goes to the headphone jacks.

HRTFs are the psychoacoustic basis of alot of work in "3-D virtual acoustic
displays" used in VR (virtual reality) applications. For example, VPL's
high-end VR systems use a Convolvotron from Crystal River Engineering to
synthesize HRTFs thereby allowing you to not only see a synthesized
3-dimensional world, but also hear a 3-dimensional world.

There's been a lot of work in this subject by Elizabeth Wenzel and Durand
Begault (NASA Ames Rsch Ctr), Fred Wightman and Doris Kistler (U
Wisconsin), and Scott Foster (Crystal River Engineering). What Roland has
done is take alot of American university and research lab technologies and
commercialize it.... I guess that's cool, except that we (Universities,
NASA, companies w/ research labs like HP, Bell, IBM, DEC, Xerox) should
attempt to do a slightly better job of hanging on to revolutionary
technologies that may make big bucks in the future (when pricing drops
enough to allow VR to go fully commercial). Hell, like I should talk... the
Convolvotron groundwork was done at HP Labs... <censored>.

FYI, the best introductory material on 3-D sound can be found in "Cyberarts
-- exploring art & technology" edited by Linda Jacobsen (Miller Freeman
Inc, ISBN 0-87930-253-4). Included there is an article by C.Chan from
Roland on the RSS system, as well as articles by Wenzel & Begault on HRTFs,
and Foster on the Convolvotron.

There's also a more in-depth article (with full references) by Wenzel,
Wightman and Kistler in the proceedings of ACM CHI '91 conference. I just
happen to have a review of the article from my trip report to that
conference:

| * "Localization by Inexperienced Listeners Using Non-Individualized
|    3-D auditory display cues"
|    Elizabeth M. Wenzel, NASA-Ames Research Center
|    Frederic L. Wightman, University of Wisconsin
|    Doris J. Kistler, University of Wisconsin
| 
| In contrast with the <censored> paper/talk reviewed above, this talk was real
| "science." People localize the direction a sound is coming from through the
| perception of interaural differences in time of low-frequency
| sound-arrival, as well as interaural differences in intensity at high
| frequencies.  Further localization occurs when sound waves interact with
| the pinnae (outer ears). Pinnae shape the spectrum of the sound, changing
| the spectrum with different locations. The effects of such spectral shaping
| needs to be simulated (via digital filters, convolvotron) if the sound is
| to be simulated for use with headphones. Unfortunately, each person's
| pinnae are slightly different, and would result in different spacially
| induced spectral shaping. The experiment tests whether it is feasible to
| create a "three dimensional auditory display" that does not need to be
| calibrated to individual subjects. The simulated spacial effects are
| derived from one subject whose pinnae-induced spectral shaping is derived
| from the "head related transfer function" (HRTF). HRTF is measured by
| putting microphones in a model of the head and pinnae of a "good
| localizer". The reference subject has been "behaviorally calibrated" for
| correlation with measured sound direction.
| 
| The experiments determined that "In general, the data suggest that most
| listeners can obtain useful directional information from an auditory
| display without requiring the use of individually-tailored HRTFs,
| particularly for the direction of azimuth."  The main problem noted is that
| people tend to have "mirror image" perception problems in localizing sound,
| e.g. back<-->front and up<-->down confusions. The discussion section
| mentions that these could be artifacts of their experimental method of
| determining real (non-headphone) location by a blindfolded person in an
| anechoic chamber listening to one of 6 speakers placed in a moveable
| semi-circle. Reflections of room acoustics may play a big role in
| disambiguating up from down and front from back.
| 
| This is a very interesting, detailed paper and the presentation almost felt
| like a science version of Shelock Holmes sleuthing.

--
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
	    Niels Mayer -- hplabs!mayer -- mayer@hplabs.hp.com
                     Collaborative Multimedia Project
		       Hewlett-Packard Laboratories
			      Palo Alto, CA.
				   *

Subject: vacation week rpt
To: sfraves@medisg1.Stanford.EDU
Date: Tue, 18 May 93 15:26:49 PDT
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]


Ah, vacation.  We did our annual back-to-nature thing; 4 days
of hiking in the Toiyabe National Forest (Mt. Charleston, 35
miles outside Las Vegas).  A total get-away-from-it-all trip;
no house music, not even Intermix, opting for Tangerine Dream
for the car ride.  Janie even left the walkman-for-hiking
at home this time.  Mountains, pine trees, sun, clouds, hail -
the only kind of scene that rivals or surpasses raving in the
bliss department.  

On the other end of the reality spectrum, we stopped at Vegas where
my parents live.  Spent an afternoon doing some people watching
at Ceasar's Palace.  Yes, the Dead were coming to town, and we
were amused to see the occasional deadhead wander through the
gaudy, tacky glitz of the Palace Mall, mouths agape, eyes wide open,
bumping into the Roman Statues and marble fountains.  Talk about
fish out of water.  Another more modest Hotel/Casino we visited was
overrun with deadheads.  While not all deadheads are poor and
smell bad, they sure could use a few pointers on how to play
blackjack.

As a mecca for those who wish to rub knees with the illusion of
wealth/riches/fortune and class, Vegas attracts a pretty diverse
sample of humanity.  But there wasn't a raver in sight, no rave
wear, not even the grunge look.  No surprise, for although the
casino establishment has done a lot in the sensory stimulation
department the VIBE just ain't here.  Even under the most optimum
of neurological conditions, Vegas is best experienced as a total
goof.

Plane landed in SF on Saturday, but I was just too drained to attend
the last Groove Kitchen.  Opted for the beach thing on Sunday.  The
laid back house music on the beach scene was the perfect way to ease
back into ravedom.  Did Tilt-a-Whirl Sunday night, and yes Goa Gil
assaulted us with a relentless 3 hours of hardcore trance.  He 
doesn't seem to bother much with beat matching, but I really wish
more DJs would play this kind of stuff instead of the retro 70's
disco/funk that keeps popping up.  Anyway, I'm sure looking forward
to Wicked this Sat., and for all those who keep whining about the
Sound Factory, do like me; nap until 2:00, show up at 3:00 and
turn the space into the center of the Universe where only 12-
dimensional superconscious cosmic energy patterns are capable of 
existing.

- leg of eel

Date: Tue, 18 May 93 17:05:55 PDT
From: dms!curly!grigsby@netcom.com (Spiral Death Trap)
Message-Id: <9305190005.AA20952@curly.agames.com>
To: sfraves@medisg.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Spatial Sound


I helped the Convolvotron people demonstrate their stuff at Siggraph a few
years ago ('91) -- worked better for some people than for others.  Generally
front-to-back comes out better than up-and-down localization.  It also
required you to have headphones on or your head localized between speakers
with tolerances ~1".  Head-related transofrms are neat, but necessarily
headphone-bound.

Localization in a PA is much different -- you really have to know where the
speakers are exactly in order to do anything more impressive than quad
panning (which _is_ cool but not what we're talking about).  This means
you pre-process a piece for one specific environment or you have lots of
expensive processing.

Then again, DSP prices have dropped like rocks in the past year or so.  The
possibilities broaden continuously -- note the proliferation of cheap effects
boxes that do more and more amazing stuff.

The problem is always writing software for a custom system -- you tend to
need expensive things like in-circuit emulators or at least logic analyzers
and downloader boards.  It's not much harder to do 10,000 magic boxes than
1, which is why you don't see much homebrew stuff -- everything changes so
fast that ROland will probably sell your mega-zowie processor for $299 byy
the time you're done constructing it.

// g

Thought some of you might be interested in Wednesday's Jacking
In/Cyberspace Literacy event ...

Jacking In: A Series on Cyberspace Literacy presents
ONLINE COMMUNITIES AROUND THE BAY: THE INNS AND THEIR KEEPERS

Every computer-based conferencing system lets its subscribers access 
relevant community information and discuss topics ranging from Apple 
Computers to zymurgy.  While these systems are all based on the same 
conceptual model, each one evolves its own personality and community 
standards based on underlying software, management policies, and, 
ultimately, the subscribers it attracts.

This installment of Jacking In will feature a talk about building and 
nourishment of online community, followed by community-conscious 
demonstrations of several San Francisco-based conferencing systems.

In cyberspace, community is not geography.

John Coate, "Building Online Community"
Wayne Gregori, SF Net
Alex Liberman, 101 Online
Gail Ann Williams, The WELL

$3-$5 sliding scale

Message-Id: <9305190533.AA10979@soda.berkeley.edu>
From: bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu (Brian Behlendorf)
Date: Tue, 18 May 1993 22:33:56 -0700
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Subject: The SFRaves Sound System

        A group of us have been talking about this and we thought we could/
should bring it to the list as a whole.  We're thinking about forming together
a sound system to do renegade parties this summer.  Realizing that the key
weak link in pulling a party together has been relying on sound people, we
think D.I.O (Doing It OUrseves :) is the way to go.

        Basically the way this would work is, those interested in working on
it woulfd meet and decide on exactly what needs to be bought - and then each
person would go out and buy a piece of equipment, and assemble it all together
in some central location.  Each person would still own the piece of equipment
they paid for, but the collection would rotate around this group of people
say once a week.  If a particular piece of equipment is too expensive maybe
one or two people could chip in on it. 

        The goal would be to assemble a system made out of small, easily
carryable pieces rather than two giant 6' stacks or something.  That makes
it easier to buy too ($1000 huge cabinet vs. $300 component).  In some cases
perhaps the components could be built inexpensively.

        The philosophy behind the system would be that it would be used for
outdoor, free/donation-only parties, and a small fund would be set up as a
maintanence fund in case equipment breaks or new pieces need to be bought or
something.  Having all the equipment at one place is essential in being able
to pull it together on short notice.

        Those of us who are interested should meet in person sometime soon.
Sometime next week would be perfect for me.  (I'll be gone this weekend).
If you're interested (and haven't already made your voice heard) drop me a 
line about meeting.  I'll be home next Tuesday-Friday...

        Brian

Composed by D Hermelun & G Schonewille, Taken from DJAX-UP 159.

SEQUENTIAL					SEQUENTIAL
(The Dune Mix)

Composed by Craig Peck & Pete Namlook, Taken from RSN 45.

1ST SYMPHONY					DAVE ANGEL

Composed & produced by Dvae Angel, Taken from Orchestrations.

BARBARELLA					SVEN VATH
(The Irresistible Force Remix)

Composed & Produced by Sven Vath & R Hildenbeutel, Remix by Mixmaster Morris


If you have any further enquires mail me at:

miles.pearce@bristol.ac.uk

From: geoffw@nexsys.net (Geoff White)

To: ComeUniverse@nexsys.net
Subject: The Progression of House Culture

I found this under a stack of papers that I got while attending the CyberForum
a few weekends ago...



	           THE PROGRESSION OF HOUSE CULTURE
		   ________________________________


	"As mankind moves into the new millennium, we will progressively
	leave behind the inflated value of the form level, and look more
	towards expressions of the heart" (Celtic Renaissance by 
						Alice Rigan, 1980)

	This we must do, and especially people involved with house culture.
Since evolution is the very nature of the house movement, the people involved
with it must take more responsibility.  We must demonstrate with our lives the
type of caring, sharing community attitude that is now needed so much if this
planet has any chance of getting back together as a communal family organism.
House people should be among the most highly evolved, sensitive groups in the
modern world today.  Through use of certain sacred medicines, ancient or modern,
people are beginning to see the way things really are.  Whether Rave promoters
know it or not, they provide a forum for mass personal and planetary change.
Raves can be treated as shamanic workshops.  However, this forum can so easily
be destroyed by commercialists, capitalists, and sharpsters who were robbing
banks before the raves.  Our sacred time is often someones else's fast buck.
If the people throwing events and playing the music are living old world 
lifestyles and laughing all the way to the bank, what does the new generation
have to go on?  It is up to us to teach by example.  Treating raves as just
another way to gain financial security or success will crush the movement from
within.  Here are two quotations from two articles out of the current 
nationwide Mixmag Magazine, concerning the much older house movement in Britain:

	"Raves are not always run by music lovers.  All too easily they
	become risk free, high return, black market operations.  as the
	scene exploded, the money men moved in."

	"No matter their loyalty to the scene, there aren't many ravers
	who are going to carry on getting abused by promoters and scam 
	merchants."

It is obvious that with too many years of commercial raving, the ravers will
start to become disillusioned.   There is still a healthy underground house
movement in Britain- it has nothing to do with paying 20 pounds to get in.
Here in San Francisco we have the chance to start turning things around and
giving some positive direction to the countless loyal ravers who come to these
functions to dance and expand their minds.  Our family depends on us.  Our
planet needs us.  Rave culture must be continued by people who truly care
and understand what is going on with regards to house culture and the evolution
of mankind.  We are dealing with people's minds and consciousness, not just
their cash flow.  we must maintain integrity and always always remember we have a responsibility to guide the next generation into the new millennium.


Mission Earth, 1993

Subject: hooligans turn from agression to togetherness
Reply-To: rnj%lila@us.oracle.com

Quote from "MDMA - The View from England", by Nicholas Saunders,
in the MAPS Newsletter (Multidisciplinary Association for
Psychedelic Studies), Spring 1993, Vol IV, No. 1.

   It may well be that MDMA has actually had a beneficial effect in Britain.   
Last season saw a large reduction in football violence.  Mark Gilman from  
Lifeline in Manchester is conducting a two year study of a sample of young  
men in the north west including 'football hooligans'.  He says "in their  
transition from hooligan to raver these young men spurned excessive use of  
alcohol in favor of ecstasy.  Conversations were no longer about which team's  
'lads' could be ambushed where and when. Rave culture and ecstasy use have  
become more attractive than using large amounts of alcohol and running around  
the streets looking for fights with opposing football fans.  MDMA use  
encourages a desire for friendship and togetherness, not aggression."  It is  
not that MDMA is cheaper, the cost of a good night out is about the same.   
However, he tells me that the shortage of good 'E' this season has caused a  
return to alcohol along with other drugs, and he fears a return to the  
previous levels of violence.

   There is no reason to believe that this change of behaviour is restricted  
to football fans.  Just as LSD in the sixties caused lasting cultural  
changes, I believe that the widespread use of MDMA now is laying down the  
foundations of new, as yet undefined, social values.  And i believe it will  
be a largely positive change.
  [...]
  There are those who think that MDMA can be stamped out by a scare campaign  
or heavy use of the law, and others who believe that it is a passing fad.   
MDMA is here to stay for a simple reason"  it provides access to an  
experience that human beings value.

---------------------------

MAPS is a non-profit, membership-based organization working to assist  
psychedelic researchers around the world design, obtain governmental  
approval, fund, conduct and report on psychedelic research in humans. [...]   
If you can even faintly imagine a cultural re-integration of the use of  
psychedelics and the states of mind they engender, please consider joining  
MAPS in supporting the expansion of scientific knowledge in this area.

	MAPS / 1801 Tippah Avenue / Charlotte, NC  28205
	704 358-9830 voice 704 358-1650 fax

---------------------------

Nicholas Saunders recently (April 1993) published a sparkling, 320 page book,  
E for Ecstasy.  It covers MDMA's therapeutic use, the British rave scene,  
scientific research concerning MDMA, the political situation...  The book  
contains a 79 page bibliography by Alexander Shulgin, a 73 page reference  
section with synopses, and several other appendices.  It's available from

	N. Saunders / 14 Neal's Yard / London WC2H 9DP England

Write (or call +44 071 836 9404) for info - a 37% discount is available for  
orders in multiples of five copies.

Subject: The Ultimate(tm) Renegade Sound System



	OK folks,
	I have a friend in Baltimore who builds sound systems.

	He is REAL good at it and builds them out of the joy that he
	gets from the technical challenge and the joy others get from
	listening to the Systems that he builds.

	I've been talking to him about building me a portable fairly light
	ass kickin sound system.  He is not a raver and only has a few "techno"
	compilations in his collection but he knows how to build a system
	taylored to the type of music that will be played on it.


	What I need to know from the group is what are the key variables.

	So far I think I need:  

	2- way operation (bass on one amp mid and highs on the other)
	Portability (i.e. light and not to bulky)
	Rugged casing.


	What I need to know is stuff like 
	how much bass power at what frequencies (he says he can build technology
	that can go down around 20 Hz but it would cost in money/power)

	Remember this system is being designed for OUTDOOR PARTIES.

	So all you audio dudes and dudettes please give me feedback.

>>>>> On Wed, 19 May 93 07:26:51 PDT, geoffw@nexsys.net (Geoff White) said:

  Geoff> I found this under a stack of papers that I got while
  Geoff> attending the CyberForum a few weekends ago...

[...]

  Geoff> There is still a healthy underground house movement in
  Geoff> Britain- it has nothing to do with paying 20 pounds to get
  Geoff> in.

Liked the post.  Dunno to what extent this is the norm, but most of
the events I go to at the moment are small free parties put on by a
local soundsystem.  They do it because they have fun doing it.  The
locations don't cost them anything -- usually a squat or someones
house, maybe outdoors when the weather gets better.  The DJ's spin for
free.  Sometimes there's a colection to help pay for the hire of the
amps and speakers.  These parties happen most weeks, and if people
don't know where the next one is, they know that if they turn up to
the right pub they'll probably find someone who knows...

From what I hear, the scene's much the same elsewhere, though I'm
fairly new to the scene, so I couldn't really say...

    Rave on,

	Cosmic Roy

> 
> 
> >	2- way operation (bass on one amp mid and highs on the other)
> 
> This is usually called "bi-amping".  Given the use outdoors, ideally
> you should have a summed mono bass / stereo mids/highs crossover.
> This would improve overall bass response in the space, and keep the
> important parts stereo.
>
Yeah! Thanks.


 
> >	What I need to know is stuff like how much bass power at what
> >	frequencies (he says he can build technology that can go down
> >	around 20 Hz but it would cost in money/power)
> 
> You definitely want to go down to 20 Hz.  At a minimum, you want to go
> down to 40 Hz.  This shouldn't be too hard with a bi-amp scheme, so
> that you have subwoofers which go from 20 Hz - 200 Hz or so, and then
> mids and highs.  However, this doesn't really square with:
> 
> >	Portability (i.e. light and not too bulky)

I would think that with HOUSE music I should be going for as much bass
as possible or a more balanced toward mid range? Any body know?

Well I don`t think about cars when I talk about moving it.
A Two car or small pickup solution is fine, I basiclly want to be able
to "rapidly deploy it. And maybe "scoop it up" quick too.
But definitely would like to be able to set up in 5 - 15 minutes MAX.


> 
> as a good subwoofer will need to be at least 1 foot x 1 foot x 1 foot
> and weigh around 20-30 pounds.  This is pretty much minimum, and you'd
> want four of these most likely to generate enough bass.
>

My friend claims he has some sort of "circular" tube bass technology I'll
talk this over with him.

 
> In general, I think that it's definitely possible to put together a
> sound system which can be moved around in a really big car, but you're
> going to need a generator anyway, so you might as well shoot for
> something which fits in a small pickup.
> 
> Bob
> 
>
Koowel.  What kind of amps should I get?

From: Bob Ramstad <us.oracle.com!rramstad@nexsys.net>
To: geoffw%nexsys@apc.org
Cc: sfraves%nexsys@apc.org, groovy!us.oracle.com!boccibob@apc.org
In-Reply-To: Geoff White's message of Wed, 19 May 93 13:08:41 PDT <9305192008.AA11464@nexsys.nexsys.net>
Subject: The Ultimate(tm) Renegade Sound System
Reply-To: us.oracle.com!boccibob%groovy@nexsys.net


>> This is usually called "bi-amping".  Given the use outdoors, ideally
>> you should have a summed mono bass / stereo mids/highs crossover.
>> This would improve overall bass response in the space, and keep the
>> important parts stereo.

I neglected to mention there's a kit for this in the Old Colony Sound
Labs catalog, if you can't find another source, the kit is $69 and
you'd need a power supply kit at $99 too.  No cases, but otherwise
everything required.

> I would think that with HOUSE music I should be going for as much bass
> as possible or a more balanced toward mid range? Any body know?

I'd say you want roughly double the number of woofers/subwoofers as
you do midranges/tweeters.  My best guess as what would make sense:

4 15" woofers in cabinets for bass
	powered by a good PA amp, like a Crown or Peavy
	may need two amps, but if the first amp is selected well,
	you could start out with one amp powering all 4
	and then buy a second later to get extra oomph if needed
	I'd recommend something rated at 400-600w/ch in stereo operation
	another option would be 6-8 12" woofers, but then you'd
	definitely need 2 amps and you'd spend more overall
2 midrange/horn tweeter cabinets
	my guess here is that you should go for a passive crossover
	between the mids and highs, and I'd also recommend that you
	use two - four midrange drivers, and a single superloaded horn tweeter
	power these with a quality amp, it's OK if the bass amp is
	a little muddy (but very powerful) but this amp needs to be
	cleaner, and doesn't need to be nearly as powerful, 100 w/ch
	should be fine (brand recommendations, anyone?)
active summed mono bass / stereo mid/high crossover

> My friend claims he has some sort of "circular" tube bass technology
> I'll talk this over with him.

These can work well if designed properly, but can be boomy if not.
Well designed enclosures for the speakers are a must, regardless of
the shape.  

> A two car or small pickup solution is fine, I basiclly want to be able
> to "rapidly" deploy it. And maybe "scoop it up" quick too.  But
> definitely would like to be able to set up in 5 - 15 minutes MAX.

Most of the time setting up a system isn't in moving the gear, it's
putting the connections together.  If you have all of the gear in your
possession and it's stable, you can optimize the connections and make
it REALLY SIMPLE to hookup.  A good trick here is to color code / tag
/ tape everything so that completely non-technical people can hook up
the speakers without any more direction than "match the colors".

Budget?  My guess is that you'll spend around $600 for the bass amp,
roughly the same for the mid/high amp, around $1000 for
woofers/mids/tweeters (4 woofers at about $60, 8 mids at about $40, 2
horns at about $100, plus slack), who knows? on the cabinets, depends
on your friend, but maybe as much as $600-$1000, and then good strong
cables and connectors could run you another $500 or so.  Total cost in
the $3000+ range.  This system should be comparable to the standard
FMR setup but with more bass, and my guess is that it would be a lot
cheaper.

Of course, there are a lot of advantages to buying off-the-shelf PA
cabinets, primary being that you can listen to the results before
investing a bunch of money in cabinet materials which are wasted if
the resulting cabinet doesn't work well.

Just a bunch of conjecture, but I've worked in clubs and ran my own DJ
outfit where I hauled gear all over eastern WA for 4 years... but I'm
sure there are people out there on the list who know more than I about
this.

We should coordinate this, I'd like to see the SFR sound system
happen, and I could see myself buying into it if there was the
possibility of seeing some of the $$ returned at some point through
donations collected at events.

Bob

Subject: talk show


hello

did anyone see the Lifetime talk show Jane Pratt?
they had "Ecstacy and Raves" as the topic last night.

the show had 3 ravers (2 guys and 1 girl), 1 promoter (Scotto), 
1 NY dj (don't remember the name), one young lady doctor who goes
to raves with her doctor friends, and some filmaker named Duane who
is a big fan of the current war on drugs.

the show was ok as far as talk shows go.  it definitely focused on the
use of E at raves and the pros and cons of E and generally anything to
do with E.

the Dj complained about this as did others.

the 3 ravers were sometimes too enthusiastic and excited to
be taken real seriously by the studio audience, especially one
guy who was wearing shorts.
 
the doctor seemed to come from a psychiatric background and was not
as clear and authoritative as you would hope.  she did explain the
MPTP/Parkinsons confusion but was vague about the spinal fluid rumor.

both of these were put forward by Duane the well informed drug warrior.

i thought the funniest part of the show was when some lady in the
audience started yelling at the girl raver asking if "she ever planned
on having kids?"  and telling her that "her babies were going to be
mutated by all the drugs she used to take."

makes me wonder if a lot of bored New Yorkers go on this show
just to say ridiculous stuff.  maybe she was a plant - hired by
the show to spice things up?  or maybe it was a fairly typical
antidrug rant.

dave

P.S.  the doc did try to explain that E doesn't cause mutated babies.

To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu, sfraves-calendar@soda.berkeley.edu
Subject: This week's RAVE guide

	Hi gang!  I'm calling in from LA long-distance so this'll
have to be short... I was gonna do this last night but soda decided
to veto that idea, as it was down right up to the time I had to leave.
Anyways, I don't have much to recommend for Friday night, but it might
be a good chance to see what the inside of 16th and Harrison looks like 
for $5 :)  Saturday night I'd recommend you set your luv phasers to STUN
and make a Wicked vibe, tho Foundation could be cool, and FLO definitely
looks intriguing (I for one will always champion the cause of the unheard
DJ and/or party, so I would go even to just see what's up on your way
to wherever else).  Last Sunday there was a beach party where Sloat meets
the great highway, and they *say* they're gonna try and have it there each
week, tho I don't have a phone # for them yet.  Graham & co. may try
a party this Sunday as well, so call the phone # listed....

	Have fun!

	[Come with your luv phasers set to STUN]  415-512-5713

	return time of late Sunday night.

Here are some weeklies - whether or not they count as real "raves" is 
debatable, but they were advertised by fliers and the music could be
good. If anyone can provide reviews of them, i.e., their 
appropriateness in being on the list, let me know....

Fridays - Mission Rock - DJ's James and Gavin (from Tweekin Records)
	& others.  Outside dance floor. In China basin at 17th and Illinois.
	Phone  415-241-8862  	Visuals by Synergy (hi Tony!)

        695-7887.  842 Valencia @ 19th St.

	[from the Love Garage people]

CONNECTION 2 TAPES are still available from Bob Ramstad,
boccibob%groovy@us.oracle.com.  It's a 4-tape set, with music by
Moonpup, Scott Hardkiss, Jon Drukman, Lee, and Blurrrr - the tapes are
$20, plus $5 shipping (unless you pick it up in person) $5 of which
goes to the Malachy O'Brien trust fund.

----------------------------Original message----------------------------
I saw the following posted on another mailing list.  I was wondering if
there is anyone else out there who has heard about this, or can verify
it?

***********************************************************************

Original message: "ACTION ALERT"


Time for Social Work Advocacy:

The Internet as we know it may be at risk by our Congress.
A bill written by Rep. Rick Boucher (D, Virginia), chair of the House
Science Subcommittee will remove government subsidies and place control
with the telephone companies.  A likely consequence will be a substantial
increase of cost to universities with the likelihood that some will
drop out or charge for use by individuals.

This not only threatens CUSSnet, but all other academic uses of the nets.
Perhaps it is time to notify our representatives of the value of the
internet for educational, scientific, and other scholarly uses.

Additional information can be found in "Colleges and Telephone
Companies Battle over the Future of the Internet", page A25,
The Chronicle of Higher Education, vol. 39 #37, May 19, 1993.

The MOTHER EARTH SHOUND SYSTEM outdoor sunset gathering
Saturday, May 22, 3 pm-very late
will be at Berkeley's Aquatic Park

* from SF/South Bay...
	Take 880 to the University Ave. exit
	Take University to 6th St. and turn RIGHT
	Take 6th to Dwight and turn RIGHT
	Follow Dwight til it deads ends at the railroad tracks
	Park, walk across the tracks, down the hill, veer right, and listen

* from Berkeley/East Bay...
	Take University west to 6th St. and turn LEFT
	see above

Public transportation...
	Take the AC Transit #51 down University to 6th, get off, etc etc

If driving, please try to park a little way from the end of Dwight and walk

If you need to hear the directions, call this number -

Whit (510) 549-6222 (his machine has directions on it, and IF THE LOCATION
CHANGES, we will post new location and directions on this machine)

or if you want to hear a human -
Scott (510) 549-6253

We hope to meet you out in the sun!!! :)

Peace,

			MOTHER EARTH SOUND SYSTEM

	We just got another Sound System Designer/Builder
	signed on to the renegade list and he is outlining some
	good stuff. Once again if anybody out there wants to
	join in the discussion , sign on by doing a 
	
	subscribe renegade <your name>

	in the body of a message to renegade-request@nexsys.net

	We'll keep the list going for the duration of this project
	(which will most likely result in the construction and
	delivery of a sound system)  This IS NOT the same thing as the
	sfraves sound system (although it could be) but we need sfraves
	expertise as far as making a portable, high quality system
	that Kicks (B)ASS!! We're shooting for the $3- $5 K range so all
	you techno musicians and people who know what House music should
	sound like in the great outdoors Give us a hand!

a friend sent the following email this morning.  sounds to me like there's a  
highly placed raver in the white house - she may just not know it yet!

Begin forwarded message:

Date: Mon, 24 May 93 00:43:51 -0700
From: <cortex!paul>

I have set aside this Sunday's New York Times Magazine for you.  The cover  
story is on Hillary Rodham Clinton and her political agenda.  She is quoted  
as saying "What do your lives in today's world mean?  What does it mean in  
today's world to pursue not only vocations, but to be human?  Who will lead  
us out of this spiritual vacuum?  The answer is all of us are required to  
play our part in redefining what our lives are and what they should be."  She  
talks about "defining what it means to be human going into the 21st century"  
... "how to build a society based on love and connection, a society in which  
the bottom line would not be profit and power, but ethical and spiritual  
sensitivity and a sense of community, mutual caring, and responsibility."   
She describes herself as having "a burning desire to make the world better  
for everybody" ...  They also mention someone named Michael Learner who  
discusses "developing a new spirit of cooperation, mutual caring, and  
dedication to work."

Anyway, I thought you might find some of the parallels intriguing...

Paul

Date: Mon, 24 May 93 8:59:19 BST
From: Simon Loewenthal <sloewent@lhr-sys.bru-ro.dhl.com>
Subject: Verbal Diahorrea

Thoughs for today.


Verbal Diahorrea.
I had this once in Nepal for 3 days! No, that was just plain.... STOP STOP!

I'm pleased someone said it. Yes, stateside dicussion lists do seem
to be full of the above stuff.

I can only speak on the sfraves list but, most of it is deep psychlogoy
on raving. All very well but most of its a load of crap. I think most of
the people on the list are college students who've found raving and pills,
and think its the best thing since sliced bread, and the `be all and end all'
of life!
But, they seem to be on the right track with CyberTribe and friends. Maybe
they know something we don't?

However some of the stuff they write about does have a comical value :-)

However the scene in San Fran looks very good and very positive. So I
won't cut it up, too much.

Simon the cynical, Simon the comical, Simon the _____.

Subject: Eating Crow at Wicked
To: sfraves@medisg.Stanford.EDU, wicked@netcom.com

Hi all:

Just wanted to say that even though Wicked was at Attitude Factory, I decided
to give at Try, partly because of the Wicked Communication note and also I
thought at first wicked was going to be combined with life on Fridays.

Well I had one of the best times Ive ever had at a Rave,  The Vibe there was
incredible.  The music was incredible and everybody was extremely happy.  We
got there at 1:30 and there was this long line outside and thought we would
never get in.  The line went relatively quick and we were in by 2:00. The music
was intense.  Jeno was doing this very trippy stuff with the speakers cause
incredible resonance throughout does anybody know what he was doing to cause
this? 

I left about 8:00 with a great feeling and decided to leave it that way and go
home and get some sleep.  After some sleep I went to the Dead concert to wander
around the Parking lot for awhile (is this whats called the Mall?).  First time
of ever being at one, very fun and trippy. 

The only drawback to the weekend was when somebody stole my sunglasses out of
my backpack that was in the Coat Check at Wicked.  I thought about this when I
checked the bag in but didnt think much of it because of all the times I have
checked expensive coats in.  Oh well I learned a lesson the hard way.

I take back what I said about wicked before.  It was great to see everyone on
the net.  

Later
 
NUT

	id AA19273; Mon, 24 May 93 12:33:45 PDT
Date: Mon, 24 May 93 12:33:45 PDT
From: mw@sybase.com (Michael Wertheim)
Message-Id: <9305241933.AA19273@orion.sybgate.sybase.com>
To: ne-raves@gnu.ai.mit.edu, sfraves@medisg1.Stanford.EDU
Subject: what I did this weekend
Content-Length: 2971


Jon, Jeff and I did our first Ultraviolet Catastrophe live performance this
weekend at a rave called Recess in Oklahoma City.  The rave was to feature a
live UVC performance, plus two guest DJs from New York: Joey Beltram and Keoki.

We arrived in Oklahoma City in the afternoon and formed a quick impression of
Oklahoma City -- small town in the middle of nowhere.  We got comfortable in 
our hotel room.  We tried to find Joey Beltram and Keoki but were unable to 
meet either of them.  We left for the rave at 7pm.

It was an all ages rave, average age being 17 or 18.  The rave flyers said 
that the rave would go from 6pm to 6am, and the doors did indeed open at 6pm.
There were a few people on the dancefloor from 7pm to 10pm, but it didn't 
really reach critical mass until 11pm or so.  People in general seemed to be
having a good time, but there wasn't much of a rave-y vibe going.  It reminded
me of a very hip high school dance, actually.  There were quite a few people
sitting around just watching, and the people on the dancefloor didn't dance 
with a lot of energy.  But the music wasn't too terrible, and the crowd seemed
pretty nice.

The music was varied.  Between 6pm and midnight there was a progressive house
set, a hardcore set, a breakbeat set, etc.  None of the DJs were incredibly 
impressive.  There was also an incredibly annoying MC who kept on talking over
the music.  He would say the usual MC cliches like "everybody scream", and 
everybody would scream.  And he would said "can you feel the E?", which seemed
pretty strange to me because I didn't see a single person who looked like they 
were on E.  The whole thing seemed odd to the four of us because we're used
to raves where microphones are *never* used, except maybe at the end of the
rave to thank everyone for coming and to tell them where the after party will
be.

We went on at 12:30.  Our set was about 45 minutes long and consisted of nine
songs, including "The Trip" and "Trip Harder".  The crowd seemed to enjoy it.
They continued dancing, occasionally looking up at the stage.  The oddest part
of the show was that there were bubble machines and fog machines going on all
around us, and bubbles kept on popping on the keyboards, so we kept on having
to wipe the bubble soap off the keyboards.

After our set, Joey Beltram went on to DJ.  He played a very hard hardcore set.
We were incredibly tired because we had been up since 6am traveling, and the
performance was pretty taxing as well, so after half an hour or so we went
back to our hotel room and crashed.  We heard later that the rave lasted until
7am.

We woke up at noon and knocked on the door of the hotel room that Joey Beltram
was staying in.  He answered the door, and we chatted for a while.  Then we met
Julie Jewels from Project X magazine.  Then we all then went across the street
and ate lunch in an Italian restaurant.  We finished lunch at 3, at which time
we headed to the airport to catch our planes.
