Date: Mon, 24 May 93 13:18:23 PDT
From: Jon Drukman <jdrukman@us.oracle.com>
To: sfraves@medisg1.Stanford.EDU
Subject: fear & raving in oklahoma
Reply-To: spudboy%dlsun87@us.oracle.com

RAVE & LOATHING IN OKLAHOMA CITY

so, got back from oklahoma last night.  it was very weird.  for one
thing, everybody talks with a southern accent which is disconcerting.
i felt like i had been transplanted into a TV show set in the south,
rather than actually *being* in the south, if that makes sense.  it
was very big, open, flat and cheap looking.  you can buy a really nice
house there for $30-45K.  ("lot of land" chris said.  "it's still
oklahoma" i said.  "nice view" he said.  "nice view of oklahoma" i
said, hoping that that would explain it.)

so, we get in, and one of the rave promoter's assistants picks us up
at the airport, only he doesn't really know the flight number so he
just wanders around the airline looking for people who look out of
place.  i guess he homed in on us pretty quickly, all things
considered, but it was just a symptom of how disorganized the promoter
was...

he drives us to the club, which is a converted church - nice high
ceilings.  cool.  it looks like a mess in there, and people are
erecting all sorts of paraphernalia.  the basement had flooded (i
guess they had been having lots of rainstorms there lately) and it
smelled very mildewey.  dusty cement floor.  of course since it had
been raining a lot, it was more like mud than dust...

we are pretty burned out from the flight so we ask if they've thought
about where we're staying.  nobody seems to know but the promoter asks
if we'd like a hotel.  we of course say "YES" and chris drives us to
an OK looking place that wants way too much money.  fortunately, we're
not paying, so it doesn't matter.  we hang out in our (air
conditioned!) rooms for a while and watch TV.

eventually, we get bored, and nobody calls to see what time we want to
be at the party or anything like that, so we take matters into our own
hands.  after a quick fast food dinner, we call a cab and go to the
club.  they're still setting up, even though the party was supposed to
start 30 mins prior to this, according to the flyer.  the sound guys
are testing the system using some hideous bon jovi-esque material.  we
tell them to put our tape in, and it sounds pretty good but given the
way they are driving the system, we suspect that it will only last for
about 1 hr before it craps out.

so, we're supposed to go on at 11, and it's around 7 now.  we hang
out, meet the promoters/DJs/etc.  the DJs all love us to bits and we
are actually asked to *autograph records*.  we said, "you don't really
mean that, do you?"  but they insist and are thrilled to bits when we
sign.  weird juju, bwana.

the music throughout the night is a weird melange.  some DJs play
nosebleed techno, some play breakbeat.  a really nice guy named Mike
Lombard from houston plays a mix of progressive house and old
favorites - very cool.  there was a DJ from San Francisco (Mike
Manahan) out there and he plays all the typical current SF hits -
needless to say, this was my favorite part of the evening!
  
eventually, we have to perform.  so the lights go out and the fog &
bubble machines kick into high gear.  Mike Lombard insists on
introducing us, so we come on and launch into jeff's slow/ambient
intro piece.  considering that midwesterners are still really into 160
BPM breakbeat it was pretty weird, but once the beat finally kicked
in, they started swaying appreciatively.  next track was The Trip
(original) which was the big hit for those guys - unlike here where
Trip Harder was the one.  but they whooped it up when the dead can
dance samples came in like it was michael jackson singing thriller or
something and i thought "this fame stuff ain't so bad actually."  it
was really interesting reading the crowd.  the slower, trippier stuff
didn't work too well - i guess oklahoma isn't much of a drug town.  we
certainly didn't see too many high people.  and of course it was a
no-alcohol event.

since drugs were pretty much non-existant, the only way for people to
keep going all night was for the music to be really high energy, fast
and pounding.  so, our more straightforward pounding tracks really got
people moving.  at least when the energy flagged, nobody left the
floor - they just sort of shuffled around until the beat picked up
again.

anyway, we came, we played, we conquered.  the DJs and promoters were
all over us: "you guys were great!  you kicked ass!  come play my
party in houston next month!"

after our set, we were dead tired, so we went back to the hotel and
fell asleep.  james, the promoter, said he'd be by the next day to
pick us up for a barbeque that was being held with all the DJs,
organizers & talent.  we woke up the next day and wandered out of our
room, where we bumped into Julie Jewels (NY club scene queen & editor
of Project X magazine).  she said she didn't know what was going on
with the promoters and we doubted we'd be able to find them or get to
this BBQ before we had to be at the airport.  so we knocked on Joey
Beltram's door and talked to him for a while.  we went out to lunch
with Julie & Joey and then by the time we got back to the hotel, it
was time to get to the airport.  still no sign of chris or james or
any of the organizers (and they weren't answering their phones or
pagers) so we called a cab.  while waiting we met Keoki (another NY
DJ) who was pretty cool.  eventually, the cab showed up and we bailed
on oklahoma.

pretty cool trip all in all but those promoters were really out of it.

still, it's nice to be famous and worshipped and adored and all
that... AND get paid for it!

Jon Drukman         spudboy%dlsun87@us.oracle.com        jdrukman@us.oracle.com
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Always note the sequencer - this will never let us down.

From: lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9305242115.AA07910@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: sfraves@medisg1.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Sweat & pancakes


Got into Wicked around 4 and we chilled a bit waiting for things to
settle down a little.  The dance floor was incredibly hot, even later
when the crowd thinned.  The chill rooms were very comfortable,
comparatively chilly in fact, so I can only conclude that they were
having some kind of ventilation problem.  By around 6, I finally
started to feel like I was at a rave, and started to have fun.
The music and sound system was superb.  The general ambience of the
Sound Factory left me cold however, and I never really felt comfortable
there.  I caught some Michel Jean Jarre, Kraftwerk and Laurie Anderson
in one of the chillout rooms, stuff I was into 10 years ago. 
Another room housed a pool table, and another offered a dirty carpet
under a steady drip of ceiling condensation.  There were a couple of 
screen with some standard computer animation stuff, far less mesmerizing 
than Synergy's (Tony & Co.) stuff.  There were some upstairs spaces
that were basically saunas, except that everyone kept their clothes on.

I think I'm getting too used to outdoor raving, cause I found the
heat and lack of air to be more of a distraction than usual.  I was
never able to really let go on the dance floor and I sensed that
many others were also struggling with this.  But since everyone who
has already posted had such a great time I am forced to conclude that
I am a just a wimp.  Oh well.  My better half made the mistake of not 
drinking enough fluids and she suffered greatly for it the next day.
Double oh well.

Booger Buffet was great fun, warm/friendly/happy vibe with good 
ventilation, visuals (Synergy) and free food.  The fruit salad was fine
but I broke my fork on the pancakes.  If I ever blow a flat on a Sunday
morning South of Market, I know where to get a cheap tire patch.  
Now that DNA is closed and Tilt-A-Whirl has time shifted, 
Boogie Buffet has no trouble reaching critical mass.  As another
Termiraver once said, "I'll be back."  

I was too pooped to get to the beach thing, but heard that it was
fun, except for an incident where a disgruntled surfer turned off
the generator and tried to end the party.  I'll others give a first
hand report.  Next week: Maybe the Gathering Friday nite followed
by the Malachy benefit at the End-Up Sat. morning... Oh, and let's
not forget the grand birth of My Sister's House this Thursday, or
is it next Thursday?  

- leg of eel

Subject: connection 2 tape update

Howdy, all... just a quick update on the C2 tape situation and a
general financial summary.

I had 500 sets of 4 tapes made at a cost of roughly $4,000.  The sales
of each set includes a minimum of $5 for Malachy.  At $15 towards my
expenses per set ($5 for Malachy, with an extra $5 for mail order
mailers and postage) I will break even after selling 265 sets.  So
far, I have sold roughly 130 sets.

What does this mean?  I am currently holding $650+ for Malachy and I
am planning on turning this over to the fund either a) in mid June or
hopefully b) when it hits the magic figure of $1,000 as I'd like to
have the donation be a "significant amount" and not have it roll in in
dribs and drabs (whichever comes earlier).

In addition, I'm starting to feel some financial pressure to work
harder on selling the sets, as I'm currently still almost $2,000 in
the hole.  My current plan is to take some samples with me to Boston
this weekend, and I'm also planning on taking some sets to Bay area
stores (suggestions, anyone?) to have them either buy them outright
and sell them or, if they are honest and reliable, have them do
consignment with me.

If you are out of the Bay area and have a store you frequent which
might be interested in carrying the tapes, email me a phone number and
I'll contact them.  I'll gladly send non-local stores a sample set and
an address to order the tapes wholesale.

Hopefully I can continue to sell the sets and break even without
having to lower the price significantly, as this would reduce the
overall donation to the healing fund.

So... that's the current situation.  I'll post more detailed financial
information when things wind down more.

Naturally, I'm still selling C2 sets mail order ($25, $29 non-US) and
in person ($20).  I haven't been available at events much recently,
but I'm planning on being very available the first weekend in June.

Also, the Mountain View Tower Records, at the corner of San Antonio Rd
and El Camino Real is carrying the C2 sets in the cassette techno
section for $24.99 + tax.  Many people have found this option very
convenient.  

If the sets end up for sale at any other stores in the Bay area, I'll
let people know through this list.

Thanks for all of your support, the sales so far have been quite
strong, and I'm really happy with all the positive comments and
everything!

Bob

	Well I didn't have a great time at Wicked, I had an OK time but not
	a great time.  The dance floor was too hot, and coupled with the
	"fire" in my body (first time in 70 days) I was sorta uncomfortable.
	The music was OK but didn't really get me going,  I just didn't feel
	that incredible Vibe that I'm used to feeling at a Wicked.  Maybe
	It was too big butI've been to larger wickeds, maybe it was too hot
	but I've enjoyed myself at hotter more styfling wickeds, maybe it
	was the drugs but I've been more blasted at Wickeds.  I donno, but
	eventhough the music was OK , I had few moments of real enjoyment.
	I think for me I might gauge a party by the intensity of my Trance
	and I didn't trance out that much.  But I did like seeing a lot of
	my friends and seeing folks like Jessica, Ann the Normals, and others
	did make me feel wanted.

XDZebra Review #30

        Addiction

This is all my opinion.  Flames against a review are pretty pointless, so
don't bother.  Let me know if you have any other comments though.

Review #30 Contents:
50 Years of Sunshine
Tox Uthat - A Techno Compilation
Nu-tro-gen
Twitch CD 7
System 7: 777
Fortran 5: Persian Blues
SonnenSystem: Virtual Ambience EP


50 Years of Sunshine
Silent Records: SR9333
100 Micrograms:
1       04:15 Dr. Timothy Leary: The Incredible Lightness Ov Being Molecular
2       07:03 Pelican Daughters: The Bicycle Ride
3       05:34 Closedown: Bliss
4       04:51 Love Spirals Downwards: Kykeon
5       06:20 Nurse With Wound: Beetle Crawls Across My Back
6       05:06 White Stains: Let It Be Thus
7  126  06:16 XKP & Mr. L: Thee Spirit Ov Thee Molecule
8  122  07:28 The Ultraviolet Catastrophe: Full Moon (Crescent Mix)
9  125  09:01 Nonplace Urban Field: Pseudogarten
10 129  06:45 Psychic TV: Acidosis
11 102  08:42 Earth Leakage Trip: The Awakening
250 Micrograms:
1       03:59 Phauss: Radiator (For Amanita Muscaria & Mark McCloud)
2       03:34 Belt: Under the Sunset
3       03:45 Elliot Sharp: inSERGEncy
4       15:37 Harvey Bainbridge: The Voyage - In the Wake of Passing Clouds
5       04:15 Controlled Bleeding: After the Rain
6       05:24 Hawkwind: Space Dust
7   96  05:35 68000: Disillusion
8  115  05:07 Satellite IV: In A Sugarcube
9  139  07:12 Hyperdelic: Dosed
10 168  05:47 Drome: Biopolar Trip
11 123  06:07 Steel Porn Rhino: On LSD

Comments: A wildly varied two disc compilation put out by Silent Records
celebrating Albert Hofmann's first LSD trip.  The theme is obvious, but is
presented in such different manners, that listening to this compilation
becomes a trip of its own.  With an introductory reading by Timothy Leary,
things move into a stark ambient industrial tone then gradually builds into a
dark dance ending.  Ultravoilet Catastrophe does their second release with a
transitional piece from rythmic ambience into a tribal explosion.  This is
placed perfectly on the disc as things swing into an up tempo to close off
"100 Micrograms".  PTV seems to be the odd track out, since it is more noise
based than dance, Earth Leakage Trip closes things off nicely with more of
their weirdness.  "200 Micrograms" begins in the same way with brooding
distorted lyrics over beatless noise by Phauss, then takes a different
direction into bright tones and psychedelic trance.  Harvey Bainbridge
presents a stunning Enoesque piece which puts Eno himself to shame.  As the
beat kicks in, 68000 does an incredible slow piece which is
uncharactaristically good over their miserable album.  The final four tracks
are fantastic dance with good samples.  I especially enjoy the closing by
Steel Porn Rhino.

Summary: 9/10.  An excellent tribute and a fine compilation as well.  Drop it
if you're into exploration, but if you're looking for solid dance, it probably
isn't a good idea.


Tox Uthat - A Techno Compilation
Pulse Soniq: PS9329
1  146  06:15 Orange Sky: Aeronautic Trip
2  140  07:02 Cirrus Minor: Solar Sperm
3  125  06:37 Cirrus Minor: Whales
4   98  04:02 Nonplace Urban Field: Unireverse
5  143  04:33 Nonplace Urban Field: Holding Hands
6  130  04:56 Cosmic Breeze: Carrying Galaxies
7  128  09:44 Mindope: Subsonic Soul
8  130  06:58 Brain Unltd: Atlantic Ocean
9  121  14:58 Horizon 222: Spirit Level

Comments: Very similar in form to the FAX release "Compilation 1".  Fast
trance with a touch of funk provided by Nonplace Urban Field.  NUF is unusual
in the use of vocals that sound like a radio announcer delivering Timothy
Leary lines.  Several of the tracks take advantage of my weakness for
unintelligible Cocteau Twins like female singing over distinct beats.  Mindope
attempts to cross diva and trance, and barely makes it, but slides more into
the deep house area.  Brain Unltd, Cirrus Minor, and Orange Sky are most like
the FAX trance, with sweeping melodies and steady rhythms.  Finally, Horizon
222, with members from Zoviet France, makes a gradual collage of sound that
compares favorably with Psychic Warriors ov Gaia.  This is the only group on
the compilation who is not on the Toxikktrakks label.

Summary: 8/10.  At a domestic price, this is an eclectic collection of trance
that is well worth the tag.


Nu-tro-gen
Thunderpussy: THP 2002-2
1  136  05:13 Rollin' Reptiles
2  136  04:41 Breakin' n' Bazzin'
3  136  05:02 Freakin' n' Humpin'

Comments: Bouncy techno with a bit of chipmunk thrown in.  The best part of
this short release is the two remixes.  True to its name, "Breakin' n'
Bazzin'" has some finely placed and picked breaks that make it interesting to
listen and move to.  "Freakin'" is the same but to a lesser extent, it
concentrates more on melody manipulation than rhythm.

Summary: 5/10. Too short, but moderately cool.


Twitch CD 7
Twitch: TW-CD-07
1  120  06:58 The Shamen: Boss Drum
2  125  07:04 Gipsy: I Trance You
3  128  05:13 Rupaul: Supermodel
4  128  06:39 Paradise Organisation: Prayer Tower
5  131  05:58 Slave to External: Disintegrate
6  130  06:10 Fargetta: Music is Movin'
7  130  07:10 Outer Mind: I Still Want Ya
8  130  06:51 Daisy Glow: Give it All
9  133  05:23 Tasti Box: Asid
10 135  05:16 Lemon Interupt: Minniapolis
11 136  06:11 Intermix: Monument
12 143  05:09 Illuminator: Your Eyes Will Be Open

Comments: A more housier release than usual for Twitch.  Firing things off,
The Shamen's "Boss Drum" has been completely reworked into a groovin'
instrumental.  Other highlights are Lemon Interupt's "Minniapolis" and
Intermix's "Monument".  I was mildly disappointed in "Monument" though, it
doesn't differ drastically from the original.  "Asid" by Tasti Box puts analog
to extensive and almost obnoxious use.  "Prayer Tower" is another standout on
the progressive side with decent classic samples thrown in.  Taylor808 makes
his CD debut with Illuminator and Slave to External, which are musically solid
but tend to punch your jaw with sound bites that don't add much to the
original workings.  Gipsy, Rupaul, Outer Mind, Fargetta, and Daiy Glow are a
bit over the line on house for my tastes, but are well done nonetheless.

Summary: 7/10.  Didn't grab me as much as past Twitch releases.  Twitch did
throw in a couple of hilarious opener samples though.


System 7: 777
Big Life/Weird and Unconventional: BF LCD 1
1  124  09:31 7:7 Expansion
2  125  08:19 A cool dry place
3  138  07:47 Desir (Ghost Mix)
4  120  07:33 On the seventh night
5  130  08:02 Sinbad
6  127  09:46 Ship of the desert
7       07:23 Faydeaudeau

Comments: God help me, I love this album more than Orb's "U.F.Orb".  I tried
and tried, but the fact just keeps coming back, this definitely sounds better.
Even though Alex and Thrash threw their hands into "A cool dry place" the real
stunners are what follows with fabulous rhythms, Arabic themes, and real
innovation.  "Desir" is an energetic fast piece, "Seventh night" takes trance
through the sands of the Sahara, and "Sinbad" and "Ship" follow up well with
melodic mutating tracks.  The ambience of "Faydeaudeau" is sweeter than
anything I've heard in months.  Hillage and Giraudy have taken Orb's
inspiration to another level.

Summary: 10/10.  A masterpiece in green.  This will probably be domestic soon,
if you can wait that long.


Fortran 5: Persian Blues
Mute: CD MUTE 157
1  128  03:59 Original Mix
2  134  08:59 Full On Orchestral Philharmonical Mix
3  127  11:59 The 11.56 Sound Clash System Remix
4  128  07:15 3YE1270 Mix
5  128  06:16 Pulsation Mix

Comments: Fortran 5 return on the Arabian ship with their new single "Persian
Blues".  Although the orchestration of this piece is really swell, the vocals
are really poopy.  This is unusual since I enjoyed all the vocals on their
previous album, "Blues".  However, this time, they've got a male vocals
singing about petroleum in an overpowering manner.  Yes, it doesn't work, but
thankfully, there are two instrumental mixes, "Philarmonical" and "Pulsation"
as well as a mostly instrumental mix, "Sound Clash".  So things may look grim
in the F5 camp, but lets hope for a return to greatness on their album, "Bad
Head Park".

Summary: 5/10.  Fantastic music awash with an emotional political-ecologist
wailing about the Middle East.  Too bad I can't dance on oil wells.


SonnenSystem: Virtual Ambience EP
Paul E. Tan (03) 3476674 (Tape)
1  118  03:59 Subsonic Dreams (Organic Bliss)
2  109  01:55 Tropical Braindance (Abbreviated)
3  118  04:17 Master and Servant (SS "Brutality" Mix)
4  115  03:33 Heaven (I-Dom Factor One)
5  131  05:01 Deep Structure (Spatial Vibration Mix)
6  131  04:41 Deep Structure (Virtual Assault Mix)
7  106  05:21 Even If I Wanted To (I-Dom Factor Two)

Comments: A nicely produced EP tape from Paul E. Tan.  The opener tracks are
my favorites.  "Subsonic Dreams" samples a Meat Beat Manifesto rhythm and
makes it all its own, "Tropical Braindance" is short, but quirky and fun.
The "Master and Servant" remix, although capable, seems really out of place
after the first two original pieces, but not as bad as "Heaven".  The I-Dom
Factor tracks are very poppy, and although well produced, are on the wrong
side of the radio dial for my sensitive stomach.  "Deep Structure" takes
things in an Oldfield direction, yet in a darker sense.  The "Virtual Assault"
mix would be at home on any industrial comp.

Summary: 5/10.  I would really like to see Paul put the first two tracks on a
single and head in that direction.  They are really the best thing about this
EP.

From: Robert.Fanfelle@eng.sun.com (Rob Fanfelle)

To: trocha@netcom.com
Subject: Re: Foundation
Cc: sfraves@medisg1.Stanford.EDU




Yeah,  I went to Foundation.

I called the number and found out that it was less than 10 miles from my
house!  I was extremely enthused.  I decided to give the location a drive by
to see how secluded it was.  The rave was in an abandoned auto wrecking
garage on a dead-end street.  The building was between 101 and the San Carlos
airport/lagoons.  I figured that this was a pretty good location that should go
unnoticed.   (WRONG)

We got there around 11pm+ and was greated by your generic "Lyon security" dweeb.
After a $20 deposit we go in.  Standard faire with a few day-glow posters,
a tired looking juice bar, and four Port-a-Pods.  Still, I didn't expect TOO
much (hell it was close to my house).  There were about 50 people there,
some hanging, some dancing.  I was settling in to the music and the rave
Xperience when lo; the cops.  ACK.  Complete shutdown.

Some promoter stopped me on the way out and said that the rave was moving
to some backup location less than 10 minutes away.  It was midnight and my 
group and I were not in the mood to wait around.  We ate the cash loss and 
headed to Wicked. (an interesting drive)



-Rob "da Morph"

full list.  This workshop is set for Friday afternoon, but we still
need a space to do it in.
			G

----- Begin Included Message -----

From nexsys.net!geoffw@cdp.igc.org Tue May 25 12:29:38 1993
Return-Path: <nexsys.net!geoffw@cdp.igc.org>
Date: Tue, 25 May 93 12:08:01 PDT
From: geoffw@nexsys.net (Geoff White)
To: sfraves-planners@soda.berkeley.edu
Subject: First Aid/CPR training
Content-Length: 1361
X-Lines: 26
Status: RO

Sean O'Quin who is a Medical Consultant has offered to train people in
Basic First Aid and CPR for personnel involved in doing "Security" for
the Unity Benefit.  This first Training session is only for people who
are working/going to the Unity event who are interested in knowing how
to take care of people and be available in the event of a medical
emergency.  If this goes well, future workshops will be planned for the
entire community.  This training will be free (but a small donation to
cover the cost of the training equipment may be requested.) An
organizational meeting is scheduled for this Friday, please call Sean's
pager at 560-6068 code 60 i.e. <your_number>*60.

We also need a location to stage the training workshop (large room to
set up CPR dummies, etc.) if you have any ideas call Sean or e-mail
me.

Hi gang,

I'm going to be in the Baltimore/Washington D.C. area in a week or so and
I thought it would be swell if I could make part of the trip a working
vacation. The problem is, I don't know anyone that's involved the scene
over there (if there is one), and none of my friends do either. It's been
a looong time since I'd last been in that part of the country. If anyone
knows of the scene there, and hopefully some of the people involved, I'd
be eternally grateful if you could send any info this way regarding the
promoters/organizers/events and such.

Many Thanks in advance,
Lee



From SFRaves-request@medisg1.Stanford.EDU  Tue May 25 17:01:56 1993

	id AA17166; Tue, 25 May 93 17:01:56 -0700

	id AA01648; Tue, 25 May 93 16:19:05 PDT

	id AA01644; Tue, 25 May 93 16:19:04 PDT
Received: from pilot.njin.net by soda.berkeley.edu (5.65/KAOS-1)
	id AA14378; Tue, 25 May 93 16:15:36 -0700
Received: by pilot.njin.net (5.59/SMI4.0/RU1.5/3.08) 
	id AA11603; Tue, 25 May 93 19:19:00 EDT
Date: Tue, 25 May 93 19:19:00 EDT
From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)

From: bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu (Brian Behlendorf)
Date: Tue, 25 May 1993 16:16:33 -0700
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu
Subject: a question or two

    1)  I currently am looking at a private beach about 25 minutes south
of San Francisco for use for a party.  There are, however, two
caveats, though if one or two parties are held there after awhile
those conditions may be repealed.  It's a beautiful beach, plenty of
parking, and this would be 100% legal, but the music couldn't go past
1am or so (at least, not officially, but people can drum afterwards,
and/or if the vibe is right and the owner knows it, maybe it could last
til dawn) and also the owner would want $5 per person, since that's
what he asks for normal users of the beach.  I may be able to talk him
down to $4, but as it stands I'd probably ask $8 or maybe $9 per person
to have some good production and pay the DJ's what they deserve.

So I'd envision this as a "sunset serenade" party - maybe that's the
name I'd use, I dunno - starting around 6pm, ending at midnight or 1,
with free food and drinks and bonfires and a large soundsystem.  I'd
be aiming for 500 people, which the site could easily hold, and the
party would end just in time for people to make it to the next party.
On the advice of some people this would be on a Saturday.  Arranging
a bus would be expensive, but renting a couple of vans to drive people
from the Haight is definitely a possibility.  I'm not sure I'd want to
make it a Connection 3, but if this goes off well and the owner does
let us do an all-nighter I would definitely make that C3.  Also, I'd
use those vans to make sure people who Shouldn't Be On The Road make
it home safely.

I wouldn't do it as a money-raiser, I'd make sure everyone gets paid
and then give the rest to Malachy or a charity.  

Now, given those conditions, do you all think I could get a large enough
group of people to make it worth it?  I figure I'd need at least 250 to 
break even.  



   2)  Anyone know the current state of the challenge to the cabaret
laws in the city of San Francisco?  I have another site, outdoor, private
property, very close to downtown, I'm looking at which we could definitely 
throw something at but we'd have to make it 21+ :(  

Right now it is illegal, officially, to have an event with under-21 folk
in the city of SF that goes past 2:30 thanks to the curfew.  I intend to
spend time this summer CHALLENGING that, and I don't care if it's a
brick wall I'm going up against I want to at least try and stop this
sillyness.  Anyone interested in joining?

	Brian

>Yeah,  I went to Foundation.
>
>I called the number and found out that it was less than 10 miles from my
>house!  I was extremely enthused.  I decided to give the location a drive by
>to see how secluded it was.  The rave was in an abandoned auto wrecking
>garage on a dead-end street.  The building was between 101 and the San Carlos
>airport/lagoons.  I figured that this was a pretty good location that should go
>unnoticed.   (WRONG)
>
>We got there around 11pm+ and was greated by your generic "Lyon security"
>dweeb.
>After a $20 deposit we go in.  Standard faire with a few day-glow posters,
>a tired looking juice bar, and four Port-a-Pods.  Still, I didn't expect TOO
>much (hell it was close to my house).  There were about 50 people there,
>some hanging, some dancing.  I was settling in to the music and the rave
>Xperience when lo; the cops.  ACK.  Complete shutdown.
>
>Some promoter stopped me on the way out and said that the rave was moving
>to some backup location less than 10 minutes away.  It was midnight and my 
>group and I were not in the mood to wait around.  We ate the cash loss and 
>headed to Wicked. (an interesting drive)
>
>
>
>-Rob "da Morph"

Uh...the $20 BS pissed me off!  I talked to the guys who threw it and have
NOT stopped giving them hell for what they did.  I will be seeing them this
weekend at a friends house and I will route their asses some more.

LOOK, $20 for a RAVE in a warehouse is UNCALLED for.  I expect to pay
$20-$25 on new years, with a GREAT DJ lineup, in a GREAT space.  Those guys
shoulda charged  $10 the MAX.  If the production was pumped, $15, but their
porduction lacked even the basics most people have come to expect.

It is productions like these that are making people stay home
unfortunately.  This only makes the scne more and more like LA and degrades
the experience for first timers.  I hope they stop this trend, and soon.

I did see the crowd at wicked.  Looked as if everyone had a GREAT time
there...and uh, they charged $13-$15.  Now that's WICKED!  At least it is
good to know that there are some promoters who remain ethical despite the
fact others choose different routes!

I say NEVER pay $20 for a party unless it is MASSIVE and PUMPED.  $20 for a
warehouse?...gimme a break!

Peace :)

Message-Id: <9305260230.AA00288@slamdance.us.oracle.com>
Date: Tue, 25 May 93 19:30:36 PDT
From: Derek Chung <dhchung@us.oracle.com>
To: sfraves@medisg1.Stanford.EDU
Subject: Seattle update


Hi all!

I went to Seattle this weekend, and although I didn't get
a chance to go out (I was with my father), I managed to
figure out where I could have gone, had I been able to.
I suppose any of you SFR-people from Seattle would be
more enlightened, but here's a tourist's perspective.

One dance-music record store is Underground Dance Music
(they have house, techno, and hiphop), 422 E Denny Way
in the Capitol Hill area.  There I picked up some 
flyers for some parties called Kaleidoscope, Belgian
House Party II, Euro-Rave '93, and the (3 * GetDown + Wicked)
party in SF (!). Some Bay Area DJs featured were
Scott & Robbie Hardkiss, Bones, and Pasta.  I also picked
up a 12-page newspaper called XLR8R, which has interviews,
reviews, and a calendar; one of the issues I picked up 
also reprinted the info-E flyer that was done here.
The cover story this month was about the conflicts between
rave promoters and the cops (imagine that).
XLR8R listed a few more events, which include Garth,
Christophe, Carlos, Dutch, Markie Mark, and Dub Tribe.  
It also has a list of weeklies.  

An ad for Underground Dance Music listed an info line,
206.322.RAVE, which I assume is free, which is supposed
to list the weekend's events.  

The May issue also featured "top ten" lists from Moonpup
and Jon Williams, if you're looking to spend a little money:

Moonpup (a baker's top ten):
1. TC93 "Harmony" (white label)
2. Keekotronics and NLTJ - "Gimme the Funk" (Burma)
3. 290 North - "Spirit of 93" (Tomahawk)
4. Sounds of Silence - Lounge Lizards EP (Inner City)
5. Matter - "Don't You Want Some More" (Guerrilla)
6. The Look - "Glamour Girl" (Sexy)
7. Sounds of Silence - "DJ Equalizer" (Inner City)
8. Unreal - "Nairobi" (CT)
9. Gayle Lynne - "Rain Come Down On Me" - (Tomato)
10. Double Dee - "The More I Get, The More I Want" (Irma)
11. Phuture - "Inside Out" (Strictly Rhythm)
12. Cheeky Chunks - "Disco Yahoo"
13. "Bass The Night Away" (Spot On Records)

Jon Williams:
1. Acid Rain - "Twista" (UR)
2. Hawke - "3 Nudes in a Purple Garden" (Hardkiss)
3. Too Critical - "Coca-Cola"
4. Sven Vath - "Ritual of Life" (Eye Q)
5. Sonic Solution - "Arab Girl" (R & S)
6. Genesi - "White Dance" (Ishtar)
7. Megalon - "Semblance" (Plink-Plonk)
8. Choice - "Acid Eiffel" (Fragile)
9. Sequential - "Saturn Cruises" (Rising High)
10. UVC - "The Trip (Hydroponic Dub)" (Acetate)


and June's Tweekin' Records top 10:

1. Master Freez - "Listen to the Bass" (Irma)
2. Hawke - "3 Nudes in a Purple Garden" (Hardkiss)
3. D.I.Y. - "Mobile Music" EP (Strictly 4 Groovers)
4. Man Power - "Ring the Wave" (Global Cuts)
5. Hustlers Convention - The Dance EP (Stress)
6. Ready for Dead - "Ready for Dead" (Limbo)
7. Jump - "Luv It Up" (Dark Records)
8. Nation of Noise - "Feel the Joy" (Lock Groove)
9. Corduroy - "Something In My Eye" (Acid Jazz)
10. Stereo MCs - "Creation" (4th & Broadway)



-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 o derek chung  o  oracle graphics  o  dhchung@us.oracle.com  o 415.506.6195 o
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

As I've said to you in person, politicians understand two things...
Money and votes.
18-21 may not have a lot of money, but you do have the vote.  If you made
it known that you were going to have 18+ parties where people would have
the oppertunity to sign a petition to repeal the law and REGISTER TO VOTE
so that ypur voice would be heard.  I bet you would see some action REAL
QUICK!  Be sure to call the media so that they can see that these 18 year
olds are intelligent and are willing to follow the democratic process.
In fact if you had a 18+ rave JUST FOR THIS PURPOSE the resultant
publicity will definitely get the city's attention.

Hmmm... a petition would be a great place to start.  I'm leaving for Boston
for 10 days this Saturday so I won't make it to Get Wicked, but if someone
could go and maybe have a booth or a station collecting signatures that
would be great.  I know a "Hemp for Victory" stand will be there too. 

We need to do some research first:

1)  Find out if there's currently an appeal in the works, and if so, 
synchronize with whoever's running that so we don't duplicate efforts.

I have asked around a lot, and though I remember hearing someone had 
started something I'm getting nothing but blank stares (not just from the
list).  I will call Hallinan's office tomorrow and find out what's up.

2)  Find out the exact code ID in the Penal code/whatever the curfew laws
fall under.  I'm pretty sure it's a county or maybe even city of San Francisco
law, not a state law.  Again, a call to Hallinan may clear this up - but if
it doesn't would someone be able to go down to city hall and look it up?

3)  Decide if we want the petition statement to be a general statement or a
call for a vote on the subject - if the latter we have to limit the signators
of the petition to registered voters in San Francisco....  anyone have
experience with petition law?  I *know* some of you out there were around in
the 60's :)

Maybe just a general this-is-who-we-are-and-this-is-how-we-feel petition to
throw in their face at a supervisor's board meeting would be sufficient.
We could get a lot more signatures for this.

Let me know what you think about #3 - meanwhile I'll do some digging, and
maybe talk to the petitioners who always cruise around the Berkeley campus...

	Brian

Resent-To sfraves@nexsys.net ^ ? "/usr/local/lib/mh6.7/rcvstore +sfraves"

> a friend of mine is in LA right now, and I asked her if she'd get some
> new dj tapes for me.  I heard a semi-new Doc Martin tape where he's slowed 
> right down (I dont remember the name tho). If anyone is knows of any recent
> Doc tapes, please send me titles. -i really liked that slo style!
> 
> Also, where in LA should my friend go to find dj tapes?                          

> thanks                                  __
> -cato                                  / '>  tweet!
> (plui@iossvr.gm.hac.com)              /\ /\         (luvbird)

there are tons of record stores in la where you can find mix tapes. i
highly recommend that your friend go to melrose blvd in hollywood. there
are three excellent stores on that one street alone--including street
sounds, dmc, and beat non stop. and if she can't find what she wants in
those stores (highly unlikely), she can head east a coupla blocks to santa
monica blvd, where prime cuts, one of the first rave music oriented record
store in la, is located. if you can't get what you need at any of those
places, it doesn't exist...

happy hunting,
lee

             <9305262016.AA26030@netcom3.netcom.com> 
Date: Wed, 26 May 93 16:06:11 -0700
From: Joachim Vance (The Underdog) <jvance@einstein.oac.uci.edu>

> 
> can we please settle on one mail address?
> 
  I agree.  I do get sick of constantly adding to my .maildelivery
file.  but there are a few things you can to to shorten that list.
The main thing is to match on "sfraves@".  This covers almost all of
em.  Here's my few lines...  Hope this helps anyone with long filter
lists:

To            sfraves@   pipe A   "/usr/lib/mh/rcvstore +sfraves"
cc            sfraves@   pipe A   "/usr/lib/mh/rcvstore +sfraves"
Apparently-To sfraves@   pipe A   "/usr/lib/mh/rcvstore +sfraves"
Apparently-To sfraves-list1@ | A  "/usr/lib/mh/rcvstore +sfraves"
Resent-To     sfraves@   pipe A   "/usr/lib/mh/rcvstore +sfraves"
To       sfraves%nexsys  pipe A   "/usr/lib/mh/rcvstore +sfraves"
cc       sfraves%nexsys  pipe A   "/usr/lib/mh/rcvstore +sfraves"


BTW, aren't we all supposed to be using sfraves@techno.stanford.edu?

        The problems with the seemingly random mail headers has
been caused by the cluster of machines we use getting shifted around
as newer machines come in... sendmail on the newer machine was
acting funny, but a newer vrsion of sendmail was brought in and it
should be working now.  Anyways, the machines have been renamed too,
so no more medisg1, it's now, officially, techno.stanford.edu.  However,
sfraves.stanford.edu is the same machine, a simple alias for it, so 
even if you send mail to sfraves@sfraves.stanford.edu it'll show up
as "sfraves@techno.stanford.edu" in the mail header.  All the bs with
"sfraves-list1" and stuff should be gone now that sendmail is working
fine.

        So remember, the correct address, the one that will always work,
is:  (drumroll, please)

        sfraves@sfraves.stanford.edu

        which is the same (currently) as:

        sfraves@techno.stanford.edu.

*phew*  :)  Sorry about all the confusion earlier.

        Brian

confusing and usually three months late.  I got a copy of Mixmag Update
yesterday and even though it was a month old (it is a weekly), I was blown

their soul source of information are people I laugh at.

Subject: This week's RAVE guide

	I'm going on vacation for 10 days starting Saturday morning, so
if I go out Friday night it'll be my last for awhile (damn, and just as it 
looks like it's getting GOOD).  I'll have net.access of course, so I'll
still be maintaining the list and putting the calendar out... 

	Anyways, Friday night looks decent, DO could be quite good, and any
rave that advertises the price of admission on the flyer is definitely good
in my book.  The phone messages says it'll be somewhere in North Beach (not
the Stone), so Joe Bob says check it out.  I believe Alladin's Lamp will
be in the Sacramento area, so for those of you up there that'd be worth your
time definitely.

	Saturday night the choice is obvious: Get Wicked.  Looks like this
is the first in what promises to be a summer full of, er, large parties.  
Let's make sure the large parties maintain that vibe we all experience at the
small ones by supporting them 100%...

In a few weeks I will be leaving the east bay, my home of 24 years. In the
last few years a mysterious energy has been manifesting itself here in the
form of all night parties unlike any other, and it feels good to have been
in these houses:

Recess (the immediate predecessor to rave here? got your hall pass?)
E is for Everybody
E is for Everybody 2
Little Shellys Seafood Salad
Toon Town 2
Osmosis
Candyflip (the first house weekly?)
The Outlaws BART party
Mr Floppy's flophouse (the original multiday party!)
Mr Floppy's longest day
The Gathering
Woopy Ball (perhaps the most successful 2 night party!)
The Gathering: Vision (5 stars!!)
Community
Love in the Bassment
Wicked
Full Moon at candlestick park&Baker Beach
The Sound Factory (just a joke..relax)
Groove Kitchen
Mission Rock
Smartie Party (even though I fell asleep on the dance floor)
after hours at 187 Shipley
Sunny Side Up
Utopia Project
and so many more....

(ren voice) memories......

I wish luck to all of the sound systems who are taking the music 
giving it back to the people. Keep fighting. and keep dancing.

Please send some positive vibes my way and wish me luck in NYC! 

Love, peace, 120 beats
and fuck the hair grease...
Superhigh
and see you at mission rock!
dit@sybase.com

How old you want? 70s disco? 80s bubblegum remake? 90s dance?

It's probably "We are family/we all into love" by Unit3 UK. Some ragga on it.
I think it was out in 91, maybe 92. Popular in big dance clubs...
The 80s remake, i dont remember who made it, and the original song is:
"we are family" - (shit, a blank...hmmmm....) was it sister sledge? geez... i
wuz about 7 years old, so dont lapidate me if i'm wrong on this one... It was
around 1977 i would say...(good luck finding it)

Mon May 31st

A Day In the Park (in a San Jose park)

9 pm @ the FX (in San Jose) FREE!
DJs Rick Preston and Harry Who

Monday in the park is definitely worth checking out....

Deep Space was rocking tonight. DJs were Mark Farina, Rick Preston, Garth and
Spun. This weekly event typically has better music than most all-night raves
I go to these days. It's not big on Vibe, but there's no attitude either.
Definitely check it out if you get the chance. What do you know, there is life
in San Jose...

XDZebra Review #31

        Addiction
        266 Delmar Ct.
        Salt Lake City, UT 84101-1817

When in Utah call the T A S T E hotline 801-461-3375.

Trying to find these releases?  Try Ear/Rational Music:
FAX 805/893-8553, Phone 805/564-4949, email angst%cs@hub.ucsb.edu

Back issues are available from me by mail or by ftp'ing to soda.berkeley.edu.
They're in the pub/sfraves/music directory.

This is all my opinion.  Flames against a review are pretty pointless, so
don't bother.  Let me know if you have any other comments though.

BPMs provided courtesy of Eric Pederson's BPM calculator for the Sparc.

XDZebra Reviews may be reproduced without permission under one condition,
they remain intact and unchanged.  If you publish this in print, mail me a
copy via "Addiction".

------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Review #31 Contents:
Post Acid Crash Vol. 2
Falconer
<< Tequila Slammers and the Jump Jump Groove Generation >>
Bass Cube
Compilation 2
David Bowie: Jump They Say
Front 242: Religion


Post Acid Crash Vol. 2
Force Inc.: FIM - 1 - 007
1  148  05:36 Vinyl Countdown: Paroles
2  150  04:46 Force Mass Motion: Sub Sonix
3  141  06:08 Madonna 303: I Love You More Than Sex Can Say
4  153  05:29 Twin Drive: In - Sync
5  175  04:13 Car & Driver: Help Germany
6  144  06:39 Age: Underground
7  155  05:54 Biochip C.: Strange Invader Remix
8  149  07:33 Space Cube: Mental Terror (S.F. Acid Mix)
9  155  04:55 Car & Driver: Drive
10 165  04:07 The Modulor: Noon
11 149  06:31 Age: Strange Insight
12 156  06:18 Jammin Unit / Walker: Egglayer Queen
13 148  05:39 Walker: 303 Interface

Comments:  Force Inc. finally puts out a followup to the excellent Post Acid
Crash.  Once again, the acid on this disc is like sucking lemons, and there is
plenty of it.  The one complaint I have is the usual substitution of blatant
speed over texture in an attempt for the hardcore sound.  Car & Driver are the
fastest tracks on the disc, but thankfully they manage to pull it off well.
Other excellent tracks are by Vinyl Countdown, Age, and Force Mass Motion.  On
the underside, Madonna 303 is acidically strong, but uses a really insipid
sample, Biochip C. is a bit too on the Industrial-Belgian mode for my tastes.

Summary: 6/10.  Not as good as the original, but still the best collection of
acid around.


Falconer
Clockwork Records/CMV: CMV 08-5510
1  110  06:02 Earth Rise
2       02:25 Dream Scape No. 1
3  110  01:23 Studio (A Day in the Life)
4   90  06:32 Eve of Buddha
5       03:47 The Aurora Shrine
6  108  04:05 Dream Scape No. 2
7       06:08 Voyager
8  128  06:20 Last Moment (First Breath)
9   96  04:40 Primary
10  86  07:55 Final Transmission
11 110  03:43 Provincial Perspective

Comments: I was extremely skeptical when I saw this disc and its booklet
imprinted with a yellow sticker-like oval reading "Andy Falconer ex The Orb".
Usually a dependence upon old associations indicates a poor ability to stand
on your own.  Andy worked on two Orb tracks, "Into the 4th Dimension" and the
Apollo IX release, "Peace in the Middle East".  Word is that he also
contributed heavily to Hypnotone projects.  There are a few references to the
Orb sound, but there are more extreme departures away from it.  Funk with
"Final Transmission", jazz with "Provincial Perspective", shining "Ai" style
ambience with the two "Dream Scape" tracks, plus a healthy dose of
experimentation.  Most tracks are off the floor, but "Earth Rise" and
"Voyager" contain healthy beats that would work well.  Everything from baby
sounds to videogame music to Hillage style guitars have been mixed in by Andy
for an album that is quite distinctly his own.

Summary: 9/10.  Don't trust the label's dependent marketing.  This is a real
treat to listen to.


<< Tequila Slammers and the Jump Jump Groove Generation >>
Warp: WARP CD10
1  125  05:46 Jaco: Show Some Love
2  129  05:26 THK: France (Saturn Mix)
3  125  05:54 Solitaire Gee: Slumberland
4  120  05:10 DIY: Hothead (Original DIY Dub)
5  125  05:41 Coco Steel & Lovebomb: You Can't Stop The Groove
6  126  05:58 Nightmares on Wax: Happiness
7  125  05:33 Rhythm Invention: Ad Infinitum
8  124  04:46 Eternal: Mind Odyssey
9  118  09:35 DIY: Hothead D (W Insifignificance Mix)

Comments: The latest compilation from Warp is a bit of a disappointment in the
innovation area.  Usually Warp is plowing the way for the rest to follow, but
on this one, very few tracks stand out as something unusual.  Coco Steel &
Lovebomb and Nightmares on Wax present a pair of above-the-rest tracks.  The
only other entry that really grabbed me was "France" by THK.  DIY's work is
deeply cool bleepiness.  The "D" version of "Hothead" is more significant for
its high mixability than its listenability.  "Slumberland" by Solitaire Gee is
a decent builder.  Rhythm Invention comes very close to being boring, and the
inclusion of widely available "Eternal" is puzzling.  "Eternal" is a decent
track, but I would have rather seen Black Dog, Polygon Window, or even (gasp)
LFO.

Summary: 7/10.  Less than par compilation this time around.  Still leaps and
bounds above most other non-label comps.


Bass Cube
PANDiSC: PDD-8831
1  136  03:50 Bass Bass Music
2  115  04:18 Sicilian Brown
3  128  05:16 Planet Bass 93
4  102  04:47 Faraway Bass
5  137  04:10 Hittin' Bottom
6  128  04:25 Bass So Strong
7  144  04:25 Bass Feels Good
8  128  03:46 Ode To Billy Jive
9   79  04:49 Slo Jam
10 132  05:14 Basswerk
11 124  04:18 Arabian Bass
12  99  04:23 Dance While The Record Spins

Comments:  Whilst investigating monster-bass hip-hop, I ran across this disc.
What piqued my curiosity was the "Basswerk" track.  I was surprised to find
that there wasn't any bass present while I was first playing this disc, then I
realized that my tiny home stereo couldn't handle it.  If played through
headphones, you can almost hear it, like a subliminal wind in the background.
In other words, the bass is huge on here, and unless you have a system that
can handle it, it isn't worth purchase.  As for the tracks themselves, they
are mostly hip-hop with a bit of techno cross-over.  No rapping is present at
all, just a lot of insipid samples about bass.  "Basswerk" uses a lot of
Kraftwerk samples, and "Arabian Bass" uses the same "Wah ah wah wah" sample
that Orb's "Blue Room" uses.  However, there are some really boring snoozers
on here too.

Summary: 5/10.  Cool for investigation, but structurally weak.  Biggest bass
I've ever haven't heard, can't wait to try it on a PA.


Compilation 2
FAX +49-69/450464
1  148  05:43 Deltraxx: The Real Secret
2  140  06:04 Limelight: Mens, Mentis (Lex Durus Mix)
3  150  06:03 Subsequence: Healthy
4  150  05:36 Hearts of Space: Drawn to the Thrill
5  140  07:22 SynSyl: AngeLIcKES the dEVIL
6  150  06:54 4Voice: Catching the Scent of Mystery
7  154  05:41 Escape: Escape to Mars
8  136  07:05 Sequential: 20,000 Leagues Under the Sea
9  145  06:01 Sextant: It's Gonna Be Alright
10 140  05:22 SYN: Angel Kicks the Devil

Comments: Another compilation release from the excellent FAX records.
Compilation 2 did not impress me as much as Compilation 1 did.  Things are a
bit harder and a bit faster here.  Whereas Compilation 1's strength lay in its
hard trance, this is just plain hard and tends to fall through in that area.
Seqential stayed with the program and turned in a whispery, but uptempo
ambient piece.  4Voice is great once again with a sweeping pounder.  Another
chiller is "Drawn to the Thrill" by Hearts of Space, which brings to mind
Resistance D's "Cosmic Love".

Summary: 6/10.  Not near as good as Compilation 1.  A few gems, but mostly
harder crud.


David Bowie: Jump They Say
BMG/Savage: 74785-50034-2
1  126  04:23 Jump They Say (Album Version)
2  125  04:04 Jump They Say (Radio Edit)
3  125  05:02 Jump They Say (Club Hart Remix)
4  126  07:42 Jump They Say (Leftfield Remix)
5  115  04:42 Pallas Athena (Album Version)
6  115  05:36 Pallas Athena (Don't Stop Praying Remix)

Comments:  After hearing the raging ballyhoo over the Leftfield remix of David
Bowie's "Jump They Say", I finally broke down and bought the single.  OK stuff
but not terrific in my eyes.  Probably the worst thing I've heard yet from
Leftfield.  The real delight on this disc is the Meat Beat Manifesto remix of
"Pallas Athena" (Don't Stop Praying).  Usual funkadelic Jack Danger's
trademark, it makes commercial Bowie fun to listen to and move to.  As for the
rest of the single, there are two remixes by JAE-E which don't do much for me
and standard Bowie.  If he turns you on, I'd imagine you'll like it.
Unfortunately, I don't.

Summary: 4/10.  An especially good MBM remix, a mediocre Leftfield remix, and
trademarked Bowie.


Front 242: Religion
Sony/Epic: 49K 74928
1  130  03:34 Religion (7" Mix by Andy Wallace)
2  130  06:06 Religion (Pussy Whipped Mix by J.G. Thirlwell)
3  148  04:43 Religion (The Prodigy Bass Under Siege Mix)
4  130  03:40 Religion (Bitch Slapper Mix by J.G. Thirlwell)
5  140  04:56 Religion (The Prodigy Trance U Down Mix)
6  133  05:30 Crapage (Never Hurry a Murray Mix by The Orb)
7  133  05:58 Crapage (The Turd Mix by The Orb)
8  130  05:24 Religion (Lovelace A Go-Go Mix by J.G. Thirlwell)

Comments: It must be a difficult task for talented artists to remix something
that is complete garbage.  This is the case with Front 242's new single, the
completely pathetic "Religion".  In this case, they got some of the best
people for the money, and in the long run, only one person came out on top.
J.G. Thirlwell's remixes completely kick, except for when Jean-Luc De Meyer's
vocals are used.  Thankfully in the best mix, "Pussy Whipped" these are kept
to a minimum.  The Deep Throat samples he uses in the "Lovelace" mix are
hilarious.  Prodigy manages to do OK in instrumentation, especially in the
"Trance U Down" mix, but fails under vocals.  Last, The Orb floats to the
occasion and does a pair of crap remixes for a crap song named "Crappage".

Summary: 3/10.  Thirlwell manages to make the gold-plating stick, but more
often than not, the smelly dung underneath pokes through.

Subject: LA's benefit for Malachy
Date: Fri, 28 May 93 21:29:48 -0700
From: Joachim Vance (The Underdog) <jvance@einstein.oac.uci.edu>


   Today I got told by two people that a bunch of LA promotors are
getting together to throw a benefit for SF promotor Malachy.  

(for SoCal-Ravers who don't know of Malachy, he was very instrumental
in throwing small intimite gatherings in SF like the Full Moon Raves.
He was seriously injured in a car accident a short time ago.)

   Well, I just got off the phone with someone and have a bit more info.
The event will be called "Unification of a House Nation: LA to-gather"
(or something similar.  it was suggested by Doc.) and it will be on
July 10th.   
   A lot of major promotors are helping out with this thing and have
cancelled all events for the 10th so that all energy can be focused on
this event.  Shredder is donating a sound system.  I'm sure the DJs
are donating their time.  50% of the money would go to the Malachy
fund.  The other 50% would go to an LA charity or there was apparently
talk of founding a Drug Education organization that would educate
ravers and help people with addictions and the like.  They already
have Jeno and Thomas from SF lined up (and they're trying to get
Garth), and I'm sure every major DJ from LA will spin.

   It sounds like they're trying to make this a pretty big event.  I'm
going to see if I can attend the promotor meetings to find out a bit
more.   This sounds like the perfect direction for LA to move and
shows a lot of hope for the scene here.

Joachim

>From: Joachim Vance (The Underdog) 28 May 93 21:29:48 -0700

>50% of the money would go to the Malachy
>fund.  The other 50% would go to an LA charity or there was apparently
>talk of founding a Drug Education organization that would educate
>ravers and help people with addictions and the like.

i strongly support the idea of making a drug policy or research organization  
one of the beneficiaries of raves.  MAPS - Multidisciplinary Association for  
Psychedelic Research - seems to me especially worthy of consideration.  MAPS  
wants to improve the quality and survivability of the rave scene, and has  
contributed to the dissemination of benefit enhancement and harm reduction  
information about MDMA.  i feel sure the scene would benefit in many ways  
from contributing back to MAPS.

from their quarterly newsletter:

MAPS is a non-profit, membership-based organization working to assist  
psychedelic researchers around the world design, obtain governmental  
approval, fund, conduct and report on psychedelic research in humans. [...]   
If you can even faintly imagine a cultural re-integration of the use of  
psychedelics and the states of mind they engender, please consider joining  
MAPS in supporting the expansion of scientific knowledge in this area.

	MAPS / 1801 Tippah Avenue / Charlotte, NC  28205
	704 358-9830 voice 704 358-1650 fax

individual membership is $30/year, and gets you the quarterly newsletter  
(current issue is 48 pages) of research info, social & policy news, etc.

	We are progressing with the design of the Ultimate(tm) Renegade
	Sound System.  So far we think the system will cost around $3 - $4K
	not including amps, or turntables/mixers.  (does include, drivers,
	cabinets, active crossovers connectors, amp rack.  I would like
	people on the list to have an oppertunity to help us allong,
	we need a small amount of cash to do build prototypes, the total
	needed is $300, I'm willing to put in $200 of my own.  I'm asking
	for SMALL donations of around $5 - $10, no more than that, we will
	figure out something juicy that you get for your contribution,
	make suggestions.  Your money will go to building prototype
	enclosures so that we can have a portable system optimized
	for HOUSE music. As more autonomous, renegade sound systems become
	operational, it is your bet gurantee of having quality, low cost
	or free OUTSIDE parties, and events!

	Please see me if you want to donate or send your contribution
	to:
	    Geoff White
	   316 Escuela Ave. #62
	   Mt. View california, 94040
	   Att: URSS

	I will post a total of amounts received and what was done with the
	money in the next status message.  If you want to remain
	anonymous please say so.

Beyond the ultraworld of cmkoski@thunder.berkeley.edu:
> 
> Hello,
> 
> 	I am a student in Lakehead University in Thunder Bay, Ontario
> Canada

That's far to go to raves in SF! ( hmmm... i'm even farther... :P )

> and I would like to know (after reading Mondo 2000) how to get onto
> your bbs?

Cory, all well behaved email lists work with a request address and a reflector
address. The convention is to add -request to the handle.

Ex:  sfraves@sfraves.stanford.edu for the reflector (your msg was sent to all)
     sfraves-request@sfraves.stanford.edu for the request addy. When you email
     to a request address, you must put in the subject line: subscribe

Brian, i was going to email sirius with a list of all rave reflectors and the
*proper* way to use a reflector (including the conventions) but i dont know if
it's a good idea. Maybe just tell him the conventions but not the addresses?
I was also going to send it to wired and boardwatch. Should I?
[Brian Behlendorf - Vitamin B is the list maintainer, cory]

> Please send me mail, because I am interested in finding out more...

SFraves covers the bay area raves (that's the San Francisco bay). This is a
pretty good list, but if you want to go to raves and not just read about them,
i would also suggest to join:

Raving Up North (digest on the Montreal and surrounding cities like Ottawa/Hull,
                 Quebec, Burlington, Plattsburg etc... on the local rave scene.
                 Drop me a note if you want to subscribe as this is not a
                 reflector, so there is no request addy)
ne-raves@gnu.ai.mit.edu (reflector for the north east rave scene. dont forget
                         the -request when subscribing)

There is also a rave list for the midwest, the northwest, south california,
southeast, florida, and washington D.C. The first was sfraves (almost 2 years?)
then ne-raves 1 year ago, then Raving Up North etc... just so you know who
started it all (this list).

Ciao,
-- 
Francois Dion

From: Fred Heutte <phred@well.sf.ca.us>

Good to see another NW update.  As you may know, there IS a nw-raves
list now . . .

I've just returned from another incredible SFrave trip which I'll write
about elsewhere.  But I'm hoping for better things from the Northwest
this summer.  In recent months I've been to one excellent event at
La Luna in Portland, a semi-OK UHF one at the old Euphoria (featuring
a killer set by Markie), turned away from another UHF one, and a
couple of small things at Park Ave and one truly underground party
at 8th and Everett in a really cool space that just didn't attract
many people.  Haven't seen anything in Seattle yet, though I hope to.
But I have hopes for Portland and will try to make some local connections
soon.  

The news from SF is -- let the commercial crowd do what they want, it
is time to go tribal and spread it around.  Come/Unity and FMR have
shown the way -- with no more effort and a lot less hassle than the
pure-profit approach, the stealth rave is the way to go, in small
rooms, clubs or outdoors.  Surely Portland, Seattle and other Northwest
areas can be more than mildly receptive to this approach!

one left throwing good parties.  Sure, and you can tell from his style
that he is a harcore LA man (no games, rides, sponsers...past parties have
come with dancers and cages), but at the same time he seems to be the one
that attracts the best crowds.

To: Derek Chung <dhchung@us.oracle.com>

On Tue, 25 May 1993, Derek Chung wrote:

> 
> Hi all!
> 
> I went to Seattle this weekend, and although I didn't get
> a chance to go out (I was with my father), I managed to
> figure out where I could have gone, had I been able to.
> I suppose any of you SFR-people from Seattle would be
> more enlightened, but here's a tourist's perspective.
> 

As a native of the Seattle scene, I'd just like to verify and update this
information.  The scene here is pretty pathetic right now.  The topper
came just last Saturday when just about all the main promoters (Chris
Rosemonde (Mr. X) Dee-lyte (Tom) , The Clockwork people, Foundation 451,
Cat in the Hat prod, just about the only one's not involved were Mark and
Rich (Mark was previously Prophets of Psyche-AudioVisions)) got together to
do the Eclipse rave on memorial day weekend and only about 500 people
showed up.  What a change from a year ago's fourth of July rave nation rave
at Union station in which about 2200 showed, or even Halloween's Union
Station rave that attracted 2500.  This fourth, we'll be lucky to bring in
1000.  
	The situation between the cops and promoters has caused a lot of
problems that have defintely detracted from the scene.  The Seattle PD
has spread the malicious word around to space owners not to rent out to
promoters due to drugs and violence.  Promoters are constantly being
harassed during their parties to provide permit after permit.  Chris is
no longer allowed to have dancers at his parties since (in the cops
words) they see BUTTOCKS!  VIP rooms are also no longer allowed since the
cops must be able to see the full party upon entry.  Some promoters are
being forced to find spaces outside the city limits because of their bad
publicity.  Raves are strictly monitored by uniformed and UC police.  Not
the kindof environment to have lots of fun at.  When interviewed and
asked by The Rocket why there was such a control freak emphasis upon the
scene, the PD responded by likening the amount of people at raves with
those at concerts and cited some rowdy incidences at some recent Mudhoney
concerts.  Gimme a fuckin' break!  
	Anyway, it seems like the scene is just about dead.  Another reason
for the downfall seems to be due to the insurgence of yuppiedom.  Some
promoters, in hopes to make more money, began advertising heavily along
UW's frat row.  With this, went most of the UG which makes for worse
parties and atmospheres.  
	The club scene isn't too hot anymore either.  For anyone coming
here, Flowers on Wednesday's nights is still a good fun crowd and
atmosphere.  The Vogue on Saturday's can be good.  Fetish nights for the
hardcore are Sunday's at the Vogue, however if you show up, make sure you
look like you belong.  The Doormen have been cracking down as of late
because too many spectators have been coming to gawk at everyone.

	As for Portland, the main promoters there seem to be Blonde Indian
Productions (Minage and Brian) and UFO productions (Mark Meyers).  The
crowds there do seem to be a bit better.  The cops are extraordinarily
relaxed compared to the Seattle scene.  The average draw is around 500
people, not really a UG there though.  

If anyone wants any more info on the Seattle/Portland scene and/or
upcoming events please E-mail me.  If there are enough requests I would be
happy to post the weekly events and/or start up a NW raves
mailing list.  Funny how it's the only part of the country left that is
NOT represented.

BTW:  For you out of towners, I will be throwing a private invite-only
rave at my school...Reed College, Portland...with full bar and all the fun
extra's in July (tentative date, 24th) so if any of you will be in the
area, feel free to drop me a note.

-Arias

Beware of deceiving record store clerks!
After being cooped up for weeks due to
illness, I finally got some fresh air today
and hit the only record store open on Melrose
Avenue here in LA on Memorial Day, the very
inferior Beat Non Stop. After perusing the
meagre CD selection and finding a copy of
Twitch CD3, I asked the seemingly honest clerk
if he had a copy of the new Twitch release.
"This one, " (indicating CD3) "is their latest
release". Yeah right. And monkeys might fly
outta my butt.
--Tamara

> 	I have seen that the Full Moon will be on Friday, so I assumed
> the FMR would be on Friday as well.  But I have seen a couple people say 
> it will be on Thursday night...
> 	So does anybody out there know for sure?

> Gioni
> 

The Full Moon will occur on Friday June 4 at 1302 h Universal (GMT) time.
The Full Moon happens at the same instant all around the world, it does not
travel through the time zones. So PDT is 9 time zones (9 hours west of
Greenwich, England - 1 hr. for Daylight savings time =m 8 EARLIER, which makes
the exact Full Moon at 502 am Friday Morning, the FMR is always on the night
of the rising energy unless the Full Moon occurs on or before the evening of
the current day. In other words even though the full moon takes place on friday,
it happens friday MORNING, the rising energy is the night before!

[Taken from the FDA archives]
PRODUCT         Artificially flavored Strawberry Magic Fizz Popping Candy.
                Recall #F-344-3.
CODE            Uncoded.

MANUFACTURER    Coca-Cola Foods, a division of the Coca-Cola Company,
                Houston, Texas.
RECALLED BY     Manufacturer, by Fax April 7, 1993.  Firm-initiated recall
                ongoing.

DISTRIBUTION    Nationwide.
QUANTITY        1,300,000 packages were distributed.
REASON          Product is contaminated with metal fragments.

From SFRaves-request@techno.Stanford.EDU  Tue Jun  1 02:01:11 1993
Received: from techno.Stanford.EDU by soda.berkeley.edu (5.65/KAOS-1)
	id AA04025; Tue, 1 Jun 93 02:01:11 -0700

	id AA24599; Mon, 31 May 93 19:24:11 PDT
Received: by soda.berkeley.edu (5.65/KAOS-1)
	id AA11800; Mon, 31 May 93 19:20:39 -0700
Message-Id: <9306010220.AA11800@soda.berkeley.edu>
From: bbehlen@soda.berkeley.edu (Brian Behlendorf)
Date: Mon, 31 May 1993 19:20:39 -0700
X-Mailer: Mail User's Shell (7.2.3 5/22/91)
To: sfraves@soda.berkeley.edu, ne-raves@gnu.ai.mit.edu
Subject: Full Moon Parties, Renegade arties, and Site Finding

       Hi guys, it's Brian, posting from Laura's terminal in New Jersey.
Why am I spending my vacation time making a post to everyone?  Because the
Full Moon Party in SF is this Thursday night, and the one in Boston is
supposed to be Friday night.  Both parties, though, are currently without
a set site for their location.  

        The reason I'm posting is because I want to see both parties HAPPEN,
particulary the one out here because many people are travelling a long way
in anticipation of this.  I'm not as worried bout SF, because there are always
a few safe fallback spaces available. 

        So I'm going to present here the guidelines that I've been following
in deciding if sites mke a particularly good site for an outdoor unpermitted
party. Why am I telling you this?  Becausethis should motivate you to go out
and look for sites around where you live, maybe spark a memory of a location
you hung out at in high school, etc.  

	Now, if you're in SF, and you find a location which matches the
guidelines set below, send mail to geoffw@nexsys.net, as he's gonna be the
coordinator for the FMR there.  If you find a location within an hour of
Boston, send mail to Shannon (sscoen@gnu.ai.mit.edu) as he seems to be pretty
close to the Full Moon people (they say they can't find a location due to
"being really busy with Yellow", their for-profit party the next night).
If you don't live around these (or even if you do), look at this as a guide
to finding renegade sites.  This summer is set to be the summer of renegade
parties ALL OVER North America, and see this if you will as a primer, a guide
to finding a good location.

	The info presented here is the result of 10 months of location-
hunting, for both SFRaves events and the Full Moon parties in SF, and for
the most part the locations have worked fantastically -the FMR last month
in Palo Alto had 285 cars ~= 800-1000 people, and the cops didn't show up 
until 9am, and even then said to just be gone by 11am.  But more on that later.



THE DANCE SPACE - anticipate how many people you are gonna have, nd make sure
there's enough room where you're setting u the speakers and such for these
people - also make sure there's room for people to rest and relax without
harming the environment or others.  Grass is the best surface, as it bounces
back and doesn't make you tired as quickly as sand does.  Sand, especially
rocky sand, is hard to dance in, but if you find a space where it's hard,
and try and clear away any large rocks from the center, you should be okay.
Aim to provide a surface on which people can dance barefoot.  Try and avoid
dancing on concrete whenever possible, but also avoid having the dancefloor
be a bed of plants, because 10 hours of pounding Doc Martens are gonna kill
anything but the hardiest grass.  For this reason, avoid using the same
grassy space more than onces every two months or so, to give the grass a 
chance to grow back.  Also, dry grass can be VERY dangerous, particularly
for people who smoke and unconciously drop cigarrette ashes on the ground.

THE SOUND SYSTEM - Geoff White is coming up with some specs on what outdoor
sound systems should sound like, but in general terms, two speaker stacks
and about 1.5kw of amp power should be enough for any gathering of less than
1000 people.  Aim the system towards the waterif you're on a beach, or in
general away from civilization as best as possible.  Remember that cold air
can carry sound well, and so can water surfaces and canyons.  As for the 
generator, take your total wattage needed and multiply by two - most renegades
get 5kw generators which cost maybe $50 per night to rent - make sure you get
enough gasolin.  If the location is far away from civilization, you may want
to consider bringing extra needles (we found this out the hard way at C2) and
other small but vital parts, maybe so much as extra turntables or mixer.

ACCESS TO THE SITE - You want to have your system somewhat removed from the
road, as you want to be INVISIBLE to the casual driver passing by if possible.
But, you also don't want to make the sound crew carry their heavy equipment
a mile and a half, so try and find a reasonable spot.  The flip side, of
course, is that the farther away from the road, the less likely cops are going
to confiscate equipment (more on that later).  

PARKING - This is usually the weakest link in any site.  There are HUNDREDS of
gorgeous sites around the Bay Area, I kid you not, which are hampered by the
fact that they couldn't support more than maybe 5 cars :)  Anyways, you want to
get the cars as far off the main road as possible, parking them down a side
street, or in a big parking lot.  Parking attendents are mandatory if you 
expect more than say 30 cars.  If you have to park on the side of the road, try
your best to obey traffic laws, park outside the lines, and make sure there 
is enough room for emergency vehicles to access the dance floor if the need
ever arose.  You want to be as invisible as possible.  Also, have the parking
attendents hand out flyers to arriving cars saying, "Welcome to *blah*.  Please
leave your alcohol in the car.  Please be careful and aware of your environment
and each other.  Thank you, and a donation of $*blah* would be appreciated."

LEGALITIES - The ideal site is unincorporated land, or Bureau of Land
Management land, or simply property which has a history of being used by
the public at large for parties (high school hangouts in the woods are
good sources believe it or not).  Failing this, city parks, then county,
then on up the list - the higher the authorities whose toes you step on,
the more likely they are to be mean.  When they show up, as you should fully
expect them to, there is only one option - be completely upfront, honest,
call a spade a spade and say it's simply a group of kids who want to get
together and dance under the stars, and you didn't want to do it in a place
where you'd be bothering anyone.  Pledge to clean up after yourselves and
DO LEAVE your name and address.  In every case I've dealt with, being upfront
with the cops shows them you're not trying to be sneaky, and they will 
appreciate that.  If they give you a line about drug use, tell them they can
go around and confiscate any drug use they see: for the most part this'll
prolly mean dumping out people's beers, but people shouldn't be bringing beer
to an outdoor party anyways.  Anyways, do your best to work WITH the cops - 
don't see this as an US vs. THEM situation, because that'll land you in
trouble faster than you can say "lawyer".  If the cops insist on not letting
the party continue, then politley comply, tear down the system, and move the
party either by having pre-printed directions to the next site or a phone #
to call for further directions.  

DRUGS - as noted above, avoiding the obvios drugs is a definite plus. The
worst offender is alcohol, as not only will it piss the cops off, it's also
likely to harm the vibe and create potential "flash points" of violence.  
Nitrous is alo far too obvious, and it should be discouraged, particularly
if someone tries to sell it.

THE MORNING - as the sun is rising, you should anticipate stopping it if the
location is used by the public during the day.  You should also DEFINITELY,
DEFINITELY clean up after yourselves - bring trash bags and LEAVE THE PLACE
CLEANER THAN YOU FOUND IT.  Make sure others are in a state to drive home,
especially if "home" is more than 20 minutes drive away.  Carry Epheadra or
Vivarin orcoffee if you can to help people make it home.

Other assorted info: if the area is sensetive ecologically, try and maintain
a vigil around the sensetive areas to prevent too much damage;  keep in mind
in every gatheing there are Stupid peope who do Stupid Things, so be prepared
to educate them as to what's really going on... try and maintain a database,
if just in your head, of which cops are usually meaner than hich others; and
if you have a relative or friend or other sympathetic ear in the police force,
perhaps letting them know ahead of time, or gettingtacit permission, would be
 a very GOOD thing.

Okay, my machine's about to shut down, so I better go for now.  If I think of
more I'll post.  But print this out and keep it around all summer and beyond.
And I hope we can get it together this week.  Good luck all :)

	Brian

Yeah, I was going to reply to this thread asking what the hell was
going on...  

You're not *really* trying to tell me that it's illegal for people
under the age of 21 to go out at night.... ARE YOU ?  God, what kind
of a police state are you living in...?

I had enough difficulty comprehending the idea of a minor curfew when
someone on the net tried to explain it to me a while back.  But are
you really saying that this kind of thing is used against people over
18 too...?  Or is this just something to do with permits for clubs to
open late... (god, we have enough of that kind of stupidity here....)

I'm continually amazed by the opressive powers that the state seems to
have in the US...  I have this theory that the reason you Americans
take civil rights issues so seriously is because you have (virtually)
no rights...

Mind you, I'm also continually surprized by the way our government
manages to chip away at our rights without any objections from the
populace...  the powers that came about during the minors strike to
prevent people assembling, and to set up exclusion zones... the new
crack down on travellers....

Well, I guess I'm rambling here.... why can't we live in a world
governed by sane people...

	Cosmic Roy

Roy Badami writes:
 > You're not *really* trying to tell me that it's illegal for people
 > under the age of 21 to go out at night.... ARE YOU ?  God, what kind
 > of a police state are you living in...?
 > 
 > I had enough difficulty comprehending the idea of a minor curfew when
 > someone on the net tried to explain it to me a while back.  But are
 > you really saying that this kind of thing is used against people over
 > 18 too...?  Or is this just something to do with permits for clubs to
 > open late... (god, we have enough of that kind of stupidity here....)

Rather than teaching our children to deal with life's challenges, we
Americans try to protect them. Regardless of maturity level, we don't
let people drink until they're 21. We protect them from nudity and sex
because they may be SCARRED(tm) for life. Rather than teaching them
how to deal with things, we teach them that these things are Evil, and
that associating with them should bring great guilt. We take away
everything for them to do, and then are indignant when they spend time
"cruising" in their cars.

The Japanese said it right. Americans are basically lazy. They want to
do it the easy way. They're taught that they want kids, so they make
them. Then they don't want to spend time with them to find out who
they are, and how to help them be ready to make decisions. These kids
grow up and the cycle continues.

I'll start calling our society advanced when we start solving problems
and not symptoms.

Sean

(I return you now to your regular programming. DISCOnnected!)

	id AA12091; Tue, 1 Jun 93 13:29:31 -0700
Message-Id: <9306012029.AA12091@netcom3.netcom.com>
To: "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU>
Subject: nootropics? // quick review of (get down)^ 3 && wicked
Date: Tue, 01 Jun 93 13:29:29 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>


previous discussions mentioned the word "nootropic" -- whazzat?

--------------------

I went to the (get down)^3 && wicked party at the sonoma county
fairgrounds in santa rosa -- i mighta blown it off cuz of the distance
involved, but the fact that I had two "comps" for this rave (courtesy
of KFJC) and didn't have to stand in a big huge line made me go. I'm
glad I did. For a "big" rave, I found it most excellent, perhaps one of
the better ones I've been to this year. 3hree different rooms to dance
in, the big beautiful outdoors to chill in, a positive vibe throughout.
Didn't see as many sfravers as I expected, but i did run into Geoff,
Zak, M and P-ter, Ethan, Ovid, and Shaun (in order of appearance).
Other than that, I saw a few familiar faces, and lots of unfamiliar
faces.

Believe it or not, I liked the music best at the small hall near the
entrance. Carlos played a tasty crowd-hyping set there around 3:30AM,
and immediately afterwards some DJ that I didn't reconize played some
music that motorvated the booty to dance dance hard n' trippy. Who was
that anyways?

Best visuals happened in the big hallway at the rear w/ the arched
ceiling. The things seen were hard to describe, so I won't try, other
than to say that they made nice use of a laser, fog, and these
"searchlights" that scanned through the expanse of the room, briefly
illuminating gossamer filaments of swirly fog.  Due to the expansive
nature of the room, the sound was a bit too reverberant when we first
arrived there around 2:00AM, but got better later in the evening
(perhaps because as it got more crowded people's bodies damped out the
reflections).

I was enjoying myself just fine in the wicked room until someone blew
chunks on my eyes-of-buddha jacket, which was otherwise minding it's
own business on the back of a chair. After spending some time in the
bathroom cleaning it off (which seemed like an awesome feat at the time
given the way the bathroom fixtures were breathing), I decided to try
to forget about it by not returning to the wicked room... 

There was supposed to be an after party under the metal bridge in
Guerneville, but, come morning, I was too tired and decided to use the
last of my remaining energy to drive back to SF.... Did anyone go to
the afterparty?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==           Niels Mayer -- netcom!mayer -- mayer@netcom.com               ==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
