	Welp there are many articles and a couple FAQs on this subject
matter, mostly at either stein.u.washington.edu or at fenris.claremont.edu
under pub/drugs or alt.drugs or something like that, I do have a lot of
these but not handy so it you don't have ftp access I might possibly be
able to send it to you or something but this won't be easy so try a
different way please.
	From what I have read the FDA currently allows anyone to buy "1
months supply for your own personal use" of whatever from any foreign
company.  Though this might take many months to finally arrive at your
doorstep and you might be subjected to research and lited on their files
or whatever. 
	I know people who have placed orders, sent the money and never
received their supplies because the FDA is holding the order.  
	So basically do it at your own risk for you might get screwed.  I
have never ordered anything from Interlab or anybody else so this is all
2nd-hand knowledge.
	
Hope that is of help,

Later

Gioni Pasquinelli
gdpasquinelli@ucdavis.edu      What doesn't kill you makes you stronger

Date: Tue,  1 Jun 93 13:36:27 PDT
Subject: Re: Seattle/Portland update (Seattle Scene is DEAD!)

Polyphemus, o staring CRT tells me that on 3/31, Arias Hung wrote:

>>If there are enough requests I would be
>>happy to post the weekly events and/or start up a NW raves
>>mailing list.  Funny how it's the only part of the country left that is
>>NOT represented.

Um, there IS a mailing list already, and it is

	nw-raves@wimsey.bc.ca
		which is the general, higher traffic list, or

	nw-raves-request@wimsey.bc.ca
		for sub and unsub requests.

>>"The scene here is pretty pathetic right now. The topper came just last
>>Saturday when just about all the main promoters...got together to do the
>>Eclipse rave on memorial day weekend and only about 500 people
>>showed up."

Sounds like you didn't have such a good time; too bad, because I 
thought Eclipse was actually one of the better parties to be thrown in 
quite some while:

NOT 	overcrowded
	overfogged
	overstuffed with Shirtless Male Hunter-Gatherers
	overwhelmingly saturated with hairspray and _faaaaashion_
	overloud--good clean sound, I mean imagine _that_...
	overblown into this huge attitude feeding-frenzy

Merely o'erbrimming with two rooms of _killah_ free-your-spine 
grooving, an amazingly friendly crowd, fairly sharp eye-candy, enough 
room for everyone to really get out of their heads and NJOI, no hassles 
by the police, even friendly and courteous door/bouncer staff.  And 
everyone there seemed to be having a great time; high smile-wattage.  
For example, while I was admiring this woman's flawless styley 
bone-crunching grooving, I saw someone walk up to her, exchange a 
couple of words, and for her to start showing him what her steps were.  
I mean, how often do you see that?!?  Seems to me to be more of a 
return to what good raving fun used to be than a departure from it.

As another Seattle raver, I'd like to offer a slightly different 
clarification; true, there has become a rave "scene" as opposed to a 
rave community, somewhat aided by the "L.A. style" of the majority of 
the parties here (which IMHO produces nothing but high-profile 
exhibitionism and separation as opposed to creating a friendly 
atmosphere) but that's to be expected when profit motive overtakes the 
original purpose of sheer, unadulterated fun I suppose.   So now it 
takes a little more effort to push through the gloss and get down to 
the free-fusing core, which can usually be found somewhere near the 
front or beside the bins.  There are a small group of regulars that 
show and show and show and set off sparks.  As far as the cops and the 
bureaucracy goes, that's how the right-wing membrane recoils; if raves 
have to go further underground, I'm all up for it!


>>Anyway, it seems like the scene is just about dead.

Well, if Eclipse is an example of scene, post-mortem, then

			SCENE

			   RIP

		         ...good riddance...

Make way for something a lot better this summer!!

	<0>  Dread-Eye	"There's only one way out...and that's _up_"

	id AA17539; Tue, 1 Jun 93 13:59:16 PDT
Message-Id: <9306012059.AA17539@dlsun87.us.oracle.com>
Date: Tue, 1 Jun 93 13:59:16 PDT
From: Jon Drukman <jdrukman@us.oracle.com>
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
Subject: my weekend
Reply-To: spudboy%dlsun87@us.oracle.com

i apologize to anyone who went to SPLASH this weekend and wanted to
take a swim in the pool.  it wasn't opened because the Oasis staff has
yet to install a ladder, or something equally stupid.  casey sez next
week for sure!  (but then again he also said last week for sure, so
take it with as much NaCl as you need.)

-----

so, i was invited to DJ at a party called MASS which was happening
down in Fresno.  ordinarily, nothing could persuade me to drive that
far but it was being put on by two friends of mine and i managed to
con a ride in a much comfier car than my own.

the space was some abandoned office space (or something).  the
promoters invited the fire marshal to come inspect the space ahead of
time in order to avoid hassle at 3 AM.  this made things tidy and
legal but it meant that a lot of the planned spaces had to be
abandoned when the marshal said that (for instance) the basement was
off limits, no more than 3 people on the upper level at a time, etc
etc.  it did have one positive effect - as the turnout was pretty
small (just a few hundred people), it concentrated the partiers in one
space and made for some nice bonding opportunities.  and it wasn't
crowded or anything, so that was cool.

we got there while they were setting up and i was instantly whisked
away to Cal State Fresno where the weekend techno radio show demanded
a party DJ in exchange for promotion, so i got to practice my set live
on the air.  pretty cool.  immediately after finishing, i was zipped
back to the party where i tried out my hiphop/funk/nasty house set on
the unsuspecting crowd.  i managed to immediately alienate a few
people, so i knew i was doing something right.  fortunately, most of
the people i met said that they really liked the change of pace.

anyway, the party really went off nicely.  i had a great time, met
lots of new people, and left with that happy feeling that you get
after a truly great rave.  it also led me to a few observations about
the scene...

1) Ecstasy is an important catalyst.

I understand that we don't want to play up the scene as being one
continuous drug-fueled orgy, but having seen ecstasy use drop off in
SF and a corresponding increase in attitude & cliqueishness, I have to
say that the two are inescapably linked.  Obviously you don't *need*
to have everyone zonked on E to have That Vibe, but it certainly
helps.  Maybe we're all just too uptight to create a communal feeling
without having our inhibitions chemically dissolved.  Think about it:
how many people have just walked up to you and struck up a
conversation lately?  How many of them were on E?

2) SF no longer has a "rave" scene.

Maybe I'm an old fuddy-duddy purist, but to me there is a concrete
quantitative difference between "big party with visuals and techno
music and chill spaces and smart bars" and "rave".  For the latter,
there is always some kind of "vibe" - a feeling that is indescribable
but quite perceptible.  You know you've been to a rave when you leave
the party with a warm mushy happy feeling.  When you think back to it,
you get another warm little thrill.  When I started out on this whole
scene a year ago March, I felt this way quite often after leaving
events.  Now, I'm lucky if I leave with only a headache.  Experiencing
the energy and unbridled enthusiasm of the Fresno kids reminded me of
why I waited in incredible lines to pay $20 to get in all that time
ago.

I'm sure I'm going to draw a million flames for both of these
observations, but I stand by them.  My traveling companion absolutely
agreed with me on both points, btw, and she's been to even more
parties than I have...

Jon Drukman         spudboy%dlsun87@us.oracle.com        jdrukman@us.oracle.com
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Always note the sequencer - this will never let us down.

The CRysTall ball says again that Arias Hung, 3/31, enscribed

"That one big promoter you're talking about (aka Chris, Mr.X,
see my previous post on the Seattle/Portland scene) seems to be the only
one left throwing good parties.  Sure, and you can tell from his style
that he is a harcore LA man (no games, rides, sponsers...past parties have
come with dancers and cages), but at the same time he seems to be the one
that attracts the best crowds."

Hmm.  Well he's more or less the only one left throwing parties because 
from what I hear he's rather territorial, and not above being _not_ 
nice about it.  But being the only game in town and throwing GOOD 
parties are two different things entirely (IMHO).  Lots of fog, flashy 
lightshow, knobs up to 11, glam crowd with _lots_ of attitude, same old 
same old same old <yawn> thang...

For the benefit of promoters/DJs who are thinking of coming up here, 
that highly touted LA style (IMHO) strays dangerously close to being 
old, tired, proverbial-broken-whip-and-dead-horse-ish.  New ideas?  New 
toys?  Innovation?  _fresh_?  New attitude?  I don't think Seattle is a 
one-horse town and I'd be WAY up for seeing new promoters making forays 
into this area.

Just my $0.02.

	<0>  Dread-Eye

>.......Sure, and you can tell from his style
>that he is a harcore LA man (no games, rides, sponsers...past parties have
>come with dancers and cages), but at the same time he seems to be the one
>that attracts the best crowds. 

I guess I will start my response with my usual disclaimer.   First, whatever my
criticism may be, they are not intended to denegrate or condemn anyone. 
Second, my intentions are to attempt challenge anyone reading my missives to
think about perceptions (both theirs and mine) and how to best bridge varying
perspectives so that we can mutually gain an understanding of where we are both
coming from and where we would ideally like to go.  With that said, I shall
move ahead.

I guess what I look for when I go raving is for fertile ground to plant seeds. 
I look for an environment that is hospitable for the cultivation of ideas,
understanding and ultimately, a unity betweeen myself, those that I come in
contact with and with the environment that I inhabit.  In any given situation
I've experienced,  there will always be something that I will not like or agree
with.  From my perspective, that is a given for every single thing in my life. 


I agree with you, Arias, that Chris does draw a big crowd.  But does a big
crowd necessarily make a good rave?  Is it the prescence of those frills
(rides, games and leather go-go slaves...) OR even the lack of the
aforementioned make a good rave? For myself, I look for diversity.  My call for
other promoters to the Northwest area was not a condemnation of Chris but
rather a call for diversity in an area that sorely needs it.  My point is that
the Northwest is fertile ground for a good rave community.  Yet, it also has
the potential for stagnation.  I personally would like to see this "garden"
bloom.

Peace!

Glenn  

==============================================

	id AA20583; Tue, 1 Jun 93 16:24:23 MDT
Received: by slack (4.1/E&S_client-ver1.5/SMI-4.1)
	id AA00962; Tue, 1 Jun 93 16:24:13 MDT
From: pashdown@slack.sim.es.com (Pete Ashdown)
Message-Id: <9306012224.AA00962@slack>
Subject: Devin's "Vibes"
To: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU (SF Raves)
Date: Tue, 1 Jun 93 16:24:12 MDT
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]

Things have been cracked down upon here in Slick City.  Devin came up with the
great idea to bus people from a location a few blocks away to his event on
Saturday, called "Vibes".  He asked if I would DJ and I readily agreed, since
it seems I'm having trouble finding warehouses for my own events and the new
promoters here aren't as friendly with "Taste" as Devin's "Deep" is (silly
politics).  Geoff White mentioned that he might come out for it, but didn't.
Too bad...   Had the best time I've had in a long time and probably did my best
set ever.

The night started off with the police arriving.  There wasn't even anyone
there and the sound system was barely audible!  It was apparent that someone
was calling it in.  This happened all night long, with the police showing up a
total of four times.  However, with no alcohol, nobody charging admission at
the door, and people telling them it was a "free" event (they charged $5 for
the bus ride), they were powerless!  Devin put "back to basics" on the flyer
and that is definitely what it was.  Nobody selling anything, free water in
dispensers (we had to run back to my house in the middle of the night to get
more) and a "vibe" like you couldn't believe.

I had to do two sets, a half-hour at 12:30 and close it off at 4:00.  The
12:30 was fairly standard.  Beat matched for half an hour, about ten songs.
Nothing spectacular.  By 4:00 people were coming up to me and saying, "PLEASE
PLAY SOMETHING HARD" because none of the other DJs were doing it.  When I came
on, I played a bit off of "Sesame Street Fever" then dropped into a 175 bpm
track by Car & Driver.  People were screaming.  I kept the bpms high for about
twenty minutes, until finally in the middle of Speed Freak screaming "SUCK ME,
SUCK ME HARD" I cut the power to the turntable, threw on the De La Soul sample
where he says, "NOW WAIT A MINUTE" then dropped into this sweeping airy
beatless thing from B12.  God it felt GREAT.  Lots of Orbital that night with
the new album just hitting my hands that morning.  Devin called it the
"Orbital" rave ;-).  Also dropped the dance remix of Julian Cope that I found
a month or so ago and people luv'd it.  I listened to the tape later, and my
technique wasn't too great (of course, I never think it is), but that probably
had something to do with the fact that I couldn't resist leaving the table to
dance on the floor with everyone else.  I kept things going until 6:00 after
the sun had come up.  It was in a roofless old club and it just looked
spectacular.  First time I've made it to sunrise and been able to see it
happen.  Birds flying over in blue sky.  I can't wait until Solstice.

From: Bob Ramstad <rramstad@us.oracle.com>
To: geoffw@nexsys.net
Cc: sfraves@techno.Stanford.EDU
In-Reply-To: Geoff White's message of Tue, 1 Jun 93 14:09:39 PDT <9306012109.AA15677@nexsys.nexsys.net>
Subject: SAVE AMEBA
Reply-To: boccibob%groovy@us.oracle.com


I would strongly encourage anyone considering becoming a "limited
partner investor" in Ameba to undertake a full review of the books.
This is a prudent and intelligent thing to do whenever considering
this sort of investment.  Review of the books will make it clear if
the business has seasonal cycles and this is just a temporary slump,
or if the business needs rethinking / reworking.  It will also make it
obvious as to the magnitude of the cash flow problem.

I would also encourage anyone involved to have legal notarized
contracts executed which clearly delineate what you are getting for
your investment -- in particular, should Ameba become bankrupt, any
agreements should be spelled out in black and white and witnessed by a
notary, especially if you expect to be able to hold Mark personally
liable for the funds.  Obviously, any sort of profit sharing agreement
should also be properly handled.  (Any lawyer will tell you that
proper agreements in the beginning will save lawsuits and hassle in
the end.)  An important question to have answered in the contract: if
you are a limited partner, are you liable to cover your percentage of
any losses?

Finally, I would encourage potential investors to visit the shop,
examine the inventory, layout, etc, meet the employees, talk to people
here on SFRaves, and so on to get a feel for the type of business
Ameba is in and its particulars -- before assuming partial financial
responsibility for the business.

Note that I have nothing against Mark, these are all just intelligent,
prudent, possibly obvious suggestions before making any investment.

I realize that action is needed, and that there may not be time to go
through all of this, but...  hell, now that I've said this, at least
I'll be able to sleep at night if things get ugly for an ill-informed
investor...

Blah blah blah,
Bob

> > I was at a rave in S.F. awhile ago and I heard this song with the sample--
> > "We are family...I got all my sisters and me..."--- It's probably an old
> > track but no one around here knows who it's by.
> 
>   Francois> How old you want? 70s disco? 80s bubblegum remake? 90s dance?
>   Francois> It's probably "We are family/we all into love" by Unit3
>   Francois> UK. Some ragga on it.  I think it was out in 91, maybe 92.
>   Francois> Popular in big dance clubs...  The 80s remake, i dont
>   Francois> remember who made it, and the original song is: "we are
>   Francois> family" - (shit, a blank...hmmmm....) was it sister
>   Francois> sledge? geez... i wuz about 7 years old, so dont lapidate
>   Francois> me if i'm wrong on this one... It was around 1977 i would
>   Francois> say...(good luck finding it)
> 
> Yeah, it was Sister Sledge.  Wasn't a remixed version rereleased quite
> recently...?
> 
> 	Cosmic Roy

Yup, a bunch of old Sister Sledge tunes have been rereleased and remixed
by Sure is Pure and others. "We are Family" is the most well known of the
bunch, but you might want to check out "Lost in Music" as well. The new
remixes are very good in that they incorporate new acid and progressive
house sounds into the songs without destroying the original grooves that
made the songs hits. 

Lee

From: gmosheh@nyx.cs.du.edu (Gregor Mosheh)

Subject: Nootropix

Someone asked: Nootropic? Whazzat?

Nootropics are "smart drugs". Still experimental and "quasi-legal" in the
USA, they are very popular among the new drug scene.

Re: European Labs
Under no circumstances should anybody order from Inhome Health Products,
Switzerland or Interlab, England. Both of these places have been targeted
by the DEA. They'll send your goods all right, but chances are great that
you'll never get the package through customs. As far as I know, there are
two labs that still ship to the USA and get through reliaby. I'll post them
tomorrow or so, when I get the addresses from home.

I have shitloads of text files on drugs of all sorts. Write me if you want
more info. Most of it is from FTP and stuff, but I'll save you the trouble
of FTPing it all. Nice of me, eh? ;)

Rave on, d00dz.
 The Great One has a new Internet address:
                                               gmosheh@nyx.cs.du.edu.
He can be also reached in real life:
                                                623 Radcliffe Drive
                                                Davis, CA 95616-1011
                                                (916) 758-5589

Gregor Mosheh: The Twisted Anarchist With A Heart
                                                        -Jess J. Tapper

Hi every-dang-body!!!!

I had a grrrrrreeeaaaat time this weekend.  Found vibe and some just
nice fucking people who were cooler than i ever would have expected.
Where did i find this? TILT-A-WIRL!!  Jon in reponse to your post i
totally agree with you and most of your insights so this isnt a flame
but rather just a report that there are things that are dang "ravey"
(for all those that know me you know how much i dislike that rave word)
But back to the subject: My girlfriend and i decided that since our
friends are tending to be anti party ("its just a bunch of stupid
want-a-be markie marks (as in underwear) and false E induced niceness")
we were going to go out by our selves.  went to check out tilt-a-wirl
(heard good stuff about it).  Went there early 10pm, there was maybe 30
people there and about 3-10 dancing at any given time.  Music was
slamming!  but few people, the people that were there and dancing were
mostly doing the eyes closed-i'm-trancing-out-and-i'm-not-here-to-"be
seen" thang (right on! none of that "look at me" shit)

Tony's set started and he just was great, totally impressed.  Big, deep
and housey.  CHEbob saz check him out!  I saw a guy i havent seen in a
while and talked to him for a while (.5 hr) came back and there was
about 50 people on the floor.  Things went OFF from there. 

Next up was Goa Gil.  i hadn't even heard of this guy, why?  he was
in-fucking-creditable.  The heavyest tribal i have ever heard of.  I was
destroyed it was great.  I meet this guy jeff who independently meet my
girlfriend also he new some things about Goa Gil so learned some things.
as we were about to leave and saying our good-byes and all, already
feeling great, he said "you really like Goa Gil?, i'll be back" gave me
a DJ tape (his own i'm pretty sure).  This is the finest example of
selfless niceness i have experiance in a while, call it vibe if you want

this is way longer than i wanted so im gonna get da hell out.  by the
way tilt-a-wril was $7 Good deal.  also Mr. Happys disco was lame,
clickish, and full of club attitude, waste.

Peace,
the only legit rave gear is a Smile, the guy i was refering to was
wearing a surfer tank top and a pair of levis that fit.

CHE (gotta go to my radio shift, wish me luck for a good show)

From SFRaves-request@techno.Stanford.EDU  Wed Jun  2 02:02:34 1993
Received: from techno.Stanford.EDU by soda.berkeley.edu (5.65/KAOS-1)

	id AA23131; Wed, 2 Jun 93 04:03:20 -0400

	id AA05597; Wed, 2 Jun 1993 04:03:19 -0400
From: "Benjamin P. Wing" <bpwing@phoenix.princeton.edu>

	id AA24240; Wed, 2 Jun 93 04:03:18 EDT

Subject: Re: Justice goes to pot... (fwd)

Forwarded from LERI ...

|
|FORWARDED MAIL -------
|From: CIVL097@cantva.canterbury.ac.nz ("Brandon Hutchison,Civil Eng Dept")
|Date: 26 May 93
|Originally To: Multiple recipients of list ADDICT-L <ADDICT-L@KENTVM.BITNET>
|
|X-News: cantva alt.drugs:14827
|From: slp9k@cc.usu.edu
|Subject:[alt.society.civil-liberty] Justice goes to pot...
|Date: 25 May 93 21:18:52 MDT
|Message-ID:<1993May25.211853.68476@cc.usu.edu>
|
|--------------Begin Forwarded Article--------------
|
|Given the source of this article, I figured a lot of
|interested people might have missed it.
|
|Justice Goes To Pot
|by B. J. Oppenheimer
|
|As you read this, I'll probably be behind bars,
|serving a possible five to 40 years in federal prison
|with no hope of parole.  My house will have been
|confiscated by the government, and a fine of $340,000
|will have been levied against me.
|
|I'm a nonviolent offender with no prior record.
|Married for 20 years with two small children, I'm a
|college graduate and published writer.  I have a good
|reputation in the community and have been involved in
|many charitable organizations.
|
|My only crime was planting a handful of marijuana
|seeds....
|
|When I was first arrested for growing pot last
|August, I freely admitted my guilt, fully expecting to
|receive the relatively minor sentence usually meted out
|in marijuana cases.  Until recently, marijuana use and
|cultivation was decriminalized in many places, and even
|now it's only a misdemeanor in most states (including my
|own).  It usually warrants nothing more than a suspended
|sentence and a small fine when prosecuted at the state
|level.  Last year a man in Upstate New York was
|convicted of growing 154 plants - many more than I am
|charged with - and his only punishment was a $100 fine -
|less than a dollar a plant.
|
|My penalty probably would have been similar - if
|I'd been tried in state court.  But more and more, these
|cases are being turned over to the federal government
|for prosecution, where penalties are much stiffer.  What
|would've earned me, at most, a fine and probation in
|state court carries a mandatory minimum sentence of five
|years (and a maximum of 40) when prosecuted at the
|federal level.
|
|It's all because of recently enacted mandatory
|minimum-sentencing laws.  They impose statutory minimums
|for all drug crimes and prohibit the judge from any
|exercise of judicial discretion in arriving at a
|sentence.  The judge is enjoined against taking into
|account things like my reputation in the community,
|charitable works, or lack of prior record.  Since
|there's no such thing as parole in federal prison
|anymore, if I'm sentenced to five years (assuming I lose
|my case), that's how many I'll serve.
|
|Chalk it up to the government's "get tough on
|crime" policy: So what if a few undeserving people serve
|inflated sentences? It's worth it to keep the streets
|free from crime.  The problem is, rather on being tough
|on crime, the net effect of mandatory minimums is to be
|soft on crime - violent crime.  Since the are no
|mandatory minimum sentences for offenses like rape,
|child molestation, murder, aggravated assault, et
|cetera, violent criminals are often released early to
|make room for nonviolent first offenders like me.  The
|average murderer now serves only six and a half years in
|jail (versus the five years minimum I'll serve).
|But if our jail terms are similar, there's one
|important difference between the murderer and me: He
|doesn't lose his house.
|
|Even though my house was bought with legitimate
|earnings, and there was no marijuana grown on my
|property, it was confiscated by the police shortly after
|I was arrested.  The primary reason given was that
|fertilizer was found in my basement.  My house was thus
|considered a "facilitator" of the crime, which justifies
|its forfeiture.  When I learned that the government had
|seized my property on such flimsy pretenses, it
|infuriated me, but what bothered me even more was that
|they did it without even trying me first.
|
|Since passage of the Comprehensive Crime Control
|Act of 1984, property can be seized if one is merely
|suspected of using it in a crime.  It's not even
|necessary to be charged, much less convicted.  It's up
|to the individual to prove that he didn't use it
|illegally.  And since this is a civil forfeiture, and
|public defenders are only provided in criminal cases,
|he's forced to foot the bill for a lawyer.  Often he
|also must put up a bond, sometimes as much as $10,000,
|which usually makes fighting the forfeiture cost-
|prohibitive.
|
|In the majority of cases, the government simply
|steps in and takes the property without even bothering
|to charge anyone with a crime, and there's not a thing
|to be done about it.  Since 1984 almost two and a half
|billion dollars in property has been seized this way.
|There's another difference between the murderer and
|me.  He isn't subject to penalties for tax-stamp
|violation.  Even though marijuana is illegal, in many
|states you're required by law to buy tax stamps for its
|cultivation - at a cost of $1,000 per plant - something
|that's virtually impossible to do without incriminating
|yourself.  Yet even if you are somehow able to purchase
|the stamps without getting arrested but don't actually
|affix the stamps to the plants - in the wind and rain -
|you're still liable for a heavy fine.  And they don't
|just count the living, growing plants.  They count the
|dead ones and even the cutoff stems from plants that
|were thinned from the garden and thrown away earlier.
|Even though the total weight of marijuana in my case was
|under five pounds, with all these other factors added
|in, the fine was $340,000.
|
|When I asked my lawyer how the government expected
|me to pay such an astronomical fine, he said, "They
|don't.  They want to wipe out your assets.  Then when -
|and if - you get out of jail, they intend to garnish
|your wages for the remainder.  Of course, by that time
|there'll be all that interest...."
|
|But the fine is just part of my penalty for tax-
|stamp violation.  It also carries criminal (versus
|civil) penalties of up to five years in state prison.
|That's on top of the five to 40 years I'll already be
|serving in federal prison.  All for the crime of putting
|a handful of marijuana seeds in the ground.
|If this seems like a violation of the Eighth
|Amendment ("Let the punishment fit the crime"), it's not
|the only time the Constitution's been ignored when it
|comes to drug law.  Confiscation of property without due
|process is a violation of the Fifth Amendment.  Police
|can now obtain search warrants based on anonymous tips,
|which is a violation of the Fourth Amendment.  And a
|defense attorney's legal fees can be seized in drug
|cases, a violation of the Sixth Amendment.
|
|But if drug laws are chipping away at the
|Constitution, they're wreaking havoc on our prison
|system.  Federal prisons are currently at 146 percent of
|capacity, and drug offenders serving mandatory minimum
|sentences make up 57 percent of the population (more
|than half had no prior arrests).  At the current rate of
|incarceration, nearly 70 percent of all federal inmates
|will be drug offenders serving mandatory minimums by
|1995.
|
|The United States now imprisons more of its
|citizens per capita than any other country in the world
|(455 per 100,000 people).  That's compared to the No. 2
|country, South Africa, with 311 per 100,000.
|
|As stated earlier, violent offenders often must be
|granted early release to make room for this influx.  In
|a recent four-year period in Florida more than 130,000
|inmates (including muggers, armed robbers, et cetera)
|were released, and one out of three went on to commit
|new crimes.  The F.B.I. reports that the rate of violent
|crimes in America increased by 24 percent from 1987  to
|1991, and many people feel that mandatory minimums have
|a lot to do with it.
|
|But apart from the hypothetical increase in violent
|crime due to mandatory minimums, there's the undeniable
|increase in taxpayer costs.  The National Institute of
|Corrections estimates that in 1992, the United States
|built facilities for 2,000 cells (at a cost of $100
|million) per week to accommodate the exploding prison
|population - and construction costs were only a part of
|the total.  It's been estimated that in five years, the
|financial obligations incurred by U.S. corrections could
|be double the current national deficit.  On top of that,
|it costs on average over $20,000 a year to house, feed,
|clothe, and guard each of the 81,426 federal prisoners.
|And this is to say nothing of the increased cost of
|social services of inmates' families, which were
|previously being provided for by the inmates themselves.
|Over 30 million Americans regularly smoke
|marijuana, so it's not surprising that a lot of people
|in this country feel that it should be decriminalized.
|I'm sure that many people would disagree, but I doubt
|they'd dispute the fact that the penalties for marijuana
|use are not only unjust and illogical, but make an
|unconscionable waste of taxpayer dollars.  With violent
|crime making us all live like prisoners, it's time to
|stop freeing murders to make room for marijuana users.
|
|
|reproduced without permission from a recent issue of Penthouse
|
|-----------------End Forwarded Article--------------------------
|--
|Forwarded-By:
|
|Brandon Hutchison,University of Canterbury,Christchurch
|                  New Zealand
|

what age do you become an adult in the US....?  I certainly accept
that whatever age you choose, its arbitrary, and will always be too
low for some people, and too high for others...

It's just that I'd always assumed it was 18 like in the UK -- maybe
it's just my ignorance showing here.  Can 18-year-olds vote in the US?

sonically, visually, and mentally in the VORTEX.  Spinning you deep into

and Ernie Munsen.  Visual overload will be provided by Eye-Con

it, chill out in the ambient room by Arthur Kent.

be in  Santa Clara.

information line if you'd like to be put on the mailing/voice list:

>   Howard> Of course the best Niels-ism is the term "Love Phaser", which he came
>   Howard> up with after I commented on "projecting the vibe" by having phaser
>   Howard> beams of pure love shoot out of your forehead.  Niels should slap a
>   Howard> (tm) on that one before Wired and Mondo-2K pick it up.  ;-)
> 
> Yeah, this one used to confuse me.  Especially when people made posts
> about security confiscating their love phasers.  For a while, I though
> that a love phaser must be some kind of rave toy that was popular over
> in SF.... :)
> 
> 	Cosmic Roy
> 
I thought it was John Druckman who came up with it but I think your right
it was Niels, something to the effect of "next you`ll be telling me that
you are zapping people with pahser beams of pure love comming out of your
forehead" To which I replied "How did you know!"  This was back during
the "raving is" discussion as to whether there was mystical mumbo jumbo
involved in the rave experience or just plain physiology.  I agree,
Niels should (tm) it.  It started as a personal joke but we SF ravers have
come to use it to mean any party where the vibe is strong, on a party where
we anticipate that the vibe will be strong as in I'm going home and charge
up my luv phaser.  When some-one says their luv-phaser was confiscated at
the door they are refering to the fact that the harsh security and venue
basically killed any vibe that could have happened, but sometimes
a few are smuggled in ....

Goa Gil got the name 'cause he spins in Goa, India where there are suppose
to be some wild international house things happening, and he might also be
from there but I'm not sure about that. He and Axel from Germany
use small portable DAT machines to spin, partly because a bag full of tapes are
easier to transport than boxes of records. You might have noticed that night 
that there was some crackling noise during his set, and it sounds like he was
getting some digital drop-outs off his DAT's.

	Hey everyone, I've never tried to order Nootropics through the
mail, but (since I live in So. Cal.) I've bought quite a bit from our
good friends in Mexico.  The quality is just as good( from what I am
told), and it is relatively cheap.  Last time I went down, I bought
four bottles of Nootropil (800mg/30ea), and four packs of Hydergine 
1.5mg/24ea.).  The boarder patrol checked my bag SAW IT AND SAID.....
"go through."  No hassles!  They were relatively cheap, Nootropil was
$6.30 a bottle, and hydergine was ? ($35.09 Mex.).  So my advice is,
If you know anyone down in So. Cal. have them get it for you.  If you
don't have friends down here--MAKE SOME!!! If you have any questions
just drop me a line (easu252@orion.oac.uci.edu) my name is John.

P.S.  I'm no expert, but then again, who is!
P.S.S. Looking forward to a SF trip in late June.....

                            SMILE,
                     ------>John G<------
                     easu252@orion.oac.uci.edu

Beyond the ultraworld of Brian Sassone:
> 
> When I was growing up in Ohio (with the corn and the cows), the drinking
> age for beer was 18 while everything else was 21.  I don't know what it is
> anymore -- that was a long time ago...

Most provinces in Canada, it is 18. Xcept for ontario which is 19 and several
places are 21 in toronto ontario. This (combined with the restrictive 1 am
closing time in Ontario) is particularly ridiculous in Ottawa and Hull. Hull
is in Quebec and the other side of rideau channel is Ottawa, so you see a lot
of people driving from Ottawa to Hull at midnight cause in Hull it's 18 and
the clubs/pubs/bars close at 3 am..

> P.S.  Does anybody remember 3.2 beer?  :P

Yuk, light beer

Today Apple Pie, Chris, and I went to the Explortorium. On the first
Wednesdays of each month the admission is free. I suggest you you have any
out of town vistors or have  some time to kill by looking at some cool
exhibits. BTW, in some of the exhibits they have they do have soem ariel
pictures of the Bay Area. This could help in finding sites. :)
